A narrow passage between two buildings, as between the transept and chapter house of a monastery.
See Uncle.
A widow.
A place of shelter for cattle.
The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbow to wrist.
A dyed fabric with designs drawn on by applying a removable wax where the dye is not wanted.
See Aerie, and Eyrie.
A step or degree in any series, rank, quality, order; relative position or standing; as, grades of military rank; crimes of every grade; grades of flour.

A figure in which a word is separated or repeated by way of emphasis, so as not only to signify the individual thing denoted by it, but also its peculiar attribute or quality; as, <ldquo/His wife's a wife indeed.<rdquo/
An ornamental cup or vase with a large, flat, shallow bowl, resting on a pedestal and often having handles.
A grayish green antiseptic powder, consisting of a basic iodide and gallate of bismuth, sometimes used in place of iodoform.

The name of two plants (Sesamum orientale and Sesamum indicum), originally Asiatic; -- also called oil plant. From their seeds an oil is expressed, called benne oil or sesame oil, used mostly for making soap. In the southern United States the seeds are used in candy.

A nonplane curve whose tangents are all equally inclined to a given plane. The common helix is the curve formed by the thread of the ordinary screw. It is distinguished from the spiral, all the convolutions of which are in the plane.

A device which produces an intense, usually narrow, monochromatic beam of coherent light; called also optical maser.  It has various forms, and is used in various applications in science and technology.  The beam is produced by boosting the majority of the electrons in specific radiation-absorbing atoms in a medium into a higher energy level, from which they are stimulated by their own emitted radiation to drop back synchronously to their lower energy level, and emit light which is in phase (coherent).
A person who serves to provide medical care.
A dance of Polish origin, but now common everywhere. It is performed by two persons in common time.
One fully skilled or well versed in anything; a proficient; as, adepts in philosophy.
Glimmer; mica.
That at which one aims; the thing or end to which the mind directs its view; that which is purposed to be reached or accomplished; hence, ultimate design, aim, or purpose; intention; drift; object.
A slave in ancient Sparta; a Spartan serf; hence, a slave or serf.
Waste silk formed in winding off the threads from a cocoon.

A sequence of phonemes, often a word fragment, which constitutes the minimum unit of meaning or syntax within a given word.  A morph may be one of several variants of a morpheme, depending for its individal form on the context in which it occurs.  Thus the morphs -s and -es are variants of the morpheme by which the plural form of an English noun is expressed.
A kind of heavy colored fabric, either all silk, or silk and worsted, or silk and cotton, often called terry velvet, used for upholstery and trimmings.

A tenth; the tenth part of anything; specifically, the tenthpart of the increase arising from the profits of land and stock, allotted to the clergy for their support, as in England, or devoted to religious or charitable uses. Almost all the tithes of England and Wales are commuted by law into rent charges.
A kind of fur prepared from lambskin dressed with the wool on; -- used formerly as an edging and ornament, esp. of scholastic habits.

An imitation, representation, or similitude of any person, thing, or act, sculptured, drawn, painted, or otherwise made perceptible to the sight; a visible presentation; a copy; a likeness; an effigy; a picture; a semblance.
Fairy.
Millet.
A green vegetable dye imported from China.
Belief; faith; fidelity.
Africa.
That part of the human body which extends downward from the breast to the thighs, and contains the bowels, or intestines; the abdomen.
In cards, four successive cards of the same suit.  Cf. Tierce, 4.
Realm.
Stop; halt; hindrance.
A wink; a twinkling.
Foul matter; dirt, rubbed in; sullying blackness, deeply ingrained.

A former English coin, originally of copper, then of bronze, the twelfth part of an English shilling in account value, and equal to four farthings, or about two cents; -- usually indicated by the abbreviation d. (the initial of denarius).
One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a steersman.
tarsus.
The Dragon, a northern constellation within which is the north pole of the ecliptic.
One of the pieces of sod used to line or cover parapets and the faces of earthworks.

A serpent or monster in the lake or marsh of Lerna, in the Peloponnesus, represented as having many heads, one of which, when cut off, was immediately succeeded by two others, unless the wound was cauterized. It was slain by Hercules. Hence, a terrible monster.
Same as Tuy<egrave/re.
A missile weapon of offense, slender, pointed, and usually feathered and barbed, to be shot from a bow.
A genus of tropical plants, with large leaves and often with showy flowers. The Indian shot (Canna Indica) is found in gardens of the northern United States.
A series of things in a line; a row; a rank; as, a range of buildings; a range of mountains.
See Shawm.
Warrant; attestation.
one of the Titans.

In Mexico and the southwestern United States, a kind of plastered house or hut, usually made by planting poles or timber in the ground, filling in between them with screen work or wickerwork, and daubing one or both sides with mud or adobe mortar; also, this method of construction.
nonsense; balderdash; humbug; -- usually used in the phrase a crock.
See Mohr.
The act of twisting; a contortion; a flexure; a convolution; a bending.

A light and elegantly furnished vessel, used either for private parties of pleasure, or as a vessel of state to convey distinguished persons from one place to another; a seagoing vessel used only for pleasure trips, racing, etc.
Corrupted form Bolt.
A violent disturbance of the atmosphere, attended by wind, rain, snow, hail, or thunder and lightning; hence, often, a heavy fall of rain, snow, or hail, whether accompanied with wind or not.

A tree of the genus Acer, including about fifty species. Acer saccharinum is the rock maple, or sugar maple, from the sap of which sugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, by evaporation; the red maple or swamp maple is Acer rubrum; the silver maple, Acer dasycarpum, having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple, Acer Pennsylvanium, called also moosewood.  The common maple of Europe is Acer campestre, the sycamore maple is Acer Pseudo-platanus, and the Norway maple is Acer platanoides.
The act of belching; also, that which is belched; an eructation.
Any bird of the genus Junco, which includes several species of North American finches; -- called also snowbird, or blue snowbird.
See Do<ntil/a.
A blow; a stroke with something hard or heavy; a jar.
An offensive weapon, having a long and usually sharp-pointed blade with a cutting edge or edges. It is the general term, including the small sword, rapier, saber, scimiter, and many other varieties.
Agonic line.
A chore; to chore; to do. See Char.
a genus of bivalve mollusks consisting of razor clams.

An artificial hill or elevation of earth; a raised bank; an embarkment thrown up for defense; a bulwark; a rampart; also, a natural elevation appearing as if thrown up artificially; a regular and isolated hill, hillock, or knoll.
Same as Yaupon.
A bristle or bristles.
a genus of tropical American trees with palmately compound leaves and showy bell-like flowers.
A young bullock or heifer.
See <Eacute/tui.
Limit; bound; restraint; extent.
A viola da gamba.
The act of seeing; perception of objects by the eye; view; as, to gain sight of land.
The proximal segment of the hind limb; the thigh.
That which is exhibited to the eye; the appearance which anything manifests, especially any one among different and varying appearances of the same object.
A ring for fastening a hawk's leash to the jesses; also, a ring affixed to the collar of a dog, etc.
See Laund.
A Chilian shrub (Aristotelia Maqui). Its bark furnishes strings for musical instruments, and a medicinal wine is made from its berries.
A stale, or handle; a stalk.
The position of a vessel riding at single anchor and swinging clear of it.
Profound sleep from which a person can be roused only with difficulty.
A genus of small insectivores including the common European mole.
A soft composition, as of flour moistened with water or milk, or of earth moistened to the consistence of dough, as in making potter's ware.
Refuge.
Veneration or reverence of the Supreme Being, and love of his character; loving obedience to the will of God, and earnest devotion to his service.
A region or tract of land; esp., the open field, thinly forested or with bushes and shrubs; grass country.
A contemptuous speech or piece of conduct; a gibe or flout.
A country in Southern Asia; the two peninsulas of Hither and Farther India; in a restricted sense, Hither India, or Hindostan.
The Richardson's skua (Stercorarius parasiticus);- so called from its cry.
See Pavan.
See Slant.
An annoyer.

A South African shrub (Barosma) with small leaves that are dotted with oil glands; also, the leaves themselves, which are used in medicine for diseases of the urinary organs, etc. Several species furnish the leaves.
An encounter.
A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldic achievment.
A little pie.
A shard or fragment.
One who votes; one who has a legal right to vote, or give his suffrage; an elector; a suffragist; as, an independent voter.
In Guam and the Philippines, an idol, fetich, or spirit.
See Leech, a physician.
all the plant and animal life of a particular region.
An object that is a conscious or living object, and hence not a direct object, but an inferred object or act of a subject, not myself; -- a term invented by W. K. Clifford.
To live in, or as in, a stall; to dwell.
The act of wresting; a wrench; a violent twist; hence, distortion; perversion.
A register of daily events or transactions; a daily record; a journal; a blank book dated for the record of daily memoranda; as, a diary of the weather; a physician's diary.
a person who uses the left hand with greater skill than the right; a left-handed person.
A battle or tumult; encounter; combat; disturbance; passion.
An anvil; a stithy.

The chick-pea.
Trifles; jests.
An Irish serving woman or girl.

A rounded mass of anything, esp. a large pill.
The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being the external or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares, the openings of the nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.

Of or pertaining to the lores.
A poll tax paid by peasants absent from their lord's estate.
One who plays on a pipe, or the like, esp. on a bagpipe.

A perfect, or normal, feather.
The act of snuffing; perception by snuffing; a sniff.
The signs, abbreviations, letters, or characters standing for words, shorthand, etc., in ancient manuscripts, or on coins, medals, etc.
the other world; land of fairies.
The joint which connects the foot with the leg; the tarsus.
A projection in a building; also, a pier or mole; a jetty.
The daughter of Tantalus, and wife of Amphion, king of Thebes.  Her pride in her children provoked Apollo and Diana, who slew them all.  Niobe herself was changed by the gods into stone.
The rotating part of a generator or motor.  Contrasted with stator, the stationary part.
A maniple.
Anger; wrath; scorn.

An Indian of a linguistic stock of tribes of the Peruvian coast who had a developed agricultural civilization at the advent of the Spaniards, before which they had been conquered by the Incas. They constructed irrigation canals which are still in use, adorned their buildings with bas-reliefs and frescoes, and were skilled goldsmiths and silversmiths.
In the Cabala, a water spirit; in later folklore, a light and graceful spirit of the air.
A crowd, a rabble.
A very venomous snake of India (Bungarus coeruleus), allied to the cobra.  Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often with narrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.
A young hog. Same as Shote.
Any plant of the Arum family (Arace<ae/); -- have small flowers massed on a spadix surrounded by a large spathe.
A hump; a protuberance.
Fetters.
The Ottoman court; the government of the Turkish empire, officially called the Sublime Porte, from the gate (port) of the sultan's palace at which justice was administered.
A club; esp., a policeman's club.  Also called billy club
Same as Conine.
An open box car used on railroads.  Compare Lorry.
pl. of Tooth.
A bird; the flicker.

The character, sentiment, or disposition of a community or people, considered as a natural endowment; the spirit which actuates manners and customs; also, the characteristic tone or genius of an institution or social organization.
A crystallized substance of the composition C4I4NH, technically tetra-iodo-pyrrol, used like iodoform.
A smooth, flat surface, like the side of a board; a thin, flat, smooth piece of anything; a slab.
That which is destitute of light or whiteness; the darkest color, or rather a destitution of all color; as, a cloth has a good black.

A form of headdress worn by the ancient Persians. According to Xenophon, the royal tiara was encircled with a diadem, and was high and erect, while those of the people were flexible, or had rims turned over.
A genus of plant-sucking bugs.
A large basket or hamper of wickerwork, used for the transportation of china, crockery, and similar wares.
A farrow.

One of a sect or school of philosophers founded by Antisthenes, and of whom Diogenes was a disciple. The first Cynics were noted for austere lives and their scorn for social customs and current philosophical opinions. Hence the term Cynic symbolized, in the popular judgment, moroseness, and contempt for the views of others.
A spiral-horned South African antelope (Tragelaphus angasi) with a fringe of white hairs along back and neck.
Benzene.
A person having a common right or privilege with another; a partner.
That one of the four cardinal points directly opposite to the north; the region or direction to the right or direction to the right of a person who faces the east.
Profit; advantage toward success; benefit; value; as, labor, without economy, is of little avail.
Money or other valuable thing given to evidence a contract; a pledge or earnest.
A bird of Celebes (megacephalon maleo), allied to the brush turkey. It makes mounds in which to lay its eggs.
A coal broker.
A small bottle-shaped vessel for holding fluids; as, a flask of oil or wine.

A group of thallophytic plant-like organisms of low organization, destitute of chlorophyll, in which reproduction is mainly accomplished by means of asexual spores, which are produced in a great variety of ways, though sexual reproduction is known to occur in certain Phycomycetes, or so-called algal fungi. They include the molds, mildews, rusts, smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each.  In the two-kingdom classification system they were classed with the plants, but in the modern five-kingdom classification, they are not classed as plants, but are classed in their own separate kingdom fungi, which includes the phyla Zygomycota (including simple fungi such as bread molds), Ascomycota (including the yeasts), Basidiomycota (including the mushrooms, smuts, and rusts), and Deuteromycota (the fungi imperfecti).  Some of the forms, such as the yeasts, appear as single-celled microorganisms, but all of the fungi are are eukaryotic, thus distinguishing them from the prokaryotic microorganisms of the kingdon Monera.
See Ramie.
Whatever exists, or is conceived to exist, as a separate entity, whether animate or inanimate; any separable or distinguishable object of thought.
That which cores; an instrument for coring fruit; as, an apple corer.
A monatomic, hydrocarbon radical, C2H5 of the paraffin series, forming the essential radical of ethane, and of common alcohol and ether.
The back, or top of the back; a crest.
One of the ancient Scandinavian poets and historiographers; a reciter and singer of heroic poems, eulogies, etc., among the Norsemen; more rarely, a bard of any of the ancient Teutonic tribes.
A stunted shrub, bush, or branch.
A block or clay tempered with water, sand, etc., molded into a regular form, usually rectangular, and sun-dried, or burnt in a kiln, or in a heap or stack called a clamp.
A genus of composite plants (Buphthalmum) with large yellow flowers.
The vitreous coating of pottery or porcelain; anything used as a coating or color in glazing. See Glaze, v. t., 3.
The writ by which such persons are summoned.
Virtue; power.  See Virtue.
The members of the national, or king's, council which sat to assist the king in administrative and judicial matters; also, the council.
An abacus.
A carouse; a drinking bout; a booze.

A small evergreen tree (Theobroma Cacao) of South America and the West Indies.  Its fruit contains an edible pulp, inclosing seeds about the size of an almond, from which cocoa, chocolate, and broma are prepared.
A flat layer, or fake, of a coiled cable.
Any imagined frightful object, especially one supposed to haunt the darkness; a bugbear.
A small shield.
Silica, SiO2 as found in nature, constituting quarz, and most sands and sandstones. See Silica, and Silicic.
A male waiting servant; a servant who attends on a gentleman's person; a body servant.
A species of steel imported from the East Indies, valued for making edge tools; Indian steel. It has in combination a minute portion of alumina and silica.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk or white of egg; frosting.
A collection of huts within a stockade; a village; sometimes, a single hut.
A marine in the English navy.
A quantic of the eighth degree.
A genus of parasitic insects including the fleas. See Flea.
A loud, ringing sound, like that made by metallic substances when clanged or struck together.
A bay, recess, or inlet of the sea, or the mouth of a river, which affords anchorage and shelter for shipping; a harbor; a port.
A leaf of a book or manuscript.
See 2d Hanse.
A rectangular garment or piece of cloth, usually made of the checkered material called tartan, but sometimes of plain gray, or gray with black stripes. It is worn by both sexes in Scotland.
Same as Pixy.
A maker of ropes.
Relic.
a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.
The call of a hen to her chickens.
See dickey.
One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
A vegetarian who does not eat any animal products, not even fish, eggs, or milk.
A buffoon or merry-andrew; one that practices odd gesticulations; the Fool of the old play.
A distinctive mark, token, sign, or cognizance, worn on the person; as, the badge of a society; the badge of a policeman.
An invocation of, or prayer for, harm or injury; malediction.
Any object which is a very large example of its class.
A state of holding on in a continuous course; manner of continuity; constant mode; general tendency; course; career.
A union of three; three objects treated as one; a ternary; a trinity; as, a triad of deities.
A stump of a tree.
A low, continued moan; a murmur.
A guillemot.
A beacon tower; a lighthouse.
Quick, pungent, lively pain; a pricking local pain, as the pain from puncture by nettles.
Any one of numerous marine gastropods of the genus Turbo or family Turbinidae, usually having a turbinate shell, pearly on the inside, and a calcareous operculum.
A box.
A tribe of Indians which formerly occupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.
A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the Old World. Many species are known. See Coral snake, under Coral.
A saddlecloth; a housing.
The glossy ibis (Ibis falcinellus); -- said to have given its name to the city of Liverpool.

Ability to act, regarded as latent or inherent; the faculty of doing or performing something; capacity for action or performance; capability of producing an effect, whether physical or moral: potency; might; as, a man of great power; the power of capillary attraction; money gives power.
Stock; race; family.
A horse, especially a spirited horse for state or war; -- used chiefly in poetry or stately prose.
essential oil or perfume obtained from flowers.
Violent contest or striving.
Negligence or fault, as distinguishable from dolus (deceit, fraud), which implies intent, culpa being imputable to defect of intellect, dolus to defect of heart.

A well-known high-flavored juicy fruit, containing one or two seeds in a hard almond-like endocarp or stone.  In the wild stock the fruit is hard and inedible.
A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Switzer; the people of Switzerland.
A stuffed jacket worn under the mail, or (later) a jacket plated with mail.
Same as Buddha.
A kind of clay for making melting pots.
One of the terminal divisions of a limb appendage; a finger or toe.
A movement or piece in largo time.
That which comes, arrives, or happens; that which falls out; any incident, good or bad.
A tribe of American Indians including many of the Pueblos of New Mexico and adjacent regions.
an East Indian annual erect herb (Sesamum indicum); the source of sesame seed or benniseed and sesame oil.  Same as benne
One who works as a mason without having served a regular apprenticeship.
One of the whitish and elastic bundles of fibers, with the accompanying tissues, which transmit nervous impulses between nerve centers and various parts of the animal body.
To make rhymes, or verses.
An arrest; a legal seizure.
Song; melody.

The peceived object occasioned by the impulse or vibration of a material substance affecting the ear; a sensation or perception of the mind received through the ear, and produced by the impulse or vibration of the air or other medium with which the ear is in contact; the effect of an impression made on the organs of hearing by an impulse or vibration of the air caused by a collision of bodies, or by other means; noise; report; as, the sound of a drum; the sound of the human voice; a horrid sound; a charming sound; a sharp, high, or shrill sound.
A country seat; a country or suburban residence of some pretensions to elegance.
See 4th Crowd.

originally, a cutaneous disease with the appearance of the skin having been gnawed, and occurring under two distinct forms.  Now used as a generic term for over ten distinguishable diseases having visible cutaneous symptoms.
Ready money; a loan of money.
Straw.
A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in the glands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends in suppuration.

A colorless, odorless gas occurring in the air (of which it constitutes 0.93 per cent by volume), in volcanic gases, etc.; -- so named on account of its inertness by Rayleigh and Ramsay, who prepared and examined it in 1894-95. Symbol, A; at. wt., 39.9. Argon is condensible to a colorless liquid boiling at -186.1<deg/ C. and to a solid melting at -189.6<deg/ C. It has a characteristic spectrum. No compounds of it are known, but there is physical evidence that its molecule is monatomic. Weight of one liter at 0<deg/ C. and 760 mm., 1.7828 g.
Shape; build; form of structure; as, the built of a ship.
A large South American serpent (Boa aboma).
A society or congregation; a church or religious body.
Forced separation from one's native country; expulsion from one's home by the civil authority; banishment; sometimes, voluntary separation from one's native country.
A feast or festival; -- called also gaud-day and gaudy day.
A nest: a repository for the eggs of birds, insects, etc.; a breeding place; esp., the place or substance where parasites or the germs of a disease effect lodgment or are developed.
A mat or screen of fibers, as of the kuskus grass, hung at a door or window and kept wet to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to the shield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva.  Also fig.: A shield; a protection.
A bank, especially that of Venice.
One who is loved.
An Egyptian race thought to be descendants of the ancient Egyptians.
A rectangular iron frame in which pages or columns of type are imposed.
pl. of Shoe.
A scroll.
A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua, allied to the raccoon, having a ringed tail but with a longer body, tail, and nose; -- called also coati mondi and coati mundi.
A kind of turnip. See Navew.
A wood or forest; a wooded land or region; also, an open country; -- often used in place names.
A genus of carnivorous mammals, of the family Canid<ae/, including the dogs and wolves.
The hartbeest.
Ruth.

A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.
A seaweed of a reddish brown color, which is sometimes eaten, as in Scotland. The true dulse is Sarcophyllis edulis; the common is Rhodymenia. [Written also dillisk.]
The upper lip or helmet-shaped part of a labiate flower.

Liver of sulphur; a substance of a liver-brown color, sometimes used in medicine. It is formed by fusing sulphur with carbonates of the alkalies (esp. potassium), and consists essentially of alkaline sulphides. Called also hepar sulphuris (<?/).

The quality or state of being proud; inordinate self-esteem; an unreasonable conceit of one's own superiority in talents, beauty, wealth, rank, etc., which manifests itself in lofty airs, distance, reserve, and often in contempt of others.
Brushwood and thorns for making and repairing hedges.
A low, thorny, suffrutescent, crucifeous plant (Zilla myagroides) found in the deserts of Egypt. Its leaves are boiled in water, and eaten, by the Arabs.
an ancient Assyrian city.
A noisy quarrel; loud, angry contention; a wrangle; a tumult; as, a drunken brawl.
The namaycush.
Ghost; spirit.

The coalfish (Pollachius carbonarius).
A wandering; a roving or irregular course.
Smell; odor.
The stem of a fungus or mushroom.
A fagot of brushwood, or other light combustible matter, for kindling fires; refuse of brushwood.
The head; also, a knoblike protuberance or capitulum.
A train of vein material mixed with rubbish; fragments of ore which have become separated by the action of water or the weather, and serve to direct in the discovery of mines.
The act of strutting; a pompous step or walk.
The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abode of the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world; the grave.
A funeral song; an elegy.

Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire, made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burning some time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood or cardboard dipped at one end in a substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparation of phosphorus or chlorate of potassium.

A royal jurisdiction or domain; a region which is under the dominion of a king; a kingdom.
A ruffled varex or fold on certain shells.
One who muses.
To catch so as to hold.
A light two-wheeled carriage for a single person.
A timekeeper; especially, a watch by which small intervals of time can be measured; a kind of stop watch. It is used for timing the speed of horses, machinery, etc.
The upper leather for a shoe; a vamp.
The llama.
The act of demitting; also, a letter, certificate, or the like, certifying that a person has (honorably) demitted, as from a Masonic lodge.
A curve or surface, the locus of a point whose coordinates are the variables in the equation of the locus; as, a graph of the exponential function.
A little bag or budget.
See Gige.
The handle of an ax, hatchet, or adze.
any of various lithe-bodied round-headed fissiped mammals, many with retractile claws; a member of the Felidae.
An ovum.

A covered and inclosed entrance to a building, whether taken from the interior, and forming a sort of vestibule within the main wall, or projecting without and with a separate roof. Sometimes the porch is large enough to serve as a covered walk. See also Carriage porch, under Carriage, and Loggia.
That which diverts, and makes mirth; pastime; amusement.

A turning; a time; -- chiefly used in phrases signifying that the part is to be repeated one, two, or more times; as, una volta, once.  Seconda volta, second time, points to certain modifications in the close of a repeated strain.

Thin dry scales or scabs upon the body; especially, thin scales exfoliated from the cuticle, particularly of the scalp; dandruff.
Bread, -- generally a penny roll; the supply of food carried by workmen as their daily allowance.
music composed for dancing the conga.

A yellow crystalline substance (C15H10O7) of acid properties extracted from fustic (Chlorophora tinctoria syn. Maclura tinctoria, formerly called Morus tinctoria); -- called also moric acid and natural yellow 8.  It is used as a dye for wool, giving a color from lemon yellow through olive to olive brown, depending on the metal with which it is mordanted.
A cavity or hollow.
The language of the Osci.
Any Asiatic pheasant of the genus Lophophorus, as the Impeyan pheasant.

A substance in the form of thin sheets or leaves intended to be written or printed on, or to be used in wrapping.  It is made of rags, straw, bark, wood, or other fibrous material, which is first reduced to pulp, then molded, pressed, and dried.

A large genus of evergreen coniferous trees, mostly found in the northern hemisphere. The genus formerly included the firs, spruces, larches, and hemlocks, but is now limited to those trees which have the primary leaves of the branchlets reduced to mere scales, and the secondary ones (pine needles) acicular, and usually in fascicles of two to seven. a tropical American palm (Acrocomia vinifera) having edible nuts and yielding a useful fiber.

That part of the pistil which contains the seed, and in most flowering plants develops into the fruit. See Illust. of Flower.
A public shed, or portico, for travelers, worshipers, etc.
A ring fitted upon the head of a lance to prevent wounding an adversary in tilting.
Connection; tie.
A goblin; a bugbear.
The fourth month of the year.
A religious devotee or dervish in Persia.
The act of grazing; the cropping of grass.
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
Impulse of water flowing with violence; a dashing or splashing of water.
See Trode.
A priming tube connecting the charge chamber with the gallery, or place where the slow match is applied.
See Ey, an egg.
A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax (Linum usitatissimum).
A person who performs in a mime.
The dunlin.
Consumption; phthisis. See Phthisis.
See 1st Char.
A hydrocarbon radical, C10H21., never existing alone, but regarded as the characteristic constituent of a number of compounds of the paraffin series.
Wild oats, or darnel grass. See Drake a plant.
An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.

Any angle other than a right angle; the angle which one surface makes with another when they are not at right angles; the slant or inclination of such surface; as, to give a bevel to the edge of a table or a stone slab; the bevel of a piece of timber.
One who cites.
a lynxlike animal of Asia and Africa (Lynx Lybicus).
A pole or beam, esp. one used in Gaelic games for tossing as a trial of strength.
A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffen and support them.
A grammar.
The common newt; -- called also asker, eft, evat, and ewt.
A depilatory made of orpiment and quicklime, and used by the Turks. See Rhusma.
Form or mode of construction; general figure; make; as, the build of a ship; a great build on a man.
a sudden unexpected piece of good fortune.
Any gastropod having a general resemblance to the true snails, including fresh-water and marine species. See Pond snail, under Pond, and Sea snail.
A scarecrow, generally made of feathers tied to a string, hung up to prevent deer from breaking into a place.
A slayer.
A tortilla chip topped with cheese and often chili-pepper or beans and then broiled; -- eaten as a snack or light meal.
The erd shrew.
A resin exuding from a tropical American tree (Hymen<ae/a courbaril), and much used by varnish makers.
A kind of whip for flogging criminals, formerly much used in Russia. The lash is a tapering bundle of leather thongs twisted with wire and hardened, so that it mangles the flesh.
A low, moaning sound; usually, a deep, mournful sound uttered in pain or great distress; sometimes, an expression of strong disapprobation; as, the remark was received with groans.
The juice or other liquid matter that drips from flesh in cooking, made into a dressing for the food when served up.

A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of an aromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste.  It is valued for its odor and for its medicinal properties.  It exudes from the bark of a shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the Commiphora Myrrha (syn. Balsamodendron Myrrha) of the family Burseraceae, or from the Commiphora abyssinica.  The myrrh of the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, and partly the exudation of species of Cistus, or rockrose.
A match for firing a charge of powder, as in blasting; a fuse.
A writhing, as in anguish; a twisting; a griping.
A child.
The fluid which circulates in the principal vascular system of animals, carrying nourishment to all parts of the body, and bringing away waste products to be excreted. See under Arterial.
The one or single occasion; the present call or purpose; -- chiefly used in the phrase for the nonce, i. e. for the present time.
Pagan.
A numerous and widely distributed genus of perennial herbaceous plants of the order Cypreace<ae/; the sedges.
A luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast and dinner, most commonly about noontime.
A limehound; a limmer.
A fencer's foil.
The chambered sporogenous tissue forming the central mass of the sporophore in puff balls, stinkhorns, etc.
See sloakan.
Any one of several species of sparoid fishes belonging to Sargus, Pomadasys, and related genera; -- called also sar, and saragu.
a young unmarried woman.
A slab of stone used as a veneer for coarse masonry.
A short, sharp sound, as of metal struck with a slight degree of violence.
The world; a globe as an ensign of royalty.
A small membranous bladder or tube in which are inclosed the seedlike reproductive particles or sporules of lichens and certain fungi.
The act of draining, or of drawing off; gradual and continuous outflow or withdrawal; as, the drain of specie from a country; the project is a drain on resources.

A word of warning denoting that the king is in danger; such a menace of a player's king by an adversary's move as would, if it were any other piece, expose it to immediate capture. A king so menaced is said to be in check, and must be made safe at the next move.
Adherence; attachment; devotion.
One who wields an ax.
To show to be false; to convict of, or charge with, falsehood.
The iron lap used by diamond polishers in finishing the facets of the gem.
A long cut; a cut made at random.
Species; kind.
Faith personified as a goddess; the goddess of faith.
Grog.
A solid resembling an egg in shape.

A partly reduced copper sulphide, obtained by alternately roasting and melting copper ore in separating the metal from associated iron ores, and called coarse metal, fine metal, etc., according to the grade of fineness.  On the exterior it is dark brown or black, but on a fresh surface is yellow or bronzy in color.
See Ochrea.
The land belonging to a lord or nobleman, or so much land as a lord or great personage kept in his own hands, for the use and subsistence of his family.
A civil or military authority in Turkey or Egypt; same as Pasha.
The hedge sparrow.
pl. of Woman.
A sword.
The sound produced by anything that creaks; a creaking.
The brother of one's father or mother; also applied to an aunt's husband; -- the correlative of aunt in sex, and of nephew and niece in relationship.
an artificial computer language with a relatively simplified instruction set.
A hole; an aperture.
Great fear in view of impending evil; fearful apprehension of danger; anticipatory terror.
The act of staring; a fixed look with eyes wide open.
A framework of timber covered with boards to support rubbish; also, a framework of boards to protect miners from falling stones.
To twist together; to form by twisting or winding of threads; to wreathe; as, fine twined linen.
A white cosmetic.
To spot; to streak or stripe; to variegate; to dapple.
A cast from the hand; a throw; also, a flounce; a kick; as, the fling of a horse.
An instrument formerly used which somewhat resembled the violin, having three strings, and being played with a bow.
The young of a beast brought forth prematurely, esp. a calf brought forth before its time.
The part of a tree or plant remaining in the earth after the stem or trunk is cut off; the stub.
Any member of three species of African wild horses remarkable for having the body white or yellowish white, and conspicuously marked with dark brown or brackish bands.
any elderly pompous reactionary.
A property depending on the relations of light to the eye, by which individual and specific differences in the hues and tints of objects are apprehended in vision; as, gay colors; sad colors, etc.
To cover, decorate, or invest with a crown; hence, to invest with royal dignity and power.
The cessation of all vital phenomena without capability of resuscitation, either in animals or plants.
A mock; an insult.
A rubber of hard wood used in smoothing marble to be polished.
Same as Rani.
Thane. See Thane.
The protuberant part of a cask, which is usually in the middle.
A brush of twigs for sweeping; a broom; anything which sweeps away or destroys.
One who wakes.
A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes.
A cereal grass (Triticum vulgare) and its grain, which furnishes a white flour for bread, and, next to rice, is the grain most largely used by the human race.
The structure on which a spectacle or play is exhibited; the part of a theater in which the acting is done, with its adjuncts and decorations; the stage.

A portion of Great Britain originally under the supervision of an earl; a territorial division, usually identical with a county, but sometimes limited to a smaller district; as, Wiltshire, Yorkshire, Richmondshire, Hallamshire.
Summons to appear, as before a judge.
A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.
A small discolored place in or on anything, or a small place of a color different from that of the main substance; a spot; a stain; a blemish; as, a speck on paper or loth; specks of decay in fruit.
Any aquatic mammal of the order Cetacea, especially any one of the large species, some of which become nearly one hundred feet long. Whales are hunted chiefly for their oil and baleen, or whalebone.
Disregard or violation of law.
An ancient English fishing boat.
An open shed for sheltering cattle, or protecting produce, etc., from the weather.
Chrysophanic acid.
A native of India employed as a soldier in the service of a European power, esp. of Great Britain; an Oriental soldier disciplined in the European manner.
See Visor.
One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.
A present of books given to a meritorious undergraduate student as a prize.

A slender marine fish (Scomberesox saurus) of Europe and America. It has long, thin, beaklike jaws. Called also billfish, gowdnook, gawnook, skipper, skipjack, skopster, lizard fish, and Egypt herring.
A conserve made of grapes.
A flirt.
A gripe or seizure of the hand; a seizure by embrace, or infolding in the arms.
A Muslim who has made a pilgrimage to Mecca; -- used among Orientals as a respectful salutation or a title of honor.
A hunter.
A pet name for a cat; also, an endearing name for a girl.
The quality or state of shining; brightness; luster, gloss; polish; sheen.
To emit smoke; to throw off volatile matter in the form of vapor or exhalation; to reek.
See 1st Spade.
Defensive arms for the body; any clothing or covering worn to protect one's person in battle.

One of a vagabond race, whose tribes, coming originally from India, entered Europe in the 14th or 15th century, and are now scattered over Turkey, Russia, Hungary, Spain, England, etc., living by theft, fortune telling, horsejockeying, tinkering, etc.  Cf. Bohemian, Romany.
A small stick or rod used as a spike in thatching; a splinter.
A moment; an instant; as, I will be ready in a jiffy.
Leprosy.
A brisk, showy, gay man.
See Cross, n.
One who fries.
Any one attached to a Mohammedan mosque, esp. a student of the higher branches of theology in a mosque school.
A coarse umbelliferous plant (Ligusticum actaeifolium) with a large aromatic root.  It is found chiefly in the Alleghany region.  Also called Angelico.
A small owl; especially, the European species (Athene noctua), and the California flammulated owlet (Megascops flammeolus).
A book, especially an early form of book with pages stitched together, contrasting with the earlier scrolls; a manuscript; as, a DaVinci codex.
An elementary sound which is uttered through the nose, or through both the nose and the mouth simultaneously.
A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe.
Greeting.
A line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle; -- called also rhumb line, and loxodromic curve. See Loxodromic.

A substance, of the consistence of butter or honey, taken from glands in the anal pouch of the civet (Viverra civetta). It is of clear yellowish or brownish color, of a strong, musky odor, offensive when undiluted, but agreeable when a small portion is mixed with another substance. It is used as a perfume.
A thing; personal property.
A pool.
a valuable fiber plant (Hibiscus cannabinus) of the East Indies now widespread in cultivation.
See Carack.
Stay; stop; delay.
a magician or sorcerer of ancient times.
A piece of wood, usually long and slender, pointed at one end so as to be easily driven into the ground as a support or stay; as, a stake to support vines, fences, hedges, etc.

A colorless crystalline substance, C6H3.CH3.(OH)2, which is obtained from certain lichens (Roccella, Lecanora, etc.), also from extract of aloes, and artificially from certain derivatives of toluene.  It changes readily into orcein.
One who tames or subdues.
The grasscloth plant (B<oe/hmeria nivea); also, its fiber, which is very fine and exceedingly strong; -- called also China grass, and rhea. See Grass-cloth plant, under Grass.
A high, proud, stately step or walk.
A port or small haven; -- used in composition; as, Lambhithe, now Lambeth.
The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus and fore foot or hand.
An instrument for examining the depth or other circumstances of a wound, ulcer, or cavity, or the direction of a sinus, of for exploring for bullets, for stones in the bladder, etc.
A flat, or nearly flat, piece of metal, the thickness of which is small in comparison with the other dimensions; a thick sheet of metal; as, a steel plate.
A genus of American herbs, having showy red, white, or purple flowers.
See Tucum.
A violent collision or compression; a crash; destruction; ruin.
A bog or quagmire.
A fall or falling band.
A genus (Lotus) of leguminous plants much resembling clover.
A collection of traditions received by the orthodox Mohammedans as of equal authority with the Koran.
A square or oblong cloth of wool, cotton, silk, or other textile or netted fabric, used, especially by women, as a loose covering for the neck and shoulders.
A name applied to various skin diseases, but especially to ringworm. See Ringworm, and Sycosis.
A mean flatterer; a toadeater; a sycophant.
A pleasure boat; a vessel or boat of state, elegantly furnished and decorated.
See Clamp.
The whortleberry, or bilberry.  See Whortleberry (a).
An oily liquid derived from parsley.
One of a Dravidian race of men native of Northern Ceylon and Southern India.
A large and bright constellation on the equator, between the stars Aldebaran and Sirius.  It contains a remarkable nebula visible to the naked eye.
Proof.
A small-sized, well-proportioned, Spanish horse; a jennet.
One who deals in oils.
Any large ape; especially, the chimpanzee and the orang-outang.
The aspect of planets distant from each other 120 degrees, or one third of the zodiac; trigon.

A yellow or brownish red dyestuff obtained by the action of bromine on fluoresce<ium/n, and named from the fine rose-red which it imparts to silk. It is also used for making a fine red ink. Its solution is fluorescent.
A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, in consequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.
An iron collar fastened to a wall or post, formerly used in Scotland as a kind of pillory. [Written also juggs.] See Juke.
A spirituous liquor or drink distilled from potatoes; -- used in the Barbadoes.
A mark or depression in the middle of the abdomen; the umbilicus; called also belly button in humans.  See Umbilicus.
See Shah.
See Whaap.
A foreigner; one owing allegiance, or belonging, to another country; a foreign-born resident of a country in which he does not possess the privileges of a citizen. Hence, a stranger. See Alienage.
Whatever is produced for the nourishment or enjoyment of man or animals by the processes of vegetable growth, as corn, grass, cotton, flax, etc.; -- commonly used in the plural.
A Russian drink distilled from rye.
A light color of the iris in horses; wall-eye.
See Kish.
Printing and writing papers of particular sizes. See under paper, n.
In China, the official headquarters or residence of a mandarin, including court rooms, offices, gardens, prisons, etc.; the place where the business of any public department is transcated.
A meteor or brilliant shooting star, followed by a train of light or sparks; esp. one which explodes.
See Divot.
A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usually of a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidal fracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire with steel.
A kick, as of a beast, from impatience or uneasiness.
A small box, can, or chest to keep tea in, also called tea caddy.
A gridiron.
Same as Knop, 2.

Any one of numerous species of small clamatorial birds belonging to Pipra and allied genera, of the family Piprid<ae/. The male is usually glossy black, varied with scarlet, yellow, or sky blue. They chiefly inhabit South America.
pl. of Palpus. (Zool.) See Palpus.
The small or slender part of a thing; as, the small of the leg or of the back.
Love; affection.
a purgative made from the leaves of aloe.  Same as aloe{3}.
Such as is in common use; such as occurs in ordinary practice, or in the ordinary course of events; customary; ordinary; habitual; common.
A shout of pursuit or of war; a very of eagerness, enthusiasm, enjoyment, vengeance, terror, or the like; an halloo; a hoot, or cry, as of an owl.
A stalk or stem of certain species of grain, pulse, etc., especially of wheat, rye, oats, barley, more rarely of buckwheat, beans, and pease.
A peculiar substance obtained from the wool of sheep, consisting largely of potash mixed with fatty and earthy matters. It is used as a source of potash and also for the manufacture of gas.
The witnessing or concluding clause, duty attached; -- said of a writ, deed, or the like.
Union by league; alliance.
A piece of ordnance, consisting of a number of musket barrels arranged so that a match or train may connect with all their touchholes, and a discharge be secured almost or quite simultaneously.
A composition, vocal or instrumental, commonly of a lively, cheerful character, in which the first strain recurs after each of the other strains.

Any animal of the hog kind, especially one of the domestical species. Swine secrete a large amount of subcutaneous fat, which, when extracted, is known as lard. The male is specifically called boar, the female, sow, and the young, pig. See Hog.
The deity who assigns to every man his lot.
The top of the head; the head or noll.
Want of wit or understanding; ignorance.
See Weld.
A particular method or pattern of weaving; as, the cassimere weave.
A cavern.
The stress of voice laid upon accented syllable of a word.  Cf. Arsis.
A plate.
The first part.
A cactaceous plant (Nopalea cochinellifera), originally Mexican, on which the cochineal insect feeds, and from which it is collected.  The name is sometimes given to other species of Cactaceae.
See Oriel.
See Fascia.
A pledge.
A hoop or band.
A switch or whip.
Brilliancy of success or effort; splendor; brilliant show; striking effect; glory; renown.
The vagus, or pneumogastric, nerve.
The Turkish language of the Yakuts, a Mongolian people of northeastern Siberia, which is lingua franca over much of eastern Siberia.
A liquor made of rum and molasses.
A fon.

A game of chance, played with cards or tickets, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers by chance.  The player holding a card having on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer.  In some systems, lesser prizes are awarded for having some but not all of the numbers selected, such as four or five numbers in a six-number drawing.  A variety of lotto is called keno.  In another variety, the player chooses the numbers for the card or ticket s/he holds.  There may be from three to seven different numbers on a card or ticket.  In a modern computerized lotto system conducted by state authorities, the player chooses numbers, or allows the computer to choose numbers at random, which are then printed on a ticket that the player holds until the winning number is selected.
A large African antelope (Alcelaphus tora). It has widely divergent, strongly ringed horns.
A cow or calf; -- familiarly so called.
Second best wool from Merino sheep.
See Click.
An evil. See Mala.
The four of cards or dice.
A half.
A minnow.
See Muraena.

The mesial plane dividing the body of an animal into similar right and left halves. The line in which it meets the dorsal surface has been called the dorsimeson, and the corresponding ventral edge the ventrimeson.
Any of several thermoplastic polyamide plastics, comprising a family of high-strength resilient synthetic materials, used mostly in fibers.
An anglo-Saxon copper coin of the lowest value, being worth half a farthing.
A kind of quadrangular piece of cloth put on by the Jews when repeating prayers in the synagogues.

A member of the solar system which usually moves in an elongated orbit, approaching very near to the sun in its perihelion, and receding to a very great distance from it at its aphelion. A comet commonly consists of three parts: the nucleus, the envelope, or coma, and the tail; but one or more of these parts is frequently wanting. See Illustration in Appendix.
A genus of plants, of the order Arace<ae/.
An instrument of punishment or torture resembling the knout, used in Russia.
Soft, moist earth or clay, having an adhesive quality; viscous mud.
A genus of Carnivora including the common bears.
Sherry.  See Sherry.
Bohea tea, an inferior kind of black tea. See under Tea.
The exterior wooden rim, or a segment of the rim, of a wheel, supported by the spokes.
A plum; esp., a dried plum, used in cookery; as, French or Turkish prunes; California prunes.
A puppet.
A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end.
noisy and mischievous merrymaking.
A large drinking vessel; also, its contents.

A tailless furry marsupial (Phascolarctos cinereus), found in Australia. The female carries her young on the back of her neck. Called also Australian bear, koala bear, native bear, and native sloth.  The koala lives almost all of its life in trees, moves sluggishly like a sloth, and eats eucalyptus leaves almost exclusively.
A bugbear; false terror.
One of several species of European thrushes, especially the blackbird (Merula merula, or Turdus merula), and the mountain or ring ousel (Turdus torquatus).
A black flag with white skull and crossbones, formerly used by pirates; -- called also Jolly Roger and pirate flag.
The husks and other refuse of rice mills, used to adulterate oil cake, or linseed cake.
A basin.
To stand at the flank or side of; to border upon.
A British trout usually regarded as a variety (var. Cambricus) of the salmon trout.
Same as Vugg.
A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream.
See Skate, for the foot.
The chief city of France.
One who tries; one who makes experiments; one who examines anything by a test or standard.

A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonance in the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving to each several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound of speech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whether made with or without vocality, derives its character in every case from some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, a letter or character which represents such a sound.  See Guide to Pronunciation, <sect/<sect/ 5, 146-149.
The rich, oily, and yellowish part of milk, which, when the milk stands unagitated, rises, and collects on the surface. It is the part of milk from which butter is obtained.
A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance; a pennon.
A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil.  It has an unpleasant garlic odor.
A piece of rope spliced into a circular wreath, and put round a block for hanging it.

Any of a large class of compounds characterized by a five-membered ring which contains an atom of nitrogen and at least one other noncarbon atom (nitrogen, oxygen, sulphur). The prefixes furo-, thio, and pyrro- are used to distinguish three subclasses of azoles, which may be regarded as derived respectively from furfuran, thiophene, and pyrrol by replacement of the CH group by nitrogen; as, furo-monazole. Names exactly analogous to those for the azines are also used; as, oxazole, diazole, etc.
Same as Donat. Piers Plowman.
The benevolent spirits of the dead, especially of dead ancestors, regarded as family deities and protectors.
See Smirk.
A yeoman.
Russia leather.
Clay, or potter's earth; sometimes pure clay, or alumina. See Clay.

A loose outer garment; especially, a gown forming a part of European modern costume for women and children; also, a coarse shirtlike garment worn by some workmen over their other clothes; a smock frock; as, a marketman's frock.
One chosen or set apart.
Same as Lorry, or Lorrie.

An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whose sides are equal and the opposite sides parallel.  The angles may be unequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the angles may be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.
A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple.
A flat-bottomed boat or lighter, -- used in Holland and the Baltic, and sometimes armed in case of war.
Any pied animal; esp., a pied or <ldquo/painted<rdquo/ horse.
A kind of light cotton or linen fabric, often woven in openwork patterns, -- used for curtains, etc,; -- called also India scrim.
A climate; a tract or region of the earth. See Climate.
Any species of the genus Manis, or family Manidae.
A genus of fish comprising the true gudgeons.
Same as Basil, a sheepskin.
See Fiord.
See Clef.
The Greek letter <SIGMA/, <sigma/, or <sigmat/ (English S, or s). It originally had the form of the English C.

One who nourishes; a person who supplies food, tends, or brings up; as: (a) A woman who has the care of young children; especially, one who suckles an infant not her own. (b) A person, especially a woman, who has the care of the sick or infirm.

Any of a variety of edible unleavened doughey preparations made from flour, eggs and water, originating in Italy, and shaped into various forms, such as solid strings (as spaghetti), hollow tubes, or layered squares (ravioli).  They may be mixed with various sauces, often having a tomato base, or filled with meat or cheese fillings.
A little dell or valley; a flat piece of low, moist ground.

Any one of several species of large odd-toed ungulates belonging to Tapirus, Elasmognathus, and allied genera. They have a long prehensile upper lip, short ears, short and stout legs, a short, thick tail, and short, close hair. They have three toes on the hind feet, and four toes on the fore feet, but the outermost toe is of little use.
One who plays on a fife.
Grasp; seizure; fast hold; clutch.
A paddock, or toad.
A strong tide or current, especially in a narrow channel.
The act of sousing, or swooping.
A kind of wooden shoe worn by the peasantry in France, Belgium, Sweden, and some other European countries.
A jet of steam issuing from a fissure in the earth.
Abstinence from sleep, whether at a time when sleep is customary or not; the act of keeping awake, or the state of being awake; sleeplessness; wakefulness; watch.
In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder, Frigg, and the others.  Their home was called Asgard.
Ant<ae/. See Anta.
The fluid which descends from the clouds in rain, and which forms rivers, lakes, seas, etc.
The manta ray.  See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil.
See Pasch and Easter.
See Uhlan.
A petty contrivance; a toy; a plaything; a knickknack.
See Fisher, 2.
The sound produced by soughing; a hollow murmur or roaring.
Grieved for the loss of some good; pained for some evil; feeling regret; -- now generally used to express light grief or affliction, but formerly often used to express deeper feeling.
The large stomach of ruminating animals, when prepared for food.
an indehiscent fruit derived from a single ovary having one or many seeds within a fleshy wall or pericarp: e. g. grape; tomato; cranberry.

A surface, real or imaginary, in which, if any two points are taken, the straight line which joins them lies wholly in that surface; or a surface, any section of which by a like surface is a straight line; a surface without curvature.
A fried, or sometimes baked, turnover made from a round or square sheet of dough containing a filling, usually of meat or potatoes.
See Jack, 8 (c).
A red amorphous powder consisting of ferric oxide.  It is used in polishing glass, metal, or gems, and as a cosmetic, etc. Called also crocus, jeweler's rouge, etc.
Same as Salmis.
A key or thing touched to produce a tone.
A publication which appears regularly every day; as, the morning dailies.
A sharpshooter. See Yager.

A blowing apparatus, in which air, drawn into the upper part of a vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, is carried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it is led to a furnace.
Thread; continuous line.
A wand.  See Verge.
An alarm from a real or threatened attack; a sudden attack; also, a bugle sound to give warning.
Swedish glove leather, -- usually made from lambskins tanned with willow bark. Also used adjectively; as, suede gloves; blue suede shoes.

A viscid fluid secreted by mucous membranes, which it serves to moisten and protect. It covers the lining membranes of all the cavities which open externally, such as those of the mouth, nose, lungs, intestinal canal, urinary passages, etc.
A ratchet wheel, or notched bar, with which a pawl or click works.
Wet, spongy land; soft, low ground saturated with water, but not usually covered with it; marshy ground away from the seashore.
A kind of kettledrum.

An electronic device designed to detect objects at a distance, and determine their distance from the device, by transmitting a pulse of radio waves and measuring the time required for the echo of the pulse to return to the emitting device; as, the radar showed a plane approaching rapidly.  For more information of radar, see the article <a href="radar.htm">What is Radar?.
A voyage; a journey.
A blow on the face.
A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountains of India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger and other wild animals in packs.

Half-rotten straw, or any similar light, porous, organic substance strewn on the ground, as over the roots of plants, to protect from heat, drought, etc., and to hinder weed growth and preserve moisture.
One who rises; as, an early riser.

An ethereal salt, or compound ether, consisting of an organic radical united with the residue of any oxygen acid, organic or inorganic; thus the natural fats are esters of glycerin and the fatty acids, oleic, etc.
That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.
The act of expiring; passage from life to death; loss of life.
Dregs; sediment; excrement. See faeces.
A kitten; also, a pet name or calling name for the cat.
A public square in a city or town.
A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as the plant develops.
The tender leaves or leafstalks of the artichoke, white beet, etc., blanched for table use.
The god of love, son of Venus; usually represented as a naked, winged boy with bow and arrow.
See Cigar.
See Agendum.
Act of seizing; a grasp.
a student during his first year in a high school, college, or university; a freshman.
A strong drink; cider.

a quick move by defensive players toward the passer on the offensive team, as soon as the ball is snapped; -- it is used when the defensive teams assumes that a pass will be attempted, and risks allowing substantial gains by the offensive team if other plays are in fact planned.
A soft, earthy substance, of a white, grayish, or yellowish white color, consisting of calcium carbonate, and having the same composition as common limestone.
an object having the shape of the capital <DELTA/.
Possibility; uncertainty.
A disease of the hair (Plica polonica), in which it becomes twisted and matted together. The disease is of Polish origin, and is hence called also Polish plait.
A glen; a ravine closed at its upper end.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.
The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn and tillage.
See Galley, n., 4.
One who, or that which, inks; especially, in printing, the pad or roller which inks the type.
A minnow.
A naevus.
The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; the person named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, the amount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange, under Bill.
The parts of a piece of house furniture, as a bedstead, packed together.
A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornblende) in the walls of tin and copper lodes.

Any wading bird of the genus Ardea and allied genera, of the family Ardeidae. The herons have a long, sharp bill, and long legs and toes, with the claw of the middle toe toothed. The common European heron (Ardea cinerea) is remarkable for its directly ascending flight, and was formerly hunted with the larger falcons.
The coarse, harsh sound uttered by a frog or a raven, or a like sound.
See 1st Souse.
A box; a pyx.
That which draws along; especially, persuasion, artifice, or enticement; allurement.
Same as Fulahs.
One who loves; one who is in love; -- usually limited, in the singular, to a person of the male sex.
A small drum used as an accompaniment to a pipe or fife, both being played by the same person.
A pipe, funnel, or chimney, as for smoke.
See Ghoul.
A long bar; a pole; a shaft; a stake.
A throw; a toss; a cast, as of something from the hand; as, a good pitch in quoits.
a genus of nocturnal South American monkeys with large eyes; the owl monkeys; the douroucoulis.  See douroucouli.

A Christian priest or monk; used as a term of address for priests in some churches (especially Roman or Orthodox Catholic in Italy, Spain, Portugal, and Spanish America); -- also used in the American military.
See Glaive.
A Southern Asiatic species of wild cattle (Bibos frontalis).
Solace.
The number greater by a unit than two; three units or objects.
A vista; a prospect.

A small three-masted vessel, with projecting bow and stern and convex decks, used in the Mediterranean for transporting merchandise, etc.  It carries large square sails, or lateen sails, or both.  Xebecs were formerly armed and used by corsairs.

Water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt; pickle; hence, any strong saline solution; also, the saline residue or strong mother liquor resulting from the evaporation of natural or artificial waters.
A boat used by rude nations, formed of trunk of a tree, excavated, by cutting of burning, into a suitable shape. It is propelled by a paddle or paddles, or sometimes by sail, and has no rudder.
See Eagre.
To give a point to; to sharpen; to cut, forge, grind, or file to an acute end; as, to point a dart, or a pencil. Used also figuratively; as, to point a moral.
Same as <AE/neid.
To yield fruit.
A woman of affected modesty, reserve, or coyness; one who is overscrupulous or sensitive; one who affects extraordinary prudence in conduct and speech.
A keen-edged knife of peculiar shape, used in shaving the hair from the face or the head; also called a straight razor.
Same as Sewen.
A nestling of a pigeon or other similar bird, esp. when very fat and not fully fledged.
The heron
Same as Acrita.
The long, projecting nose of a beast, as of swine.
A strong, offensive smell; a disgusting odor; a stench.

A letter of the Greek alphabet corresponding to th in English; -- sometimes called the unlucky letter, from being used by the judges on their ballots in passing condemnation on a prisoner, it being the first letter of the Greek qa`natos, death.
A word; reason; speech.
An annoyer.
A sharp instrument used for opening veins, lancing gums, etc.; a kind of lancet.
Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that they may be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam.
Having the rank, pungent, offensive odor and taste which substances of organic origin acquire during warm, moist weather; foul or sour and fetid; moldy; as, musty corn; musty books.
Plural form of mare, a dark region of considerable extent on the surface of the moon.
Skin; covering.
The positive pole of an electric battery, or more strictly the electrode by which the current enters the electrolyte on its way to the other pole; -- opposed to cathode.
A point in which the rays of light meet, after being reflected or refracted, and at which the image is formed; as, the focus of a lens or mirror.
One who affects special finery or gives undue attention to dress; a fop; a coxcomb.
Enchantment; illusion.
See Coif.
To beat into shape; to forge.
A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England in marking sheep.
a game in which numbered balls are drawn and random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards.
Coarse, heavy, narrow linen cloth, used esp. for towels.
One of a people and religious sect dwelling chiefly in the Lebanon mountains of Syria.

A large cervine mammal (Alces alces syn. Alces machlis, syn Alces Americanus), native of the Northern United States and Canada. The adult male is about as large as a horse, and has very large, palmate antlers. It closely resembles the European elk, and by many Zoologists is considered the same species. See Elk.
Estimation; valuation.
Boisterous weather.

A plant having twigs suitable for making brooms to sweep with when bound together; esp., the Cytisus scoparius of Western Europe, which is a low shrub with long, straight, green, angular branches, minute leaves, and large yellow flowers.
To cover with a crust; to cover or line with an incrustation; to incrust.

Any one of numerous species of small, wingless, suctorial, parasitic insects belonging to a tribe (Pediculina), now usually regarded as degraded Hemiptera. To this group belong of the lice of man and other mammals; as, the head louse of man (Pediculus capitis), the body louse (Pediculus vestimenti), and the crab louse (Phthirius pubis), and many others. See Crab louse, Dog louse, Cattle louse, etc., under Crab, Dog, etc.
A line of grass or grain cut and thrown together by the scythe in mowing or cradling.
Blameworthiness.
See Hals.
A sheath; a case; as, the theca, or cell, of an anther; the theca, or spore case, of a fungus; the theca of the spinal cord.
See Orang-outang.
A seal; a coining die; -- used adjectively to designate the silver currency of the Mogul emperors, or the Indian rupee of 192 grains.
Glory; fame; renown; praise.
A sudden squall. See Pirry.
An involuntary and unnatural contraction of one or more muscles or muscular fibers.
To lay in a conical or other pile; to make into a large pile; as, to stack hay, cornstalks, or grain; to stack or place wood.

The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians, and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. He corresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usually represented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.
A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.
To insert (a graft) in a branch or stem of another tree; to propagate by insertion in another stock; also, to insert a graft upon.
an island in the Hawaiian chain.
same as benne or benni.
in Irish legend, chief god of the Tuatha De Danann; father of Angus Og and Brigit.
See 1st Lar.
A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20 sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.
One who takes or receives; one who catches or apprehends.
A region of Western Asia Minor colonized by the Ancient Greeks.
The dog salmon.
A country on the island of Malta.
A genus of longeared South American monkeys, including numerous species of marmosets. See Marmoset.
A stubble field left unplowed till late in the autumn, that it may be cropped by cattle.
A Slavic tribe which once occupied the northern and eastern parts of Germany, of which a small remnant exists.
An herb; a plant.
A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neck and throat, and extending to the shoulders.
The oat; oats.
Foul matter; anything that soils or defiles; dirt; nastiness.
One who collects bees into a hive.
The organ of sight; an eye.
A pie consisting usually of meat wholly surrounded with a crust made of a sheet of paste, and often baked without a dish; a meat pie.
One who exerts power, or has the power to act; an actor.
A miner's two-pointed pick.
pl. of Goose.
A book of the Apocrypha.
A peculiar gait of a horse, in which both legs on the same side are moved at the same time, alternating with the legs on the other side.
A demand of a right or supposed right; a calling on another for something due or supposed to be due; an assertion of a right or fact.
A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication from one siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
See Ankle.
The breeze fly. See Breeze.
The act of standing.
A work in the Persian tongue, being a summary of the Zend-Avesta, or sacred books.
A daring villain; a bandit; one who sets law at defiance; a professional assassin or murderer.
A light quick stroke or blow, esp. with something pliant; a flirt; also, the sound made by such a blow.
See Lack.
A pinnacle of ice among the crevasses of a glacier; also, one of the blocks into which a glacier breaks on a steep grade.
A leafless East Indian vine (Sarcostemma acidum); its sour milky juice was formerly used to make an intoxicating drink.
See Jougs.
A cordial of brandy, etc., flavored with the kernel of the bitter almond, or of the peach stone, etc.
The path described by a heavenly body in its periodical revolution around another body; as, the orbit of Jupiter, of the earth, of the moon.
One who rules; one who exercises sway or authority; a governor.
One of the minute grains in flowerless plants, which are analogous to seeds, as serving to reproduce the species.
The gazelle.

A South American ruminant (Auchenia llama), allied to the camels, but much smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be a domesticated variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as a beast of burden in the Andes, and is also kept on some ranches in the United States.
In Russia, a published proclamation or imperial order, having the force of law.
A piece of music of a mournful character, to accompany funeral rites; a funeral hymn.
A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries in Europe; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.
A norm; a principle or rule; a model; a standard.
A waif.

A name applied to various marine univalve shells; esp. to those of the genus Strombus, which are of large size. Strombus gigas is the large pink West Indian conch.  The large king, queen, and cameo conchs are of the genus Cassis. See Cameo and cameo conch.
One of the chief divisions of a long poem; a book.
The standard unit of electrical quantity, and also of current.  See Coulomb, and Amp<?/re.
A genus of palms, one species of which (Areca catechu) produces the areca nut, or betel nut, which is chewed in India and Southeast Asia with the leaf of the Piper Betle and lime.
A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.
A young chicken, partridge, grouse, or the like.
A wrinkle; a rimple.
The female of the ruff.
A small Italian coin worth a sou or a cent; the twentieth part of a lira.
Public disgrace or stigma; infamy; loss of civil rights.
Also (perhaps from confusion with alley), a passage into which the pews of a church open.
The wash, or mixture of liquid substances, given to swine; hogwash; -- called also swillings.
A very short time; an instant; a moment; -- now used only in the phrase in a trice.

a dish composed of well-seasoned rice (with nuts or currants of minced lamb) simmered or braised in stock, stuffed into tomatoes or green peppers, or wrapped in grape leaves; -- popular in the near east.
See Shittim.
The fennec.
The act of uniting or joining two or more things into one, or the state of being united or joined; junction; coalition; combination.

A large Asiatic antelope (Budorcas taxicolor) native of the higher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head and neck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat. Called also budorcas.
Pain; grief; distress; anguish.

Any large, rapacious bird of the Falcon family, esp. of the genera Aquila and Hali<ae/etus.  The eagle is remarkable for strength, size, graceful figure, keenness of vision, and extraordinary flight.  The most noted species are the golden eagle (Aquila chrysa<eum/tus); the imperial eagle of Europe (Aquila mogilnik or Aquila imperialis); the American bald eagle (Hali<ae/etus leucocephalus); the European sea eagle (Hali<ae/etus albicilla); and the great harpy eagle (Thrasaetus harpyia).  The figure of the eagle, as the king of birds, is commonly used as an heraldic emblem, and also for standards and emblematic devices.  See Bald eagle, Harpy, and Golden eagle.
A British Indian gold coin, of the value of fifteen silver rupees, or $7.21 (in 1913).
A medusa, or jellyfish.
Sorrow.
obs. pl. for Ashes.
Baryta.
A long, slender, flexible shoot or branch.
The act of rinsing.

A gesture consisting of drawing up the shoulders, -- a motion usually expressing doubt, indifference, or dislike; -- it is sometimes accompanied by a slight turning of the hands outward or upward.  Such a gesture may be made, as in answering "who knows" to a question, suggesting utter ignorance of an answer and a disinclination to pursue the topic further.
The whole body of salt water which covers more than three fifths of the surface of the globe; -- called also the sea, or great sea.
See Weasand.
Crude tartar. See Argol.
A protuberance; a hunch; a knob or lump; a hump.
An early Latin version of the Scriptures (the Old Testament was translated from the Septuagint, and was also called the Italic version).
A flagon; a vessel or measure for liquids.
A narration or recital of that which has occurred; a description of past events; a history; a statement; a record.
A waiting for; ambush; watch; watching; heed.
a Russian country house, especially a cottage used in the summer.
Knotty; difficult.
See Arrish.
See Faker.
An earth-covered Navajo lodge; it is traditionally built with the entrance facing east.
See water buck, under 3d Buck.
Anything that lies in a place; that which, or one who, remains in a place.
A kind of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in the Philippine Islands.
To make music upon; to tune.
A sacred song; a poetical composition for use in the praise or worship of God.
That which is roasted; a piece of meat which has been roasted, or is suitable for being roasted.
A mimeograph.
The back.
Hydrophobia.
Writing; document; scroll.
a lesbian who is noticeably masculine.
Sorrow; dole.

A word used only in the expression to play hooky, to be truant, to run away; -- used mostly of youths absent from school without a valid reason and without the knowledge of their parents.  Also (figuratively and jocosely), to be absent from duty for frivolous reasons.
One who engages in rows, or noisy quarrels; a ruffianly fellow.
The dried tubers of various species of Orchis, and Eulophia. It is used to make a nutritious beverage by treating the powdered preparation with hot water.
To be ashamed; to feel shame.

A faculty, possessed by animals, of perceiving external objects by means of impressions made upon certain organs (sensory or sense organs) of the body, or of perceiving changes in the condition of the body; as, the senses of sight, smell, hearing, taste, and touch. See Muscular sense, under Muscular, and Temperature sense, under Temperature.
An inlet from the Gulf of Mexico, from a lake, or from a large river, sometimes sluggish, sometimes without perceptible movement except from tide and wind.
An evergreen leguminous tree (Ceratania Siliqua) found in the countries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; -- called also carob tree.
See Prize, n., 5. Also Prize, v. t.
A small rat.
An ancient instrument of music with six strings; a kind of violin, being the oldest known stringed instrument played with a bow.
A plowing.
To eat sumptuously; to dine or sup on rich provisions, particularly in large companies, and on public festivals.
Same as Genius{1}.
See Petard.
Stiff; rigid.
The mountain linnet (Linota flavirostris).
To sound in harmonious accord, as bells.
A goddess.

Any plant or species of the genus Papaver, herbs with showy polypetalous flowers and a milky juice.  From one species (Papaver somniferum) opium is obtained, though all the species contain it to some extent; also, a flower of the plant. See Illust. of Capsule.

Anything that is quilted; esp., a quilted bed cover, or a skirt worn by women; any cover or garment made by putting wool, cotton, etc., between two cloths and stitching them together; also, any outer bed cover.
The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change.
An hermaphrodite.
A silver coin of about 86 grains, having the figure of an archer, and hence, in modern times, called a daric.
a country at the northeastern corner of Africa.  At one time it was joined with Syria to form the United Arab Republic.
One who, or that which, makes an end of something; as, the ender of my life.
One of a certain description of militia among the Tartars.
A sapling left standing in a fallen wood.
To turn from a straight line; to bend; to curve.

A variety of auction pitch in which a draw to improve the hand is added, and the five of trumps (called right pedro) and the five of the same color (called left pedro, and ranking between the five and the four of trumps) each count five on the score. Fifty-one points make a game. Called also double pedro and high five.
Motive.
A hill.
See Leden.
A kind of litter suspended from men's shoulders, for carrying persons or things; a palanquin.
A rocking or balanced stone.
A silly fellow; a ninny.
