One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or should be, paid.

A minute groove, or channel; a threadlike line, as of color; a narrow structural band or line; a striation; as, the striae, or groovings, produced on a rock by a glacier passing over it; the striae on the surface of a shell; a stria of nervous matter in the brain.
A gridle. See 1st Seint.
A woman newly married, or about to be married.
A cone.
The act of stooping, or bending the body forward; inclination forward; also, an habitual bend of the back and shoulders.
The stormy petrel.
A sudden turn; a starting from the point or line; hence, an artful evasion or subterfuge; a shift; a quibble; as, the quirks of a pettifogger.
same as chimpanzee.

A genus of chilognathous myriapods. The body is long and round, consisting of numerous smooth, equal segments, each of which bears two pairs of short legs. It includes the galleyworms. See Chilognatha.
One of an Oriental religious sect which worships Satan or the Devil.
A group of worms without appendages, as the leech.
A dark color inclining to red or yellow, resulting from the mixture of red and black, or of red, black, and yellow; a tawny, dusky hue.
A leaping forth; a darting; a spring.
See Trais.
See Zocco.
A socially awkward or tactless act.
A sylvan deity or demigod, represented as part man and part goat, and characterized by riotous merriment and lasciviousness.
Harm; damage; injury; hurt; waste; misfortune.
naked freshwater or marine or parasitic protozoa that form temporary pseudopods for feeding and locomotion.  Same as amoeba.
As much as is taken up between the thumb and two first fingers.
A blow with the open hand; a slap.
A genus of fungi. See Truffle.
That part of the large intestines which extends from the c<ae/cum to the rectum. [See Illust. of Digestion.]
The game of basketball.
See Labium.
One of three sea nymphs, -- or, according to some writers, of two, -- said to frequent an island near the coast of Italy, and to sing with such sweetness that they lured mariners to destruction.
A flock of snipe.
A creel or osier basket.
The substances which inclose the ore on every side.
A crag; a cliff; a glen with overhanging sides.
The last, and usually the longest, division of the small intestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine.

A partaker; a person having an interest in any action or thing; one who has an interest in an estate created by another; a person having an interest derived from a contract or conveyance to which he is not himself a party.  The term, in its proper sense, is distinguished from party.
A quire; a book.
Direct management of public finance or public works by agents of the government for government account; -- opposed to the contract system.
of or pertaining to objects which are pierced or decorated with an openwork pattern.
A severe paroxysmal pain in the abdomen, due to spasm, obstruction, or distention of some one of the hollow viscera.
A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled to preside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, or fountain.

One of the hard, bony appendages which are borne on the jaws, or on other bones in the walls of the mouth or pharynx of most vertebrates, and which usually aid in the prehension and mastication of food.
A muscle; flesh.
See Scot, a tax.
The act of purging.
A large wax candle used in the ceremonies of various churches.
See Sty, a boil.
Any curiosity{3} or article of virtu; any object esteemed for its unusual nature.
A child's mane for a doll.
The double bass, or contrabasso.
An ill-conditioned, ill-fed, or neglected horse; also, a person in a like condition.
Same as Sewen.
See Kurd.
A foot of four syllables, one long and three short, admitting of four combinations, according to the place of the long syllable.
Same as cafe latte; a type of espresso coffee served with foamy steamed milk, and usually served in a tall glass or mug.
See Myope.
A flat-floored fishing boat with a lug sail, and a drop rudder extending from two to four feet below the keel. It was originally used on the stormy coast of Yorkshire, England.

The unit of electric induction; the induction in a circuit when the electro-motive force induced in this circuit is one volt, while the inducing current varies at the rate of one amp<egrave/re a second.
The act of sliding; as, a slide on the ice.

The giant armadillo (Priodontes gigas) of tropical South America. It becomes nearly five feet long including the tail. It is noted for its burrowing powers, feeds largely upon dead animals, and sometimes invades human graves.
The universal remedy of Paracelsus.
An Australian boomerang, having one side flat and the other convex.
Craziness; insanity.
The ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.
The people of Holland; Dutchmen.
A wig; -- so called, perhaps, from being made of, or resembling, Jersey yarn.
Rapine; rapacity.
A pin, or block, of wood or metal, fitting into holes in the abutting portions of two pieces, and being partly in one piece and partly in the other, to keep them in their proper relative position.
A nun.
To fix the mind closely upon a subject; to dwell upon anything in thought; to muse; to ponder.
Any article or separable part of one's assets.
A small bag; usually, a leathern bag; as, a pouch for money; a shot pouch; a mail pouch, etc.
See Pattee.
Master; lord; teacher; -- a Jewish title of respect or honor for a teacher or doctor of the law.
Cold; chilliness.
A collusive agreement between two or more persons to prejudice a third.
See Painim.
The glandular organ in which milk is secreted and stored; -- popularly called the bag in cows and other quadrupeds. See Mamma.
The Canada lynx.
Labor; toil; drudgery.
A glimpse or glance.
A composition for eight parts, usually for eight solo instruments or voices.

A nonmetallic element occurring abundantly in borax. It is reduced with difficulty to the free state, when it can be obtained in several different forms; viz., as a substance of a deep olive color, in a semimetallic form, and in colorless quadratic crystals similar to the diamond in hardness and other properties. It occurs in nature also in boracite, datolite, tourmaline, and some other minerals. Atomic number 5. Atomic weight 10.81. Symbol B.

That which terminates, circumscribes, restrains, or confines; the bound, border, or edge; the utmost extent; as, the limit of a walk, of a town, of a country; the limits of human knowledge or endeavor.
A little face; a small, plane surface; as, the facets of a diamond.
One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal or rightful title, whether he is the possessor or not.
The head or leader of any body of men; a commander, as of an army; a head man, as of a tribe, clan, or family; a person in authority who directs the work of others; the principal actor or agent.
A small fragment or piece; especially, a small piece of bread or other food, broken or cut off.
War.
A small flat loaf or thick cake; also, a fagot.
A Feigned story or tale, intended to instruct or amuse; a fictitious narration intended to enforce some useful truth or precept; an apologue.  See the Note under Apologue.
A pair of the opposite leaflets of a pinnate plant.
A little teat; a nipple.
The sum of six times ten; sixty units or objects.
The cry of a buck in rutting time.

A brother or member of any religious order, but especially of one of the four mendicant orders, viz: (a) Minors, Gray Friars, or Franciscans. (b) Augustines. (c) Dominicans or Black Friars. (d) White Friars or Carmelites. See these names in the Vocabulary.
The European throstle or song thrush (Turdus musicus).
A clump of trees in a prairie.
The immersion of the body in water; as, to take one's usual bathe.
Vinegar; verjuice.
A woman's long dress or robe; also light covering; a scarf.
A burning of the surface; a slight burn.
A wandering; a vagary.
One of the nymphs of mountains and grottoes.

A commercial weight varying in different countries and for different commodities. In Borneo it is 135<frac58/ lbs.; in China and Sumatra, 133<frac12/ lbs.; in Japan, 133<frac13/ lbs.; but sometimes 130 lbs., etc. Called also, by the Chinese, tan.
The act or result of shaking; a vacillating or wavering motion; a rapid motion one way and other; a trembling, quaking, or shivering; agitation.
A genus including several species of large marine gastropods having massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on the columella.
A Russian measure of length containing 3,500 English feet.
One who wooes; one who courts or solicits in love; a suitor.

The organ formed by the combination or union into one body of stem and leaf, and often bearing the fructification; as, the frond of a fern or of a lichen or seaweed; also, the peculiar leaf of a palm tree.
A turning off to a side or short track, that the principal track may be left free.
Morning.
A European owl (Syrnium aluco) of a tawny color; -- called also uluia.
Formerly an allowance of two pounds in every three hundred weight after the tare and tret are subtracted; now used only in a general sense, of small deductions from the original weight.

A Latin deity represented with two faces looking in opposite directions. Numa is said to have dedicated to Janus the covered passage at Rome, near the Forum, which is usually called the Temple of Janus. This passage was open in war and closed in peace.
See Juglone.
A kind of boat used in Canton. It is about 25 feet long and is often rowed by women. Called also tankia.
One who, or that which, dries; that which may expel or absorb moisture; a desiccative; as, the sun and a northwesterly wind are great driers of the earth.
Same as Guaiac.
Amount yielded; product; -- applied especially to products resulting from growth or cultivation.

The old theory that the egg contains the whole embryo of the future organism and the germs of all subsequent offsprings and is merely awakened to activity by the spermatozoon; -- opposed to spermism or animalculism.
A fairy; a goblin; an elf.
Unhusked rice; -- commonly so called in the East Indies.
Deception deliberately practiced with a view to gaining an unlawful or unfair advantage; artifice by which the right or interest of another is injured; injurious stratagem; deceit; trick.

A West Indian dance contest, in which participants must dance under a pole which is lowered successively until only one participant can successfully pass under, without falling. It is  often performed at celebrations, such as weddings.
To sound as a knell; especially, to toll at a death or funeral; hence, to sound as a warning or evil omen.
A small piece of land inclosed with a hedge; a close.
A gutter in a candle.
The head of an Arab family, or of a clan or a tribe; also, the chief magistrate of an Arab village. The name is also applied to Mohammedan ecclesiastics of a high grade.
Feathery or wool-like down; filament of a feather.
A slight depression or pit; a fossa.
Also, any species of the genus Erica, of which several are European, and many more are South African, some of great beauty. See Illust. of Heather.
A weaver's reed; a sley.
Something annexed or appended; as, an additional stipulation to a writing, a subsidiary building to a main building; a wing.

A polyphonic composition, developed from a given theme or themes, according to strict contrapuntal rules. The theme is first given out by one voice or part, and then, while that pursues its way, it is repeated by another at the interval of a fifth or fourth, and so on, until all the parts have answered one by one, continuing their several melodies and interweaving them in one complex progressive whole, in which the theme is often lost and reappears.
Spelter.
Willow.
A friend; -- a Spanish term applied in the Philippine Islands to friendly natives.
A particular kind of writing practiced by the ancient Irish, and found in inscriptions on stones, metals, etc.
A fathom.
See Mucedin.
plural of alga.
A name applied to the amorphous or crystalline mass obtained from bile by the action of alcohol and ether. It is composed of a mixture of the sodium salts of the bile acids.
a genus of plants including the indigo bush.

A tree or shrub of the genus Ilex. The European species (Ilex Aquifolium) is best known, having glossy green leaves, with a spiny, waved edge, and bearing berries that turn red or yellow about Michaelmas.
A genus of birds including some of the puffins.
A purse or bag in which to carry or measure diamonds, etc.
The sound made when a cork is forcibly drawn from a bottle.
See Drier.
a device shaped like an erect penis, used by some women for sexual stimulation.
A covetous, sordid man; a miser; a niggard.
A cuplike spoon, often of large size, with a long handle, used in lading or dipping.
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives; as, octyl alcohol.
A vinedresser.

A note or character of time, equivalent to two semibreves or four minims. When dotted, it is equal to three semibreves. It was formerly of a square figure (as thus: <?/ ), but is now made oval, with a line perpendicular to the staff on each of its sides; -- formerly much used for choir service.
To put off; to defer; to procrastinate; to prolong the time of or before.
One who, or that which, wades.
A radical, C16H33, not yet isolated, but supposed to exist in a series of compounds homologous with the ethyl compounds, and derived from spermaceti.
An unshaped piece or mass of wood or other substance.
See Grilse.
A cover; a shelter; a protection.
A part of a harness; a hame.
A solution; an explanation.
The superior or head of an abbey.
The foundation of anything; that on which a thing rests.
A slice of beef, broiled, or cut for broiling; -- also extended to the meat of other large animals; as, venison steak; bear steak; pork steak; turtle steak.
A small copper coin formerly current in Scotland, worth less than a cent.
Plenty; abundance.
See Meter.
One who owls; esp., one who conveys contraband goods. See Owling, n.
A paved yard or floor where ores are cleaned and sorted, or where ore, salt, mercury, etc., are trampled by horses, to effect intermixture and amalgamation.
Same as Anthozoa. See Anthozoa, Madreporaria, Hydroid.
A silver coin, and money of account, in the East Indies.
The slope of the ditch nearest the parapet; the escarp.
Kind; genus; class; form; style, esp. in literature.

The upright post about which the steps of a circular staircase wind; hence, in stairs having straight flights, the principal post at the foot of a staircase, or the secondary ones at the landings.  Also called newel post.  See Hollow newel, under Hollow.
A member of one of the German tribes that in the fifth century overran and conquered Gaul, and established the kingdom of France.
One who, or that which, aids.
A nickname for a British policeman; -- from Sir Robert Peel, who remodeled the police force. See Peeler.
A loud noise resulting from collision; a noisy collision of bodies; a collision.

To protect from danger; to secure against surprise, attack, or injury; to keep in safety; to defend; to shelter; to shield from surprise or attack; to protect by attendance; to accompany for protection; to care for.
One who hides or conceals.
The cormorant.
A violent gust of wind.
A short wooden club having a deeply concave face, seldom used.
A long, narrow, pliable strip of leather, cloth, or the like; specifically, a strip of thick leather used in flogging.
Place; situation.
A detent, pawl, or ratchet, as that which catches the cogs of a ratchet wheel to prevent backward motion. See Illust. of Ratched wheel.

A dish made by boiling any article of food to a pulp and then blending it or rubbing it through a sieve; as, a pur<eacute/e of fish, or of potatoes; especially, a soup the thickening of which is so treated.
Wine boiled and mingled with honey.
See Tucket, a steak.
The next in order after the ninth; one coming after nine others.
A tribe of Indians native of Arizona and the adjacent parts of Mexico and California. They are agricultural, and cultivate corn, wheat, barley, melons, etc.
Any one of several species of sea birds of the genus Uria, or Catarractes; a guillemot.

A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere, including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces. These trees have pendent cones, which do not readily fall to pieces, in this and other respects differing from the firs.
A shelter. Same as Beild.
The hydrocarbon radical, C9H19-, derived from nonane and forming many compounds. Used also adjectively; as, nonyl alcohol.

Sheet; surface; all that portion of a surface that is continuous in such a way that it is possible to pass from any one point of the portion to any other point of the portion without leaving the surface.  Thus, some hyperboloids have one nappe, and some have two.
A mixture of oleomargarine with lard or other fatty ingredients. It is used as a substitute for butter. See Butterine.
One who makes a vow.
A man of a particular turn of mind.
See 1st Jeer (b).

A solution of continuity in any of the soft parts of the body, discharging purulent matter, found on a surface, especially one of the natural surfaces of the body, and originating generally in a constitutional disorder; a sore discharging pus. It is distinguished from an abscess, which has its beginning, at least, in the depth of the tissues.
Rule.

A vessel having one mast and fore-and-aft rig, consisting of a boom-and-gaff mainsail, jibs, staysail, and gaff topsail. The typical sloop has a fixed bowsprit, topmast, and standing rigging, while those of a cutter are capable of being readily shifted.  The sloop usually carries a centerboard, and depends for stability upon breadth of beam rather than depth of keel.  The two types have rapidly approximated since 1880.  One radical distinction is that a sloop may carry a centerboard. See Cutter, and Illustration in Appendix.
The capital city of Tibet; it is the sacred city of Lamaism.
The magpie.
A close compression, as with the ends of the fingers, or with an instrument; a nip.

A composition, in prose or poetry, accommodated to action, and intended to exhibit a picture of human life, or to depict a series of grave or humorous actions of more than ordinary interest, tending toward some striking result. It is commonly designed to be spoken and represented by actors on the stage.

A game played on a board having 256 squares, by two persons with 19 men each, or by four with 13 men each, starting from different corners and striving to place each his own set of men in a corresponding position in the opposite corner by moving them or by jumping them over those met in progress.
A variety of cryptocrystalline of a leek-green color.
The act of sniffing; perception by sniffing; that which is taken by sniffing; as, a sniff of air.
A subject or topic on which a person writes or speaks; a proposition for discussion or argument; a text.
Same as hippopotamus.
A fine rain; a thick mist; a mizzle; a drizzle.
Helmsman. See 6th Steer.
The gadfly of cattle.
A winning card; one of a particular suit (usually determined by chance for each deal) any card of which takes any card of the other suits.
A blow; whack.

Any lizard of the family Geckonid<ae/.  The geckoes are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and vertical, elliptical pupils.  Their toes are generally expanded, and furnished with adhesive disks, by which they can run over walls and ceilings.  They are numerous in warm countries, and a few species are found in Europe and the United States. See Wall gecko, Fanfoot.
An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or is octavalent.

A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic, prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strong acetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals. Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.
A puddle; a plash.

A white or gray crystalline salt, with a slight alkaline taste, used as a flux, in soldering metals, making enamels, fixing colors on porcelain, and as a soap. It occurs native in certain mineral springs, and is made from the boric acid of hot springs in Tuscany. It was originally obtained from a lake in Thibet, and was sent to Europe under the name of tincal. Borax is a pyroborate or tetraborate of sodium, Na2B4O7.10H2O.
Anything done; a deed; an action good or bad; hence, in the plural, conduct; behavior. See Do.
The stone roller. See Stone roller (a), under Stone.
An association; a league or confederacy.
A pharos; a lighthouse.
Realm.
A stout, coarse boot or shoe; a brogan.
See Skid.
Frothy matter raised on liquids by boiling, effervescence, or agitation; froth; foam; scum.
A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes; also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by the cleavage of an albumose.
A disease of sheep. The term is variously applied in different localities.
Invocation of evil spirits; witchcraft.
A coarse cotton drilling used for overalls, etc.
A smaller group of trees than a forest, and without underwood, planted, or growing naturally as if arranged by art; a wood of small extent.

A total prohibition of intercourse with, use of, or approach to, a given person or thing under pain of death, -- an interdict of religious origin and authority, formerly common in the islands of Polynesia; interdiction.
See Dammar.
Delight.
Malignity.
A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costume is worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to those of the peacock.
A small portable organ, played with one hand, the bellows being worked with the other, -- used in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid, after rennet has ceased to cause coagulation.
The breast of a human being; the part, between the arms, to which anything is pressed when embraced by them.
An alloy (usually yellow) of copper and zinc, in variable proportion, but often containing two parts of copper to one part of zinc. It sometimes contains tin, and rarely other metals.
An immigrant.
A small column or pillar, used as a monument, milestone, etc.
Same as Saki.
A small South American species of tiger cat (Felis mitis).
A similar wheel used in other machinery.
The black vulture (Catharista atrata). It ranges from the Southern United States to South America. See Vulture.
A state of undue solicitude; a state of disturbance from care and anxiety; vexation; anxiety; fret; as, to be in a worry.
A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of South America.
The part of the leg from the knee to the foot; the shin; the shin bone; also, the whole leg.

A utensil for separating the finer and coarser parts of a pulverized or granulated substance from each other. It consist of a vessel, usually shallow, with the bottom perforated, or made of hair, wire, or the like, woven in meshes.
See Payer.
A handle; a stale, or stele.
A small shoot or twig of a tree or other plant; a spray; as, a sprig of laurel or of parsley.
A cone of paper which is placed in a vessel of lard or other fat, and used as a taper.
A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar.
The gorilla.

The right line drawn through the two points of contact of the two tangents drawn from a given point to a given conic section. The given point is called the pole of the line. If the given point lies within the curve so that the two tangents become imaginary, there is still a real polar line which does not meet the curve, but which possesses other properties of the polar. Thus the focus and directrix are pole and polar. There are also poles and polar curves to curves of higher degree than the second, and poles and polar planes to surfaces of the second degree.
To hold in extreme contempt; to reject as unworthy of regard; to despise; to contemn; to disdain.
The whole; the whole sum or amount; as, these sums added make the grand total of five millions.
That elevation of voice now called metrical accentuation, or the rhythmic accent.
Heat, in a literal sense; as, the ardor of the sun's rays.
any of various perennial South American plants of the genus Loasa having stinging hairs and showy white or yellow or reddish-orange flowers.
A miniature representation of a thing, with the several parts in due proportion; sometimes, a facsimile of the same size; as, a <frac1x100/ scale model of the B-52 bomber.
The lowest deck of a vessel, esp. of a ship of war, consisting of a platform laid over the beams in the hold, on which the cables are coiled.
The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, as distinguished from the open porticoes.
A stream or spring of fresh water.
A book; esp., a collection of poems written by one author; as, the divan of Hafiz.
A fleet; especially, a <?/eet of Spanish ships which formerly sailed every year from Cadiz to Vera Cruz, in Mexico, to transport to Spain the production of Spanish America.
a Polish monetary unit, equal to <frac1x100/ of a zloty.
A rushing or setting upon; an attack; an assault; a storming; especially, the assault of an army.
An oceanic fish of large size (Elacate canada); the crabeater; -- called also bonito, cubbyyew, coalfish, and sergeant fish.
One who believes in the existence of a God, but denies revealed religion; a freethinker.
A rustic; a countryman or laborer.
The dorsal one of the three principal bones comprising either lateral half of the pelvis; the dorsal or upper part of the hip bone. See Innominate bone, under Innominate.
A pommel.
Anything round, as a circle, a globe, a ring. <ldquo/The golden round<rdquo/ [the crown].
The Canada porcupine. See Porcupine.
Loss; disadvantage; defeat.
Any void space; a void space on paper, or in any written instrument; an interval void of consciousness, action, result, etc; a void.
See Krang.
An instrument or medium by which some important action is performed, or an important end accomplished; as, legislatures, courts, armies, taxgatherers, etc., are organs of government.
A small, inclosed field, adjoining a house; a small farm.
One of an order of priests which in ancient times existed among certain branches of the Celtic race, especially among the Gauls and Britons.
That which is void or empty.
See Pygmy.
A pillow.
See Koran.

An instrument used by the ancients in writing on tablets covered with wax, having one of its ends sharp, and the other blunt, and somewhat expanded, for the purpose of making erasures by smoothing the wax.
The territory governed by a ban.
A place of deposit for the storing of goods; a warehouse; a storehouse.
A genus of woodpeckers, including some of the common American and European species.

One of a body of students in the universities of Cambridge (Eng.) and Dublin, who, having passed a certain examination, are exempted from paying college fees and charges. A sizar corresponded to a servitor at Oxford.
A religious sect noted for warlike traits, founded in the Punjab at the end of the 15th century.
The short, thick first digit of the human hand, differing from the other fingers in having but two phalanges; the pollex. See Pollex.
The upper faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond, which projects from the setting and occupies the zone between the girdle and the table. See Brilliant, n.

One not inferior or superior to another; one having the same or a similar age, rank, station, office, talents, strength, or other quality or condition; an equal quantity or number; as, <ldquo/If equals be taken from equals the remainders are equal.<rdquo/
A pet name for a donkey.
One of the primary divisions of a decompound leaf.
A chip or fragment, especially a chip of stone as struck off the block by the hammer, having at least one feather-edge.
The mangrove; -- so called in the Pacific Islands.
See Weevil.
An omen.
The common burdock; the clotbur.
An old ewe.
One who comes, or who has come; one who has arrived, and is present.
A simpleton; a gull; a dupe.
See Stoat.
A tinsmith's stake, or small anvil.
A sieve.
A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what one dislikes; also, whatever causes such a feeling; as, to work annoy.
A genus of insects belonging to the order Hemiptera and family Aphid<ae/, including numerous species known as plant lice and green flies.
See Taenia.
See Olio.
The zebra.
Cream; -- a term used esp. in cookery, names of liqueurs, etc.
The capelin.
A rosier; a rosebush.
A snath.
Same as Emir.
same as Iraqi.
A short, precise step; an affected manner.

The act of entering or passing into or upon; entrance; ingress; hence, beginnings or first attempts; as, the entry of a person into a house or city; the entry of a river into the sea; the entry of air into the blood; an entry upon an undertaking.
An embankment to prevent inundation; as, the levees along the Mississippi; sometimes, the steep bank of a river.
A fine, white, somewhat friable clay; also, the ore contained in a mixture of clay and pebbles.
A concentrated fire from pieces of artillery, as in endeavoring to make a break in a fortification; a volley.
An Asiatic.
A law or rule.
A slice; as, a shive of bread.
Refuse timber, from which the best part has been culled out.
Denial; refusal.
Noise; din; esp.; confused noise, clamor, or hum of many voices, notes of birds, or the like.
The aggregate of the muscles, fat, and other tissues which cover the framework of bones in man and other animals; especially, the muscles.
A waistcoat or kind of stays for women.
The pendent fleshy lobe in the middle of the posterior border of the soft palate.
a short high-pitched tone produced as a signal or warning.
See Clake.
An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, and fastened with brooches.
The number greater by one than six; seven units or objects.
An oily liquid, CI3.CHO, analogous to chloral and bromal.
A cutaneous disease; especially, the itch.
See Crare.

Any of a variety of oily or greasy organic compounds found as major structural components of living cells; they are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents such as alcohol and ether, and include the common fats, cholesterol and other steroids, phospholipids, sphingolipids, waxes, and fatty acids; some of the lipids, together with proteins and carbohydrates, form an essential structural component of living cells, as in the cell walls and membranes.  The term lipid refers to its solubility in nonpolar solvents, and has no significance with regard to chemical structure.
A bottomless or unfathomed depth, gulf, or chasm; hence, any deep, immeasurable, and, specifically, hell, or the bottomless pit.
A quaver.
A channel or hollow worn in the earth by a current of water; a short deep portion of a torrent's bed when dry.
See 2d Weld.
A Muslim title for a ruler; a judge.
See Twill.
With might; with full force; vigorously; violently; exceedingly.
See Iguana.
See Pontee.
A genus of plants, mostly perennial, having succulent leaves and cymose flowers; orpine; stonecrop.
See Saker.
Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes of the order Plagiostomi, found in all seas.
One of the two long pieces of wood, extending before a vehicle, between which a horse is hitched; a shaft.
A genus of hemipterous insects of which the bedbug is the best known example. See Bedbug.
A round dance.
A beginning or first attempt; hence, a first appearance before the public, as of an actor or public speaker.
Purpose; determination.
The blue buck.
In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burden bearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
See Spook.
a glazed leavened doughnut-shaped roll with a hard crust.
Debt.
A place dug; a pit; a ditch; a den; a cave.
A long garment, descending to the ankles, worn by Roman women.
Lit., a dean; the senior member of a body or group; as, the doyen of French physicians.
A wood nymph; a nymph whose life was bound up with that of her tree.
The condition of being sulky; a sulky mood or humor; as, to be in the sulks.

Any species of sea duck of the genus Somateria, esp. Somateria mollissima, which breeds in the northern parts of Europe and America, and lines its nest with fine down (taken from its own body) which is an article of commerce; -- called also eider duck. The American eider (S. Dresseri), the king eider (S. spectabilis), and the spectacled eider (Arctonetta Fischeri) are related species.
The hard covering of an egg.
Something peculiar to one's self.
Any one of numerous species of sand wasps of the genus Sphex and allied genera. These wasps have the abdomen attached to the thorax by a slender pedicel. See Illust. of Sand wasp, under Sand.
Nap or down; flue[2]; soft, downy feathers.
A friar.
The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, which overhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.
To arrange or adjust the spaces in or between; as, to space words, lines, or letters.
Same as Sapajou.
A cradle, as for a broken limb. See Cradle, 6.
A staff or truncheon, used for various purposes; as, the baton of a field marshal; the baton of a conductor in musical performances.
A native or an inhabitant of Cuba.
One of several very small species and varieties of African antelopes, of the genus Cephalophus, as the Cape guevi or kleeneboc (Cephalophus pygm<ae/a); -- called also pygmy antelope.
A unit of light flux, being the flux through one square meter of surface the illumination of which is uniform and of unit brightness.
Leprosy.
A kind of light two-wheeled vehicle, usually for four persons, drawn by ponies or bullocks.
An ask; a water newt.
A large species of barbel (Barbus bynni), found in the Nile, and much esteemed for food.
See Salep.
A kind of waved silk, usually called watered silk, manufactured like taffeta, but thicker and stronger.  The watering is given to it by calendering.

The cutting tool of an engraver on metal, used in line engraving. It is made of tempered steel, one end being ground off obliquely so as to produce a sharp point, and the other end inserted in a handle; a graver; also, the similarly shaped tool used by workers in marble.
See Alarum, and Alarm.
An extensive plain with or without vegetation.
A knife or short dagger, esp. that in use among the Highlanders of Scotland. [Variously spelt.]
One who, or that which, wipes.
A name for a negro.
An imaginary being, supposed by the Rosicrucians to inhabit the inner parts of the earth, and to be the guardian of mines, quarries, etc.
A diaper{4}.
A weight of twelve grains; or, according to some, of ten grains, or half a scruple.
The last letter of the Greek alphabet. See Alpha.
See Paunch.
A spangle or shining ornament.
a genus of East Indian trees or shrubs: dhak.
The bottom or lower part of any room; the part upon which we stand and upon which the movables in the room are supported.
A short candle end used for igniting a fuse.
One of the segments of the abdomen or post-abdomen of arthropods.
The mink.
A Venetian coin, worth about three English farthings, or one and a half cents.
Same as Inkle.
A kind of bread. See Pone.
One of a race inhabiting the valleys of the Pyrenees, who until 1793 were political and social outcasts (Christian Pariahs). They are supposed to be a remnant of the Visigoths.

A genus of airbreathing mollusks, including the common garden slugs. They have a small rudimentary shell. The breathing pore is on the right side of the neck. Several species are troublesome in gardens. See Slug.
A genus of tropical or subtropical plants of the natural order Anonace<ae/, including the soursop.
A discoloration by foreign matter; a spot; as, a stain on a garment or cloth.
An article of food; provisions; food; victuals; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Cleared land; land suitable for tillage or pasture; cultivated ground; the open country.
A consort, husband or wife; a companion; a fere.
See C<ae/cum.
A genus of rosaceous trees and shrubs having pomes for fruit. It includes the apple, crab apple, pear, chokeberry, sorb, and mountain ash.
The floating dust in flour mills caused by the operation or grinding.
See Schorl.
Tincture; hue; color; tinge.
An astringent and narcotic drug made from the dried leaves and seed capsules of wild hemp (Cannabis Indica), and chewed or smoked in the East as a means of intoxication. See Hasheesh.
Buckwheat.
transient cessation of respiration.
Something set, or offered to view, as an allurement to draw others to any place or purpose; a decoy; a stool pigeon.
A place; a locality.
See Ribbon.
Same as Ambo.
Stuffing, or mixture of viands, like that used on dressing a fowl; forcemeat.
Press; throng.
A feeling of hurt, vexation, or resentment, awakened by a social slight or injury; irritation of the feelings, as through wounded pride; stinging vexation.
A fixed pin or short axis, on the end of which a wheel or other body turns.
A breeze fly.
Gold.
A shallow porous cup, used in refining precious metals, commonly made of bone ashes (phosphate of lime).
A hood. See Houve.
See Lodge, n.
A small writing, certificate, or schedule; a piece of paper containing a writing.
A sudden and energetic effort, as in an emergency; an increased exertion for a brief space.
The ursine seal. See the Note under 1st Seal.
A mine.
One backward in book learning; a child or other person dull or weak in intellect; a dullard; a dolt.
One who cements with glue.
A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop, are used instead of dice.
A local division of the people in ancient Athens; a clan; a tribe.
A broad piece of cloth, usually linen or cotton, used for wrapping the body or for a covering; especially, one used as an article of bedding next to the body.
A prison cell; a lockup; -- probably orig. the name of the noted prison in Southwark, England.
A measure; a standard of measure; an instrument to determine dimensions, distance, or capacity; a standard.
A long dress, trailing on the floor, worn by tragic actors in Greek and Roman theaters.
a cap made of soft cloth with no brim or bill, widening somewhat outward from a close-fitting headband to a flat top, which often has a button or tab in its center.
The name of Vishnu in his tenth and last avatar.
Same as Ledge.
A kind of wild red cherry.
A univalent organic radical, C6H13-, regarded as the essential residue of hexane, and a related series of compounds.
A machine of great antiquity, used in Bengal for raising water to irrigate land.
A leaf or division of the calyx.

A genus of trees, the lindens, the type of the family Tiliaceae, distinguished by the winglike bract coalescent with the peduncle, and by the indehiscent fruit having one or two seeds. There are about twenty species, natives of temperate regions.  Many species are planted as ornamental shade trees, and the tough fibrous inner bark is a valuable article of commerce. Also, a plant of this genus.
Time.
A small, flat, sweetened cake of various kinds.
A low-lying meadow by the side of a river.
The radius or ray of a wheel; one of the small bars which are inserted in the hub, or nave, and which serve to support the rim or felly.
Ore selected for excellence.
An inspissated juice. See Rob.
Power of affecting the organs of taste; savor; flavor; taste.

A fine, strong fiber obtained from the young leaves of a Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum vulgare), used for cordage, bowstrings, etc.; also, the plant yielding this fiber. Called also tecum, and tecum fiber.
Anything; any part.
A small roll of tobacco, used for smoking.
That which is taken from another by violence; especially, the plunder taken from an enemy; pillage; booty.
The state of being tilled, or prepared for a crop; culture; as, land is good tilth.
The act of sneering.
The act or process of washing ores in a buddle.
One who, or that which, lays.
To earn by service or performance; to have a right to claim as reward; to deserve; sometimes, to deserve in a bad sense; as, to merit punishment.
An East Indian Weight of 1<frac13/ pounds.
Silver, pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe, and used as currency. The most common weight is about one pound troy.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied to other related species. See Bobwhite.
A handle, as of a mop; a stale.
A notch or incision; especially, one that is made as a tally mark; hence, a mark, or line, made for the purpose of account.
A saddle girth made of leather, canvas, woven horsehair, or woven grass.
One of the largest African antelopes (Hippotragusnasomaculatus or Oryx nasomaculatus).
A deep opening made by disruption, as a breach in the earth or a rock; a yawning abyss; a cleft; a fissure.
a coarse, tough, twilled cotton fabric used for uniforms or sports clothes.
Something drawn out or extended; expanse.

a French garlic-flavored mayonnaise.  It is often served with fish and other seafood, and sometimes with vegetables.
a large quantity.  See heap, senses 2 and 3; as, he made heaps of money in the stock market.
A variety of auction pitch in which the five of trumps counts five.
One of the flutings of a column.

A brown or reddish pigment used in both oil and water colors, obtained from certain natural clays variously colored by the oxides of iron and manganese. It is commonly heated or burned before being used, and is then called burnt umber; when not heated, it is called raw umber. See Burnt umber, below.
A reserve force in the Turkish army, or a soldier of the reserve. See Army organization, above.
A plaited, quilled, or goffered strip of lace, net, ribbon, or other material, -- used in place of collars or cuffs, and as a trimming for women's dresses and bonnets.
See Rigel.

The fluid which is excreted from the skin of an animal; the fluid secreted by the sudoriferous glands; a transparent, colorless, acid liquid with a peculiar odor, containing some fatty acids and mineral matter; perspiration. See Perspiration.
The bilge or protuberant part of a cask.
An Eskimo snow house.
Waste and knots of wool removed by the comb; combings.

A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatic theater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted their works to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; -- hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramatic performances.

A genus of large percoid fishes, of which one species (Lates Niloticus) inhabits the Nile, and another (Lates calcarifer) is found in the Ganges and other Indian rivers. They are valued as food fishes.
energy; pep.
A dear; a darling.
A similar garment worn formerly by gentlemen.

A carnivorous animal of the Weasel family (Mustela zibellina) native of the northern latitudes of Europe, Asia, and America, -- noted for its fine, soft, and valuable fur.
A breach; ruin; downfall; peril.
The quotient of a unit divided by five; one of five equal parts; a fifth part.
Curved arms of timber or iron, projecting over a ship's side of stern, having tackle to raise or lower a boat, swing it in on deck, rig it out for lowering, etc.; -- called also boat davits.
Agnus Dei.
The lading or freight of a ship or other vessel; the goods, merchandise, or whatever is conveyed in a vessel or boat; load; freight.

a sequence of three nucleotides in a genome or a DNA or messenger RNA molecule, which specifies the incorporation of one amino acid or is a stop signal, during the biosynthesis of proteins.  Codons occur within the protein-coding segments of the DNA or RNA genome of living organisms.  The amino acid sequence of proteins synthesized on ribosomes is thus determined by the sequence of the nucleotides in the genome.
A soft and flexible fabric for men's wear, made wholly of wool except in some inferior kinds, the wool being dyed, usually in two colors, before weaving.
A short line of horsehair, gut, etc., by which a fishhook is attached to a longer line.
A fish resembling the trout.
A large ornamental tropical American tree (Albizia saman) with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and sweet-pulp seed pods eaten by cattle.
red pear-shaped tropical fruit with poisonous seeds; its flesh is poisonous when unripe or overripe.

One of a breed of hardy cattle originating in the country of Devon, England. Those of pure blood have a deep red color. The small, longhorned variety, called North Devons, is distinguished by the superiority of its working oxen.
A flight of wild fowl (wild geese or the like).
Tapestry; a rich figured fabric; especially, a screen or hangings of heavy cloth with interwoven figures.
A collection of twenty-four sheets of paper of the same size and quality, unfolded or having a single fold; one twentieth of a ream.
See Koulan.
A deity corresponding to Odin, the supreme deity of the Scandinavians.  Wednesday is named for him.  See Odin.
A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list of names, etc.

Any parrot of the genus Ara, Sittace, or Macrocercus.  About eighteen species are known, all of them found in Central and South America.  They are large and have a very long tail, a strong hooked bill, and a naked space around the eyes.  The voice is harsh, and the colors are brilliant and strongly contrasted; they are among the largest and showiest of parrots.  Different species names have been given to the same macaw, as for example the Hyacinthine macaw, which has been variously classified as Anodorhyncus hyacynthinus, Anodorhyncus maximiliani, and Macrocercus hyacynthinus.
A fluke of an anchor.
An effort to raise something, as a weight, or one's self, or to move something heavy.
That which is new or unusual; a novelty.
See Pontee.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barley meal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians.  Called also kvass.
The act of sparing; moderation; restraint.
A brier.
A coarse woolen stuff with a long nap; -- usually dyed in plain colors.
A writer of an ode or odes.
A piece of a slender branch or twig cut for grafting.
A bed or stratum of shellfish; scalp.
Extreme pain; violent pang; anguish; agony; especially, one of the pangs of travail in childbirth, or purturition.
A piece of timber sawed thin, and of considerable length and breadth as compared with the thickness, -- used for building, etc.
A hangman. See Jack Ketch.
Same as Trier, 2 and 3.
The pygostyle.
The radical characteristic of xenylic compounds.
Mead. See Meathe.
Sunrise.
An ancient Greek hymn in honor of Apollo as a healing deity, and, later, a song addressed to other deities.
The inclosed space near the point where two lines meet; a corner; a nook.
A sphere.
A fine imposed as a penalty for violation of the law.
See Army organization, above.
The Manila-hemp plant (Musa textilis); also, its fiber. See Manila hemp under Manila.
Any detergent plant, or the part of it used as a detergent, as the roots of Agave Americana, Chlorogalum pomeridianum, etc.

Any one of numerous species of large, flat elasmobranch fishes of the genus Raia, having a long, slender tail, terminated by a small caudal fin. The pectoral fins, which are large and broad and united to the sides of the body and head, give a somewhat rhombic form to these fishes. The skin is more or less spinose.
A collection of such aphorisms.
The chaffinch.
Notice of a proposed marriage, proclaimed in a church, or other place prescribed by law, in order that any person may object, if he knows of just cause why the marriage should not take place.
An Eskimo.
The European cormorant.
The act of tasting; gustation.
Ill luck; misfortune.
A pet name for a rabbit or a squirrel.
A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of the servile classes; a churl.
Clean wool.
An instrument in form and use resembling the violin, but larger, and a fifth lower in compass.
A portable chair or covered vehicle for carrying a single person, -- usually borne on poles by two men. Called also sedan chair.
The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within the gleba in certain Gasteromycetes.
An implacable or malicious foe; one who is diabolically wicked or cruel; an infernal being; -- applied specifically to the devil or a demon.
That by which anything is hoisted; the apparatus for lifting goods.

A sweet white (or brownish yellow) crystalline substance, of a sandy or granular consistency, obtained by crystallizing the evaporated juice of certain plants, as the sugar cane, sorghum, beet root, sugar maple, etc. It is used for seasoning and preserving many kinds of food and drink. Ordinary sugar is essentially sucrose. See the Note below.
Sword.
A shell or husk; a cod or pod.
A bottle or vessel; esp., a vial or small glass bottle for holding vinegar, oil, pepper, or the like, for the table; a caster.
same as dicotyledon.
A weight; a poise.
Adornment.
A lobby in a theater; a greenroom.
The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall, eaquall, yaffle.
The snuff, or burnt wick, of a candle.

The ceremony observed in conferring the degree of doctor of divinity in some European universities. It begins by a harangue of the chancellor addressed to the young doctor, who then receives the cap, and presides at the disputation (also called the aulic).
Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovial sacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposed between tendons and bony prominences.
Minced meat.
A duel; also, the rules of dueling.
See Cymry.
A sphere.
A salmon in its second year.
A narrow piece of timber which holds together large pieces; a slat; as, the sloats of a cart.
An iron block, usually with a steel face, upon which metals are hammered and shaped.
The Abyssinian or Arabian ibex (Capra Nubiana). It is probably the wild goat of the Bible.

To assign a place to; to put in a particular spot or place, or in a certain relative position; to direct to a particular place; to fix; to settle; to locate; as, to place a book on a shelf; to place balls in tennis.
A forced or affected smile; a simper.
Same as Zorilla.
The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also a brood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence or resting place perched like an eagle's nest.
An Indian goat antelope (Nemorhedus goral), resembling the chamois.
The leaping, tripping, or measured stepping of one who dances; an amusement, in which the movements of the persons are regulated by art, in figures and in accord with music.
The genus of trees including the anchovy pear tree Grias cauliflora, whose fruit is somewhat like the mango.

Pottage made by pouring some boiling liquid on meal (esp. oatmeal), and stirring it. It is called beef brose, water brose, etc., according to the name of the liquid (beef broth, hot water, etc.) used.
A cylindrical glass vessel, with a large and short neck.
That which is used as the covering or ornament of the body; clothes; garments; habit; apparel.
A circle; hence, a diadem.
Of a red color; red, or reddish; as, a ruddy sky; a ruddy flame.
Half a shekel.
Tradition; occult doctrine. See Cabala.
The south wind.
Sward.

A carpenter's tool for boring holes larger than those bored by a gimlet. It has a handle placed crosswise by which it is turned with both hands. A pod auger is one with a straight channel or groove, like the half of a bean pod. A screw auger has a twisted blade, by the spiral groove of which the chips are discharge.
Bub; -- a term of familiar or affectionate address to a small boy.
A term of contempt for a worthless, dissipated fellow.
A European finch (Serinus hortulanus) closely related to the canary.
Language; speech; dialect.

An elementary substance, as sodium, calcium, or copper, whose oxide or hydroxide has basic rather than acid properties, as contrasted with the nonmetals, or metalloids.  No sharp line can be drawn between the metals and nonmetals, and certain elements partake of both acid and basic qualities, as chromium, manganese, bismuth, etc.
A corruption of pair royal. See under Pair, n.
See 2d Settee.
The human body, as distinguished from the head and limbs; in sculpture, the trunk of a statue, mutilated of head and limbs; as, the torso of Hercules.
A secret language or conventional slang peculiar to thieves, tramps, and vagabonds; flash.
The sum of five tens; fifty units or objects.
See Bonnet monkey, under Bonnet.
Wine produced on the island of Capri, commonly a light, dry, white wine.
A short, thick piece of anything.
Spermaceti.
A fault, wrong, or mistake.
Refuse; lees; dregs; the wash given to swine or cows; hogwash; waste matter.
A province; a government, as of a viceroy; also, a subahdar.
A native or inhabitant of Sweden.
The wrinkling of the brows or face in frowing; the expression of displeasure, sullenness, or discontent in the countenance; an angry frown.
A ledge; a right-angled projection.
A marmoset.
A small sloop or shallop, or a large boat with sails.
A white waxy solid, C16H33.OH; -- called also cetyl alcohol and cetylic alcohol. See Cetylic alcohol, under Cetylic.
See Alma mater, Dura mater, and Pia mater.
Orig., blithesomeness; gladness; now, the highest degree of happiness; blessedness; exalted felicity; heavenly joy.
An extortioner. See Poller.
One who applies lute.

A person who is held in bondage to another; one who is wholly subject to the will of another; one who is held as a chattel; one who has no freedom of action, but whose person and services are wholly under the control of another.
A structure or frame containing parallel or crosed bars, with interstices; a kind of latticework, such as is used ia the windows of prisons and cloisters.
English gin.
A brave person; one who is daring.
One of the leaves of the corolla, or the colored leaves of a flower. See Corolla, and Illust. of Flower.
Same as Quipu.
To apply a brush to, according to its particular use; to rub, smooth, clean, paint, etc., with a brush.
A choir or chorus.
A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.
A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyri of the brain; the gyri of brain coral.  See Brain.
Act or sound of plunking.
A flying or popular report; the common talk; hence, public fame; notoriety.
A genus of transparent, tubular, free-swimming oceanic tunicates found abundantly in all the warmer latitudes. See Illustration in Appendix.
A carouse; a drinking.
a workman who dresses things up.

A kind of canvaslike cotton fabric, used to stiffen and protect the lower part of trousers and of the skirts of women's dresses, etc.; -- so called from Wigan, the name of a town in Lancashire, England.
An earnest; earnest money; money paid to bind a bargain.
The gemsbok.
A state of anxious or fretful excitement; worry; vexation.
A fountain.
A tropical American tree (Annona diversifolia) grown in the southern U. S. having a whitish pink-tinged fruit.
A machine for spinning a number of threads at once, -- used in factories.  Also called spinning jenny.
To overlay, point, or edge with steel; as, to steel a razor; to steel an ax.
A horizontal working forming one of a series, the working faces of which present the appearance of a flight of steps.
To try; to attempt; to apply.
One who dines.

Sound uttered by the mouth, especially that uttered by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character; as, the human voice; a pleasant voice; a low voice.
The settlings of oil, molasses, etc., at the bottom of a barrel or hogshead.
One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one of the second class.
Among leather dealers, the thickest and stoutest tanned hides.
The Evil One; Satan, represented as the tempter and spiritual of mankind.
Shortened form of statistics{2} (b).
a sauce prepared from butter creamed with white wine, shallots, parsley and fish stock; -- also called Bercy sauce.
The jurisdiction of a tribunal.
A bitch of the hound kind.
Lager beer.
The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of those who acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.

A factor counted as a disadvantage; a loss or potential loss in a situation or plan; as, he added up all the pluses and minuses and decided not to do it; as, the lack of money is a big minus in an election campaign.
A whitish soluble powder used as a developer in photography.  Chemically, it is the sulphate of methyl-p-amino-m-cresol.
A name sometimes given to the raven.
A short, stout post used for any purpose, a to mark a boundary.
The quality of being wide; extent from side to side; breadth; wideness; as, the width of cloth; the width of a door.
A short spoon.

A jester; a buffoon.
Nozzle.
The first stomach of ruminants; the paunch; the fardingbag. See Illust. below. <-- ! PCP -->
A woman who has lost her husband by death, and has not married again; one living bereaved of a husband.
The oil of the mahwa tree.

A yellowish translucent resin resembling copal, found as a fossil in alluvial soils, with beds of lignite, or on the seashore in many places. It takes a fine polish, and is used for pipe mouthpieces, beads, etc., and as a basis for a fine varnish. By friction, it becomes strongly electric.
In India, a dependent person occupying a position between that of a servant or slave and a disciple; hence, a disciple or novice.
One who seeks for things which gratify merely himself; a selfish person; a selfist.
Work varnished and figured in the Japanese manner; also, the varnish or lacquer used in japanning.
A solid whose bases or ends are any similar, equal, and parallel plane figures, and whose sides are parallelograms.
The teasel.
A trumpet call for rousing soldiers; a reveille.
To possess or exercise sovereign power or authority; to exercise government, as a king or emperor;; to hold supreme power; to rule.
The Arabian name of two trees of the genus Balsamodendron, which yield a gum resin and a red aromatic wood.

A disciple of the philosopher Zeno; one of a Greek sect which held that men should be free from passion, unmoved by joy or grief, and should submit without complaint to unavoidable necessity, by which all things are governed.
Usury.
Abatement.
A tool used by coopers for smoothing and chamfering rheir work, especially the inside of casks.
An officer next in rank above a captain and next below a lieutenant colonel; the lowest field officer.

A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangular scales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on a roof.  They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed on ants. Called also Scaly anteater. See Pangolin.
The area in the central part of an amphitheater, in which the gladiators fought and other shows were exhibited; -- so called because it was covered with sand.
A short, thick, heavy piece of wood.
Furze. See Furze.
The twenty-fourth part of a grain; -- a weight used by goldsmiths.
A quantity; a goodly number.
A chicken.
A saying or utterance; especially, one that is short and frequently repeated; a theme.
An oblique direction; a line or direction including from a horizontal line or direction; also, sometimes, an inclination, as of one line or surface to another.
A tract of land used for grazing and the rearing of horses, cattle, or sheep. See Rancho, 2.
The refuse of cattle taken from a drove.

A piece of metal, as gold, silver, copper, etc., coined, or stamped, and issued by the sovereign authority as a medium of exchange in financial transactions between citizens and with government; also, any number of such pieces; coin.
See Picul.
An old English game; -- called also lawn billiards.
One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
A cup. See Calyx.

A glandular organ for secreting milk, characteristic of all mammals, but usually rudimentary in the male; a mammary gland; a breast; udder; bag.
The coaita.
The shag.
An elephant goad with a sharp spike and hook, resembling a short-handled boat hook.

One of several swimming birds or divers, of the genus Colymbus (formerly Podiceps), and allied genera, found in the northern parts of America, Europe, and Asia. They have strong, sharp bills, and lobate toes.
A floor or story of a house.
A plaintive tone; the nasal, childish tone of mean complaint; mean or affected complaint.

A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon.  When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lines drawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, and one to the dexter chief corner.
A kind of gate or portcullis, having iron bars, like a harrow, studded with iron spikes. It is hung above gateways so that it may be quickly lowered, to impede the advance of an enemy.
Gain in money or goods; profit; riches; -- often in an ill sense.
To fill by crowding something into; to cram with something; to load to excess; as, to stuff a bedtick.
Noise; confusion; uproar.
An internal muscle arising from the lumbar vertebr<ae/ and inserted into the femur. In man there are usually two on each side, and the larger one, or great psoas, forms a part of the iliopsoas.
A vagrant; an idle, sturdy beggar; a vagabond; a tramp.
Gentle heat; moderate warmth; tepidness.
A drunken condition; a spree.
A foister; a sharper.
A tropical American tree (Melicocca bijuga) bearing a small edible fruit with green leathery skin and sweet juicy translucent pulp.

The criminality and consequent exposure to punishment resulting from willful disobedience of law, or from morally wrong action; the state of one who has broken a moral or political law; crime; criminality; offense against right.
A kind of danceable music popular among black South Africans; it includes a whistle among its instruments.
A dolt; a blockhead.
A native, or permanent resident, of Rome; a citizen of Rome, or one upon whom certain rights and privileges of a Roman citizen were conferred.
A dog with long hair or shag; -- called also shockdog.
Salt or brackish water.
An inflammatory swelling or sore; a bulla, pustule, or blister.

a deciduous South African tree (Pterocarpus angolensis) having large odd-pinnate leaves and profuse fragrant orange-yellow flowers; it yields a red juice and heavy strong durable wood.
The back or upper part of the neck; the nape.
A sudden, noisy, and violent expulsion of air from the chest, caused by irritation in the air passages, or by the reflex action of nervous or gastric disorder, etc.
The moon's age at the beginning of the calendar year, or the number of days by which the last new moon has preceded the beginning of the year.
A head covering of various kinds; a hood; a coif; a cap.
A term of endearment; darling; -- corrupted from honey.

The most important salmon of Alaska (Oncorhinchus nerka), ascending in spring most rivers and lakes from Alaska to Oregon, Washington, and Idaho; -- called also red salmon, redfish, blueback, and sawqui.

An appearance of diagonal lines or ribs produced in textile fabrics by causing the weft threads to pass over one and under two, or over one and under three or more, warp threads, instead of over one and under the next in regular succession, as in plain weaving.

The sharp edge or salient angle formed by two surfaces meeting each other, whether plane or curved; -- applied particularly to the edges in moldings, and to the raised edges which separate the flutings in a Doric column.
A bust; a statue.
A small boom, pole, or spar, which crosses the sail of a boat diagonally from the mast to the upper aftmost corner, which it is used to extend and elevate.
The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4, regarded as characteristic of certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as, tolyl carbinol.
A tribunal or commission having charge of the revenue derived from trade and navigation.
A lever or key acted on by the foot, as in the pianoforte to raise the dampers, or in the organ to open and close certain pipes; a treadle, as in a lathe or a bicycle.
A person affected with leprosy.

A kind of flower cluster in which the flower stalks radiate from a common point, as in the carrot and milkweed. It is simple or compound; in the latter case, each peduncle bears another little umbel, called umbellet, or umbellule.
A salt of uric acid; as, sodium urate; ammonium urate.
A crone.

A clergyman or ecclesiastic.
A filament of a stamen.

any of various species of Dammara; as, the red kauri (Dammara lanceolata).

pl. of Beau.
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
A flat fold; a doubling, as of cloth; a pleat; as, a box plait.
A large number or mass of small animals or insects, especially when in motion.
Winter.
A delicate fiber, produced in the Philippine Islands from an unidentified plant, of which dresses, etc., are made.
The characteristic fluid of any vegetable or animal substance; the sap or part which can be expressed from fruit, etc.; the fluid part which separates from meat in cooking.
The rhinocerous bird (a).
A large, closed, four-wheeled carriage, having doors in the sides, and generally a front and back seat inside, each for two persons, and an elevated outside seat in front for the driver.
Corundum in the form of grains or powder, used in the arts for grinding and polishing hard substances. Native emery is mixed with more or less magnetic iron. See the Note under Corundum.
Rowan tree.
Any opinion, principle, dogma, belief, or doctrine, which a person holds or maintains as true; as, the tenets of Plato or of Cicero.
One who fines or purifies.
The pole or other support on which fowls rest at night; a perch.
Short for Chaparajos.
Bouche (see Bouche, 2); food and drink; provisions.

A porridge or gruel of maize meal and water, milk, or the like.

A whirling motion; an eddy, as of water; a whirl.
a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for the patio process.
Praise, honor, admiration, or distinction, accorded by common consent to a person or thing; high reputation; honorable fame; renown.
The wild ass of Persia.
The line between the lower part of the abdomen and the thigh, or the region of this line; the inguen.
The muskellunge.

An official diviner who foretold events by the singing, chattering, flight, and feeding of birds, or by signs or omens derived from celestial phenomena, certain appearances of quadrupeds, or unusual occurrences.
A week day, esp. a day which is neither a festival nor a fast.
Stucco.
A messenger.
Sound of any kind.

Loins.
A tyrant.

A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; the proclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by the very act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Roman emperors; the edicts of the French monarch.
An opening; a hollow; a bending.
Bread dried and browned before a fire, usually in slices; also, a kind of food prepared by putting slices of toasted bread into milk, gravy, etc.

The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposed to correspond nearly with our month of June.

A falling on and seizing, as the prey of a rapacious bird; the act of swooping.

A kind of portable photographic camera, esp. adapted for snapshot work, in which a succession of negatives is made upon a continuous roll of sensitized film; -- originally a trademark name of the Eastman Kodak Company, but from early 1900's through the 1930's it was popularly applied to almost any hand camera.

A medium of great elasticity and extreme tenuity, once supposed to pervade all space, the interior of solid bodies not excepted, and to be the medium of transmission of light and heat; hence often called luminiferous ether.  It is no longer believed that such a medium is required for the transmission of electromagnetic waves; the modern use of the term is mostly a figurative term for empty space, or for literary effect, and not intended to imply the actual existence of a physical medium.  However. modern cosmological theories based on quantum field theory do not rule out the possibility that the inherent energy of the vacuum is greater than zero, in which case the concept of an ether pervading the vacuum may have more than metaphoric meaning.

A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish and pellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownish shades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicate of alumina, and is used as a gem.
Having a low price in market; of small cost or price, as compared with the usual price or the real value.
an officer who proclaims the orders or directions of a court, or who gives public notice by loud proclamation; as, a town-crier.
A silky wool derived from the seeds of Ceiba pentandra (syn. Eriodendron anfractuosum), a bombaceous tree of the East and West Indies.
The lapis lazuli.

Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa; as, the oak eggar (L. roboris) of Europe.
same as Erg.

One dispatched upon an errand or mission; a messenger; esp., a person deputed by a sovereign or a government to negotiate a treaty, or transact other business, with a foreign sovereign or government; a minister accredited to a foreign government. An envoy's rank is below that of an ambassador.
an energetic American dance that was popular in the 1930s (probably named for the aviator Charles Lindbergh).

mother and earth goddess in Gilgamish epic; identified with Sumerian Ki and Ninkhursag (Mama; Nintu).
A donkey.

A variety of rum.
A woman's headband (sometimes of metal), for binding the front hair.

The wife of a king.
A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of the body; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; a neoplasm.
A contorted knot in wood; a crossgrained protuberance; a nodule; a boss or projection.
The crying of a cat.
A fabric resembling velvet, but having the nap flat and less close.
A toll. See Soc, n., 2.
An implement consisting of a small bowl (usually a shallow oval) with a handle, used especially in preparing or eating food.
a group of organisms derived from a single individual by some kind of asexual reproduction; -- used mostly of microorganisms such as bacteria and yeast.

To pierce slightly with a sharp-pointed instrument or substance; to make a puncture in, or to make by puncturing; to drive a fine point into; as, to prick one with a pin, needle, etc.; to prick a card; to prick holes in paper.

A fragrant gum resin obtained chiefly from tropical trees of the genera Amyris and Canarium. Amyris elemifera yields Mexican elemi; Canarium commune, the Manila elemi. It is used in the manufacture of varnishes, also in ointments and plasters.
The part of an anchor which fastens in the ground; a flook. See Anchor.
A tassel.
An edible fungus. Same as 1st Morel.
Any species of the order Ophidia; an ophidian; a serpent, whether harmless or venomous. See Ophidia, and Serpent.

Dainty.
The daughter of Jupiter and Latona; a virgin goddess who presided over hunting, chastity, and marriage; -- identified with the Greek goddess Artemis.
The Australian moundbird (Leipoa ocellata); it incubates eggs naturally in sandy mounds.
The act of swelling.
A tree, as distinguished from a shrub.

A degree, usually a slight degree, of some color, taste, or something foreign, infused into another substance or mixture, or added to it; tincture; color; dye; hue; shade; taste.
One who is conversant with, or who favors adoption of, Volap<uum/k.
That which is crisp or brittle; the state of being crisp or brittle; as, burned to a crisp; specifically, the rind of roasted pork; crackling.
A stoppage or irritation of the windpipe, producing the feeling of strangulation.
Any domestic animal that has an inclosure, or its proper place and company, and wanders at large, or is lost; an estray.  Used also figuratively.
A kind of coarse serge.
A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age.
The current of a stream.
A genus of polished marine gastropod shells, chiefly tropical, and often beautifully colored.
A twig of a tree cut off.
A French copper coin of one fourth the value of a sou.
One of certain narrow, crooked valleys seen, by aid of the telescope, on the surface of the moon.
A helmsman; a pilot.
A step, or set of steps, for ascending and descending, in passing a fence or wall.
A person, animal, or plant grown to full size and strength; one who has reached maturity.
A brocket.
Cloudiness; gloominess.
A slattern; a mawk.
Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit; energy.
A Turkish money of account (formerly a coin), of little value; the 120th part of a piaster.
either of two Welsh breeds of long-bodied short-legged dogs with erect ears and a foxlike head.
One of a race or tribe that has no fixed location, but wanders from place to place in search of pasture or game.

A point or hit.
A plaintive cry of, or like that of, a sheep.

One who holds a feu.
A granary; a barn.
A Hebrew patriarch (son of Isaac, and ancestor of the Jews), who in a vision saw a ladder reaching up to heaven (Gen. xxviii. 12); -- also called Israel.
To undergo or exhibit minute difference or variation, as of color, meaning, expression, etc.; to pass by slight changes; -- used chiefly with a preposition, as into, away, off.

A shoemaker's awl.
A stone.
One who labors hard and lives meanly; a mean fellow.
A trinket; a jewel; -- a word applied to anything small and of elegant workmanship.
That which is educed, as by analysis.
A country in Eastern Asia.
Miasma.

A part of the sacerdotal habit among Jews, being a covering for the back and breast, held together on the shoulders by two clasps or brooches of onyx stones set in gold, and fastened by a girdle of the same stuff as the ephod. The ephod for the priests was of plain linen; that for the high priest was richly embroidered in colors. The breastplate of the high priest was worn upon the ephod in front.
The number greater by a unit than seven; eight units or objects.
pl. of Radius.
A slope; the inclination of the face of a work.
A small wax candle; a small lighted wax candle; hence, a small light.
The act of stealing; specifically, the felonious taking and removing of personal property, with an intent to deprive the rightful owner of the same; larceny.
An English poet in the U. S.   Born 1907, died 1973.
A genus of shrubby plants, including the heaths, many of them producing beautiful flowers.
Progressive emaciation of the body, accompanied with hectic fever, with no well-marked local symptoms.

The accentual mark placed over n, and sometimes over l, in Spanish words [thus, <ntil/, <ltil/], indicating that, in pronunciation, the sound of the following vowel is to be preceded by that of the initial, or consonantal, y.
A strong, dark malt brew having a higher percentage of hops than porter; strong porter; a popular variety sold in the U. S. is Guinness' stout.
A tiger.
A small haven. See Hithe.
A large quantity; a lot; as, loads of fun.
Counterfeit money.
Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa.
Groats.
One who, or that which, eats.
A primitive word, from which spring other words; a radical; a root; an etymon.
An empty, immeasurable space; a yawning chasm.
A native or resident of Croatia.
A long, pointed weapon, used in war and hunting, by thrusting or throwing; a weapon with a long shaft and a sharp head or blade; a lance.
The East Indian leguminous tree Butea frondosa. See Gum Butea, under Gum.
The eleventh month of the ancient Hebrew year, approximately corresponding with February.
An accompanied dramatic recitative, interspersed with passages of melody, or followed by a full aria.
a relatively nontoxic South African herb (Leonotis leonurus) smoked like tobacco.

A live or glowing coal; a glede.
A botch; a patch.
See 3d Chase, n., 3.
The years of one's age having the termination -teen, beginning with thirteen and ending with nineteen; as, a girl in her teens.

A very heavy, inert gaseous element of the noble gas group, occurring in the atmosphere in the proportion of one volume is about 20 millions.  It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898.  It can be condensed to a liquid boiling at -107<deg/ C., and to a solid which melts at -111.9<deg/ C.  Symbol Xe (formerly also X); atomic number 54; atomic weight 131.3.
See Cadre.
A secret.
A variety of white lead. See Krems lead, under Lead, n.
See Morrow.
A conical loaf of sugar.
A Jewish cabalistic book attributed by tradition to Rabbi Simon ben Yochi, who lived about the end of the 1st century, a. d.  Modern critics believe it to be a compilation of the 13th century.

A frame of two strong timbers fixed perpendicularly in the fore part of a ship, on which to fasten the cables as the ship rides at anchor, or in warping. Other bitts are used for belaying (belaying bitts), for sustaining the windlass (carrick bitts, winch bitts, or windlass bitts), to hold the pawls of the windlass (pawl bitts) etc.
The goddess of flowers and spring.
Rate of exchange; also, the discount on uncurrent coins.
stupid, socially inept, unfashionable, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
A small genus of hairy herbs with yellow flowers.
The erectile external sexual organ of males, used in copulation, and in mammals, also for urination.
The redfin, or shiner.
Trust.
A bitter purgative principle in aloes.
A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kind of boat used in the Southern United States.
A sacred inclosure or temple; -- so called by the islanders of the Pacific Ocean.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C2H4N4); -- called also dicyandiamide.

A company of Irish herdsmen, or a single herdsman, wandering from place to place with flocks and herds, and living on their milk, like the Tartars; also, a place in the mountain pastures inclosed for the shelter of cattle or their keepers.
Liberty granted by which restraint or illegality is removed; permission; allowance; license.
A color of a delicate purple, violet, or lilac.
The quotient of a unit divided by three; one of three equal parts into which anything is divided.
A small loop or bow of ribbon used in making hats, boas, etc.
