A larva.
The military cloak of the Roman soldiers.
The young birds hatched at one time; a hatch; as, a brood of chickens.
A thick stew made with chicken (chicken gumbo), or seafood (seafood gumbo), thickened with okra or file, and also containing greens and often hot spices; it is particularly popular in Louisiana.
Same as Scissel, 2.
A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising or marvelous events.
The cuckoopint.
A secret council to deliberate on affairs of government or politics; a number of men combined for party intrigue; a faction; a cabal; as, a junto of ministers; a junto of politicians.
A sheet of paper, pasteboard, or the like, on which information is exhibited, esp. when the information is arranged in tabular form; as, an historical chart.

The aforesaid thing; the same (as before). Often contracted to do., or to two <ldquo/turned commas<rdquo/ (<rdquo/), or small marks.  Used in bills, books of account, tables of names, etc., to save repetition.

A rude picture, as of a bird, beast, or the like, used by the North American Indians as a symbolic designation, as of a family or a clan; also, the object or animal itself, considered as an symbol of the family.
A young salmon two or three years old, when it has acquired its silvery color.
A small plug or wooden pin, used to stop a vent, as in a cask.

Low, vulgar, unauthorized language; a popular but unauthorized word, phrase, or mode of expression; also, the jargon of some particular calling or class in society; low popular cant; as, the slang of the theater, of college, of sailors, etc.
The carrion crow.
Nightshade; -- so called from its blackish purple berries.
Water flying in small drops or particles, as by the force of wind, or the dashing of waves, or from a waterfall, and the like.
The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.

That part of the natural day when the sun is beneath the horizon, or the time from sunset to sunrise; esp., the time between dusk and dawn, when there is no light of the sun, but only moonlight, starlight, or artificial light.
Spelter.
The city and tower in the land of Shinar, where the confusion of languages took place.
The Scriptures of the Muslims, containing the professed revelations to Mohammed; -- called also Alcoran.
A fluid state.
A bamboo frame or trellis hung at a door or window of a house, over which water is suffered to trickle, in order to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
A twin crystal.
The handle of a scythe; a snead.
A shield or target.
The block through which a messenger passes.
A young hawk, when it begins to leave the nest.
A kind of flyboat; a storeship.
A beat, or strong pulsation, as of the heart and arteries; a violent beating; a papitation:
A kind of wig.

Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as the head of the Shinto religion.
pl. of Tarsus.
The female of the hawk; a falcon-gentil.
Strong desire; passion; especially, lust.
A small plate covering the armpit in armor of the 14th century and later.
One who puts out, ousts, or expels; also, an ouster; dispossession.
A crossbow. See Prod, 3.
A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plunged his forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
A natural stream of water smaller than a river or creek.

A sharp, brief, ringing sound, made by a collision of metallic or other sonorous bodies; -- usually expressing a duller or less resounding sound than clang, and a deeper and stronger sound than clink.

A passage or hall of communication, especially when large enough to serve also as a waiting room. It differs from an antechamber in that a lobby communicates between several rooms, an antechamber to one only; but this distinction is not carefully preserved.
An abyss; a gulf.
one of the units in a condominium.
A wave, or two or three successive waves, of great height and violence, at flood tide moving up an estuary or river; -- commonly called the bore or tidal bore. See Bore.
A gutter.
A sty on the eye. See Styan.
One of the small bulbs developed in the axils of the scales of a large bulb, as in the case of garlic.
The devil; a demon.
A suffusion of the cheeks or face with red, as from a sense of shame, confusion, or modesty.
Pieces of timber bolted to certain parts of a mast to support the trestletrees.
A small New Zealand owl (Sceloglaux albifacies). It has short wings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
A race of people of uncertain origin, who inhabited Scotland in early times.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as of birch.

The science and the art of tones, or musical sounds, i. e., sounds of higher or lower pitch, begotten of uniform and synchronous vibrations, as of a string at various degrees of tension; the science of harmonical tones which treats of the principles of harmony, or the properties, dependences, and relations of tones to each other; the art of combining tones in a manner to please the ear.
One who saves.

A door with an opening over it; a half door, sometimes set with spikes on the upper edge.
Freedom from restraint.
An end; conclusion. It is often placed at the end of a book.
A spotted trout (Salvelinus malma), inhabiting Northern America, west of the Rocky Mountains; -- called also Dolly Varden trout, bull trout, red-spotted trout, and golet.

Cider. See Sicer.

A love of the fine arts; a taste for curiosities.

A wild cat (Felis manul), having long, soft, light-colored fur.  It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.

A large species of American grass of the genus Zea (Zea Mays), widely cultivated as a forage and food plant; Indian corn, commonly called corn.  Also, its seed, growing on cobs, and used as food for men and animals.
A breaking or dashing to pieces; utter destruction; wreck.
The Lake herring (Coregonus Artedi), valuable food fish of the Great Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to Coregonus Hoyi, a related species of Lake Michigan.
The natives or inhabitants of Ireland, esp. the Celtic natives or their descendants.
A genus of fishes, including the fresh-water perch.

A well-known edible berry growing in pendent clusters or bunches on the grapevine. The berries are smooth-skinned, have a juicy pulp, and are cultivated in great quantities for table use and for making wine and raisins.
Any spider crab of the genus Maia, or family Maiadae.
The east wind.
The kidneys; also, the region of the kidneys; the loins.
a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.

The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column or a vase.
Ready money; cash; -- commonly with the; as, he was well supplied with the ready.

One of the two points of an orbit, as of a planet or satellite, which are at the greatest and least distance from the central body, corresponding to the aphelion and perihelion of a planet, or to the apogee and perigee of the moon. The more distant is called the higher apsis; the other, the lower apsis; and the line joining them, the line of apsides.
A legislative council of elders or chiefs; a senate.
A kind of carp (Cyprinus gibelio); -- called also Prussian carp.

An instrument for threshing or beating grain from the ear by hand, consisting of a wooden staff or handle, at the end of which a stouter and shorter pole or club, called a swipe, is so hung as to swing freely.

The Mexican pocket gopher (Geomys Mexicanus). It resembles the common pocket gopher of the Western United States, but is larger. Called also tugan, and tuza.
To reduce the purity of by mixing with a less valuable substance; as, to alloy gold with silver or copper, or silver with copper.

An unburnt brick dried in the sun; also used as an adjective, as, an adobe house, in Texas or New Mexico.

The front of an army. [Obs.] See Van.
A fragrant essential oil; esp., a volatile and highly fragrant essential oil obtained from the petals of roses.

Reverence for animal life or belief in animal powers and influences, as among savages.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part of British America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson's Bay.
The human body, whether living or dead.

Liquid to be swallowed; any fluid to be taken into the stomach for quenching thirst or for other purposes, as water, coffee, or decoctions.
One of the Brahmanic eons, a period of 4,320,000,000 years. At the end of each Kalpa the world is annihilated.
Sap green.
The scab or itch in cattle, dogs, and other beasts.
The proximal segment of the hind limb between the knee and the trunk. See Femur.
A brown amorphous substance found in decaying vegetation.  Cf. Humin.
A rapier; a sword; so named from Bilbao, in Spain.

The crested screamer of Brazil (Palamedea chavaria syn. Chauna chavaria), so called in imitation of its notes; -- called also chauna, and faithful kamichi. It is often domesticated and is useful in guarding other poultry. See Kamichi.
See Moil, and Moile.
A small singing bird of many genera and species, belonging to the family Fringillid<ae/.

A hoofed quadruped of the genus Equus; especially, the domestic horse (Equus caballus), which was domesticated in Egypt and Asia at a very early period.  It has six broad molars, on each side of each jaw, with six incisors, and two canine teeth, both above and below. The mares usually have the canine teeth rudimentary or wanting. The horse differs from the true asses, in having a long, flowing mane, and the tail bushy to the base. Unlike the asses it has callosities, or chestnuts, on all its legs. The horse excels in strength, speed, docility, courage, and nobleness of character, and is used for drawing, carrying, bearing a rider, and like purposes.
An inferior olive size having a woody pulp and a large clingstone pit, growing in the mountainous and high-valley districts around the city of Moron, in Spain.
A cage for hawks; a mew. See 4th Mew, 1.
A running knot, or loop, which binds the closer the more it is drawn.

A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the body covered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in front of the nose; -- called also noble, pluck, pogge, sea poacher, and armed bullhead.

A gift begged; a present.
A decorative member having the shape of a triangular gable, such as that above a Gothic arch in a doorway.

a large tropical American tree (Cordia alliodora) grown for its abundant creamy white flowers and valuable wood.

The course or way which is traveled or passed, or is to be passed; a passing; a course; a road or path; a march.

A mark made by impression; a line, character, figure, or indentation, made by the pressure of one thing on another; as, the print of teeth or nails in flesh; the print of the foot in sand or snow.
A suborder of struthious birds including the rheas.
The European crested titmouse.
A vitreous compound, used by potters in glazing, consisting of lime, silica, borax, lead, and soda.
A heddle.
See Rattan.

A projecting member left by cutting away the wood around it, and made to insert into a mortise, and in this way secure together the parts of a frame; especially, such a member when it passes entirely through the thickness of the piece in which the mortise is cut, and shows on the other side.  Cf. Tooth, Tusk.
A colloquial or humorous appellation for a negro; sometimes, the offspring of a black person and a mulatto; a zambo.
An East Indian insectivorous mammal (Gymnura Rafflesii), somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.
The refuse whale blubber, used as a manure, and in the manufacture of Prussian blue.

The science or art of exact reasoning, or of pure and formal thought, or of the laws according to which the processes of pure thinking should be conducted; the science of the formation and application of general notions; the science of generalization, judgment, classification, reasoning, and systematic arrangement; the science of correct reasoning.
A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small bottle for medicines; a vial.
A quantity of the stalks and ears of wheat, rye, or other grain, bound together; a bundle of grain or straw.
A structure on the hurricane deck of a steamer, containing the pilot house, officers' cabins, etc.
An old saying, which has obtained credit by long use; a proverb.
A club bent at the lower part for striking a ball at play; a hockey stick.
A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palms and the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes a valuable kind of sago.
A thin, single-cut file for combmakers.

Any one of several species of American musteline carnivores of the genus Mephitis and allied genera. They have two glands near the anus, secreting an extremely fetid liquid, which the animal ejects at pleasure as a means of defense.
A mullet (Mugil capito) found in the rivers of Southern Europe and in Africa.
See Cheer.
Scorn; derision; abusive talk.
A sharp pinch or jerk; a twist or twitch; as, a tweak of the nose.
The place of departed spirits; Hades; also, the grave.
The frog of a horse's foot.
A variety of the chamois found in the Pyrenees.

A saxicoline singing bird (Kittacincla macroura) of India, noted for the sweetness and power of its song. In confinement it imitates the notes of other birds and various animals with accuracy. Its head, neck, back, breast, and tail are glossy black, the rump white, the under parts chestnut.
See Tarn.
a cravat with wide square ends, tied so that the ends are laid flat; the ends are often secured with an ornamental pin; -- called cravat in Britain.
The hawkbill turtle. See Hawkbill.
See Fox, n., 7.
Popularly: Herbage; the plants which constitute the food of cattle and other beasts; pasture.
A shrill cry or sound.
A kind of dry fruit, consisting of three or more cells, each which at length breaks open at the inner angle.
A false or bastard wing. See under Bastard.
A wrinkling of the face in displeasure, rebuke, etc.; a sour, severe, or stern look; a scowl.
A sudden, overpowering fright; esp., a sudden and groundless fright; terror inspired by a trifling cause or a misapprehension of danger; as, the troops were seized with a panic; they fled in a panic.
A beach; a strand; in the plains and deserts of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona, a broad, level spot, on which subsequently becomes dry by evaporation.

Russian pancakes of buckwheat flour and yeast, sometimes made from white flour; they are usually served folded over, with caviar and sour cream on the inside; -- properly, it is a plural word (from the Russian plural of blin) but in America, often used as singular; thus the common plural blinis.
The Poland marmot (Arctomys bobac).
A light, loose dress or robe.
See Cloak.
A wretch; a rascal.
A definite summary of what is believed; esp., a summary of the articles of Christian faith; a confession of faith for public use; esp., one which is brief and comprehensive.
The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion of coagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
See Krems.

Any one of numerous species of ten-armed cephalopods having a long, tapered body, and a caudal fin on each side; especially, any species of Loligo, Ommastrephes, and related genera. See Calamary, Decacerata, Dibranchiata.
A feather.
An imaginary circle or orbit in the heavens; one of the celestial spheres.

An atom whose valence is six, and which can be theoretically combined with, substituted for, or replaced by, six monad atoms or radicals; as, sulphur is a hexad in sulphuric acid. Also used as an adjective.
A stripe of color.
One of the masses of generative tissue primitively alike in both sexes, but giving rise to either an ovary or a testis; a generative gland; a germ gland.
A small freshwater fish of South America and West Indies (Lebistes reticulatus or Poecilia reticulata, originaly called Gerardinus guppyi), often kept in aquariums; also called rainbow fish.
Myopia.
A woman's under-garment; a shift; a chemise.
A cooper's tool for making the grooves for the heads of casks, etc.; also, the groove itself.
One who idles; one who spends his time in inaction; a lazy person; a sluggard.
A corolla.

A piece of timber laid horizontally, or nearly so, to which the planks of the floor, or the laths or furring strips of a ceiling, are nailed; -- called, according to its position or use, binding joist, bridging joist, ceiling joist, trimming joist, etc. See Illust. of Double-framed floor, under Double, a.
See Poise.
the people of Great Britain.

The American bison buffalo (Bison Americanus), a large, gregarious bovine quadruped with shaggy mane and short black horns, which formerly roamed in herds over most of the temperate portion of North America, but by 1900 was restricted to very limited districts in the region of the Rocky Mountains, and was almost hunted to extinction.
Weight.
One who, or that which, sows.
A landing place or wharf.
The keel or lower outline of a bird's bill, so far as the mandibular rami are united.

A variety of the domestic dog, usually having large, drooping ears, esp. one which hunts game by scent, as the foxhound, bloodhound, deerhound, but also used for various breeds of fleet hunting dogs, as the greyhound, boarhound, etc.
A genus of perennial herbs of eastern North America and Asia having aromatic tuberous roots: ginseng.
One who rates or scolds.
To heal by applications or medicaments; to cure by remedial treatment; to apply salve to; as, to salve a wound.
See Skean.
One who vexes or troubles.
The property or aggregate properties of a thing by which it is rendered useful or desirable, or the degree of such property or sum of properties; worth; excellence; utility; importance.
A small inlet or bay, narrower and extending further into the land than a cove; a recess in the shore of the sea, or of a river.
A cover.
A city of France celebrated for certain manufactures.
The gadwall.
The grand adversary of man; the Devil, or Prince of darkness; the chief of the fallen angels; the archfiend.
In the East Indies, a princess or lady of high rank.
A measurer. See Gauger.
The inward part of a building; the interior.
The name popularly given to the rich man in our Lord's parable of the <ldquo/Rich Man and Lazarus<rdquo/ (Luke xvi. 19-31). Hence, a name for a rich worldling.

A fixed point of time, established in history by the occurrence of some grand or remarkable event; a point of time marked by an event of great subsequent influence; as, the epoch of the creation; the birth of Christ was the epoch which gave rise to the Christian era.
See Aught.
See Tierce.

A genus of lichens, most of the species of which have long, gray, pendulous, and finely branched fronds. Usnea barbata is the common bearded lichen which grows on branches of trees in northern forests.

A diseased state of the system, marked by increased heat, acceleration of the pulse, and a general derangement of the functions, including usually, thirst and loss of appetite.  Many diseases, of which fever is the most prominent symptom, are denominated fevers; as, typhoid fever; yellow fever.

A thicket of bushes, usually thorn bushes; especially, such a thicket planted as a fence between any two portions of land; and also any sort of shrubbery, as evergreens, planted in a line or as a fence; particularly, such a thicket planted round a field to fence it, or in rows to separate the parts of a garden.
A case or bag. See Housewife, 2.
A musical note, formerly in use, equal to two longs, four breves, or eight semibreves.
A rope or long thong of leather with a running noose, used for catching horses, cattle, etc.
A billet of wood; a piece of timber used as a prop.
A turf.
A sudden breaking forth; a violent rending; an explosion; as, a burst of thunder; a burst of applause; a burst of passion; a burst of inspiration.
A kind of head covering; a caul.
A piece of cloth, or other suitable material, sewed or otherwise fixed upon a garment to repair or strengthen it, esp. upon an old garment to cover a hole.
A Treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union which provided for stepwise reductions in the number of nuclear weapons possessed by each country.
A shell or pod.
A person sent out to gain and bring in tidings; especially, one employed in war to gain information of the movements and condition of an enemy.
One who, or that which, dives.
A dead body embalmed and dried after the manner of the ancient Egyptians; also, a body preserved, by any means, in a dry state, from the process of putrefaction.
A question; an inquiry to be answered or solved.
The snow goose.
One who dates.
Obs. pl. of Flea.
One who takes notice.
A kind of bandage passing, by successive turns and crosses, from an extremity to the trunk; -- so called from its resemblance to a spike of a barley.
A grape of an oval shape and whitish color.
A piece of the backbone of an animal, from between the neck and the collar bone, with the adjoining parts, cut for cooking; as, a chuck steak; a chuck roast.
One who utters gibes.

A shrub or small tree of the genus Corylus, as the Corylus avellana, bearing a nut containing a kernel of a mild, farinaceous taste; the filbert.  The American species are Corylus Americana, which produces the common hazelnut, and Corylus rostrata.  See Filbert.
A crossbeam; a lay of joists.
To form by heating and hammering; to beat into any particular shape, as a metal.
Brightness or luster of a body proceeding from a smooth surface; polish; as, the gloss of silk; cloth is calendered to give it a gloss.
A puff, as of smoke from a pipe, or of dust from a puffball; a slight explosion, as of a small quantity of gunpowder.
A genus of small Insectivora, including the common shrews.
A kind of candy made of molasses or brown sugar boiled down and poured out in shallow pans.
A large bar of steel formed directly from an ingot by hammering or rolling, being a preliminary shape for further working.
A hawse hole.
Originally, a kind of ruffle worn by men on the bosom of the shirt.
A sharp or uneven edge on a board that is cut from a log not perfectly squared, or that is made in the process of squaring.  See Wany, a.
An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.
The act of snorting; the sound produced in snorting.
A kind of fishing net.
A debt; an entry on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; -- mostly used adjectively; as, the debit side of an account.

The faculty by which the mind forms an image or a representation of anything perceived before; the power of combining and modifying such objects into new pictures or images; the power of readily and happily creating and recalling such objects for the purpose of amusement, wit, or embellishment; imagination.
Something to hinder sight or keep out light; a screen; a cover; esp. a hinged screen or shutter for a window; a blinder for a horse.

Any of several valuable estates of the Egyptian khedive or his family. The most important are the Da"i*ra Sa"ni*eh (s<aum/"n<icr/*<ecr/), or Da"i*ra Sa"ni*yeh, and the Da"i*ra Khas"sa, administered by the khedive's European bondholders, and known collectively as the Daira, or the Daira estates.
A seaport town of Yemen, on the Red Sea, also spelled Mukha.
See Miter.
A hood, or cape with a hood, made of lined with gray fur, formerly worn by the clergy; -- written also amess, amyss, and almuce.
A coarse stuff, usually of cotton, originally made in India.  Also, an imitation of this fabric made for export.
A mass or lump of fat rolled up by the butcher.
A low tower, having a truncated pyramidal form, and flanking an ancient Egyptian gateway.
To show insolent ridicule or mockery; to manifest contempt by derisive acts or language; -- often with at.
A metric ton.
Weather.
An Asiatic burrowing rodent (Siphneus aspalax) resembling the mole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.
a small band of jazz musicians.
Exodus; withdrawal.
A high-flavored substance, such as extract of game, for flavoring dishes of food; less properly, a ragout of partridge and rabbit braised in wine.
One of the fruit dots, or small clusters of sporangia, on the back of the fronds of ferns.
A genus of Western U. S. annuals with showy yellow or white flowers.
To break in a stave or the staves of; to break a hole in; to burst; -- often with in; as, to stave a cask; to stave in a boat.

The principal garment of a Hindoo woman. It consists of a long piece of cloth, which is wrapped round the middle of the body, a portion being arranged to hang down in front, and the remainder passed across the bosom over the left shoulder.
A yellow or brown amorphous substance obtained as a sublimation product in the flues of smelting furnaces of zinc, and consisting of a crude zinc oxide.
Exchange of commodities; barter.
A little elf or urchin.
A stratagem by which a thing is indirectly brought to pass, or by which one thing seems intended and another is done; a trick; an artifice.
A dark blue scombroid food fish (Acanthocibium solandri or Acanthocibium petus) of Florida and the West Indies.
A light fabric of wool, worn on the head by women; a cloud.

Any one of numerous species of large shrimplike Crustacea having slender legs and long antenn<ae/. They mostly belong to the genera Pandalus, Pal<ae/mon, Pal<ae/monetes, and Peneus, and are much used as food. The common English prawn is Pal<ae/mon serratus.
To put in the ground and cover, as seed for growth; as, to plant maize.
A fainting fit; syncope.
An article of food made from flour or meal by moistening, kneading, and baking.
The act of reducing to powder, or of sharpening, by friction.
A genus of palm trees including the palmetto of the Southern United States.
The posture of one that sits on his heels or hams, or close to the ground.
A place of shelter; protection; refuge.
A kind of snuff prepared by the natives of Venezuela from the roasted seeds of a leguminous tree (Piptadenia peregrina), thence called niopo tree.
A level; a working.
A region; country.
A phenol derivative of anthracene obtained as a white crystalline substance, which on oxidation produces a red dyestuff related to anthraquinone.
Drink, esp. alcoholic drink; also, a carouse; a booze.
To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow ceremoniously, or courtesy.
One of a body of native Algerian tirailleurs in the French army, dressed as a Turk.
Tribute; toll; custom. [Obs.] See Gabel.
A piece of armor for the thighs, forming an appendage to the ancient corselet.
Straw.
A shereef.
A plant of the genus Ajuga of the Mint family, a native of the Old World.
A native, or one of the people, of Greece; a Grecian; also, the language of Greece.
a knot in wood; a large or hard knot, or a protuberance with twisted grain, on a tree.
A beverage made of wine, water, sugar, nutmeg, and lemon juice; -- so called, it is said, from its first maker, Colonel Negus.
To dress with, or as with, a preen; to trim or dress with the beak, as the feathers; -- said of birds.
Var. of Soldier.
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of its species or kind.
An empty box, crate, cask, etc.; -- used in commerce, esp. in transportation of freight; as, <ldquo/special rates for empties.<rdquo/
Barren land having only a thin coat of grass.
A pair of shears; -- now always used in the plural, but formerly also in the singular. See Shears.
To betoken.
The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as a unit of pressure.
The kinkajou.
A layer of earth between coal seams.
A lath; a shaving or chip, as of wood or stone.
Active strength or force of body or mind; capacity for exertion, physically, intellectually, or morally; force; energy.
One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system.
The service or sacrifice of the Mass.
A wood of small growth; a thicket of brushwood. See Coppice.
The comic actor in an opera.
An animal destitute of human reason; any animal not human; esp. a quadruped; a beast.
One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so for sport; a copyist; a buffoon.
That which is said, written, or done in answer to what is said, written, or done by another; an answer; a response.
See Annals.
someone who races the luge.
A money of account in Persia, whose value varies greatly at different times and places. Its average value may be reckoned at about two and a half dollars.
A Burman measure of twelve miles.
An iron bucket for hoisting coal or ore.
A prop or shore.
To rest on the surface of any fluid; to swim; to be buoyed up.
Pain of mind on account of something in the past; mental suffering arising from any cause, as misfortune, loss of friends, misconduct of one's self or others, etc.; sorrow; sadness.
A mill.
Discrimination; judgment; propriety; reason; cause.
The backbone or spine of an animal; the back.
In Louisiana, a person reputed to be Acadian French descent.  Also used attributively, as in Cajun cooking.
A pupil; a student.

Any kind of khaki cloth; hence, a uniform of khaki or, rarely, a soldier clad in khaki. In the United States and British armies khaki or cloth of a very similar color is almost exclusively used for service in the field.
See Lodge.
The white poplar (Populus alba).
one of the often brightly colored and branching hornlike structures on the backs of nudibranchs and other related mollusks that serve as gills.
One who drinks rum; an habitually intemperate person.
A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposing forces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation or other purpose; an armistice.
The hard parts or skeleton of various Anthozoa, and of a few Hydrozoa. Similar structures are also formed by some Bryozoa.
See Cabob, n. & v. t.
A saint.
A dark red crystalline substance, isomeric with and resembling indigo blue, and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.
A twelfth part, as of the Roman as; an ounce.
A slow unwieldy trading vessel.
A way; a passage or ford.
the part of a transmitted signal which conveys the sound of the event represented by the signal, such as that of a television program.
A summons to arms, as on the approach of an enemy.
discrimination against middle-aged and elderly people.
A support for the spear when couched for the attack.

Any carnivorous mammal of the family Hy<ae/nid<ae/, doglike nocturnal mammals of Africa and southern Asia, of which three living species are known. They are large and strong, but cowardly. They feed chiefly on carrion, and are nocturnal in their habits.
An inclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building, or by different building; also, a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.

A fluctuation of mind arising from defect of knowledge or evidence; uncertainty of judgment or mind; unsettled state of opinion concerning the reality of an event, or the truth of an assertion, etc.; hesitation.
A person who leads or directs another in his way or course, as in a strange land; one who exhibits points of interest to strangers; a conductor; also, that which guides; a guidebook.
Any species of marine gastropods, of the genera Nassa, Tritia, and other allied genera of the family Nassidae; a dog whelk. See Illust. under Gastropoda.
A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright, giving the characters when taken together a round look.
See Saker.
a battle in the War of the Grand Alliance in Ireland in 1690, where William III of England defeated the deposed James II and so ended Stuart Catholicism in England.
A curve of the third degree.
One whose practice it is to raise mirth by odd tricks; a jester; a buffoon; a merry-andrew.
The act of putting one thing in the place of another, or of changing the place of a thing; change; substitution.
Tape or braid; an ornament.
One placed on watch, or in ambush.
A kind of fine sand from the banks of the Trent, used as a polishing powder.
A skeleton.

A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islands frequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. It is rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerful fertilizer.
A treatise on forms of argument; a system or scheme of forms or commonplaces of argument or oratory; as, the Topics of Aristotle.
Same as Almug (and etymologically preferable).
An edible fish of the Nile (genus Chromis).

A member of the sect of the Babis consisting of the adherents of Baha (Mirza Husain Ali, entitled <ldquo/Baha 'u 'llah,<rdquo/ or, <ldquo/the Splendor of God<rdquo/), the elder half brother of Mirza Yahya of Nur, who succeeded the Bab as the head of the Babists.  Baha in 1863 declared himself the supreme prophet of the sect, and became its recognized head.  There are upwards of 20,000 Bahais in the United States.
A flake; a thread or twist.
See Sizar.
A flood; a creek or inlet; a bay or estuary; a river; -- obsolete, except as a place name, -- as Fleet Street in London.
Same as Namaycush.
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls.
A leap; an elastic spring; a jump.
the unit of measurement for the proportion of gold in an alloy; 18-karat gold is 75 2.122e-314old; 24-karat gold is pure gold.
An imaginary being inhabiting the air; a fairy.
A striving; an effort; a conatus.
A true statement; freedom from error of falsehood; adherence to truth or fact.
A weight used in certain parts of the East Indies, varying considerably in different localities, the range being from 223 to 625 pounds.
Same as Fumage.
A bale of raw silk.
A genus comprising the common cuttlefish and numerous similar species. See Illustr. under Cuttlefish.
The tapir.

To regard with kindness; to support; to aid, or to have the disposition to aid, or to wish success to; to be propitious to; to treat with consideration or tenderness; to show partiality or unfair bias towards.
The main body; the chief part, bulk, or mass.
Same as kowtow, the more common spellings.
One who hires.

The tubers of the Mexican plant Ipom<oe/a purga (or Exogonium purga) of the family Convolvulaceae, a climber much like the morning-glory. The abstract, extract, and powder, prepared from the tubers, are well known purgative (cathartic) medicines, and are also called jalap. Other species of Ipom<oe/a yield several inferior kinds of jalap, as the Ipom<oe/a Orizabensis, and Ipom<oe/a tuberosa.
A sudden jerk; a quick throw or cast; a darting motion; hence, a jeer.

Any one of several species of small lemurs of the genus Stenops.  They have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in their habits.  The slender loris (Stenops gracilis), of Ceylon, in one of the best known species.
To trick, cheat, or impose on; to deceive.
A gap.
A game at dice, properly called novem quinque (L., nine five), the two principal throws being nine and five.
Same as Tucan.
To call by a title; to name; to entitle.
A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.
The act of moving in any manner; traveling; as, the going is bad.
Nephew.
A plant, and its flower, of the ranunculaceous genus P<ae/onia.  Of the four or five species, one is a shrub; the rest are perennial herbs with showy flowers, often double in cultivation.
A spike or nail.
A kind of millet, cultivated throughout Asia, and introduced into the south of Europe; a variety of Sorghum vulgare; -- called also Indian millet, and Guinea corn.
A holiday.

Any one of numerous species of American singing birds belonging to Vireo and allied genera of the family Vireonidae. In many of the species the back is greenish, or olive-colored.  Called also greenlet.
The universal ego from whom all individual atmans arise. This sense is a European excrescence on the East Indian thought.
See Lory.
A ditch or moat.
A relative, in general; especially, a descendant, whether male or female; a granddaughter or a grandson.
A scoop with a long handle, used to wash the sides of a vessel, and formerly to wet the sails or deck.
Something spoken aside; as, a remark made by a stageplayer which the other players are not supposed to hear.
Consisting of fur.
Apparel.
A serous or mucous discharge, especially one from the eves or nose.
The lowest of the four great castes among the Hindoos. See Caste.
A market place or public place in Rome, where causes were judicially tried, and orations delivered to the people.
A verse or meter composed or consisting of Ionic feet.

The sum or amount of money at which a thing is valued, or the value which a seller sets on his goods in market; that for which something is bought or sold, or offered for sale; equivalent in money or other means of exchange; current value or rate paid or demanded in market or in barter; cost.
The foramen of Monro.
A place where the water of a sea, lake, river, pond, etc., is shallow; a shallow.
A preparation made from the seeds of the chocolate tree, and used in making, a beverage; also the beverage made from cocoa or cocoa shells.
A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound. See Foot pound.
One deputed or authorized to perform the functions of another; a substitute in office; a deputy.
Any one of various species of Lepas, a genus of pedunculated barnacles found attached to floating timber, bottoms of ships, Gulf weed, etc.; -- called also goose barnacle. See Barnacle.
See Vizier.
A weight, at Madras 500 pounds, at Bombay 560 pounds.
The whiteweed (Chrysanthemum Leucanthemum), the plant commonly called daisy in North America; -- called also oxeye daisy. See Whiteweed.
A large drinking bowl; -- originally made of maple.
See Muset.
The East Indian name for the large spiral shell of several species of sea conch much used in making bangles, esp. Turbinella pyrum. Called also chank shell.
A cleft of crack; a narrow opening.
To constrain to do or to forbear, by the exertion of a power not resistible; to compel by physical, moral, or intellectual means; to coerce; as, masters force slaves to labor.
A colloquial or humorous name for any science or branch of knowledge.
The terminal lamina, or thin ventral part, of the anterior wall of the third ventricle of the brain.
The letter h or H.

The small, spicy berry of a species of pepper (Piper Cubeba; in (Med.), Cubeba officinalis), native in Java and Borneo, but now cultivated in various tropical countries.  The dried unripe fruit is much used in medicine as a stimulant and purgative.
same as camass.
A driving; a violent movement.
A line of persons waiting anywhere.
A prop; a support, as for the feet in standing or cilmbing.
An assembly; hence, the place of assembly, especially the market place, in an ancient Greek city.
A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the East Indies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
The broad part of anything; as, the broad of an oar.
Tousled; tangled; rough; shaggy.
a taxonomic group, or the name of a taxonomic grouping.
A blockhead; a dolt; a fool.
A short crowbar. See Jimmy.
An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamed base and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which dries up, forming a blackish crust.
A diseased condition of rye and other cereals, in which the grains become black, and often spur-shaped. It is caused by a parasitic fungus, Claviceps purpurea.
Same as Ixtle.
See Plait.
A contraction of Photograph.
A West African long-tailed monkey (Cercopithecus ruber); the red monkey.
One who pules; one who whines or complains; a weak person.
In mammals, a fluid excretion from the kidneys; in birds and reptiles, a solid or semisolid excretion.
A hole in the ground, or other hiding place, for concealing and preserving provisions which it is inconvenient to carry.
One who faces; one who puts on a false show; a bold-faced person.
Realm.
Same as Beild.
The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principal totem was the wolf.
A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.
A license for absence from a college or a religious house.
That which fends off attack or danger; a defense; a protection; a cover; security; shield.
The state of being one; oneness.
Amice, a hood or cape. See 2d Amice.
The girdle of a Jewish priest or officer.
A tithe.
the American Society of Cinematographers.
A burning piece of wood; or a stick or piece of wood partly burnt, whether burning or after the fire is extinct.
The scum or refuse matter which is thrown off, or falls from, metals in smelting the ore, or in the process of melting; recrement.
the hospital ward or clinic in which patients are detoxified; -- often used attributively.
A large African forest tree (Nauclea diderrichii) yielding a strong hard yellow to golden brown lumber; sometimes placed in genus Sarcocephalus, and then called Sarcocephalus diderrichii.
A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and often covered.
The harsh noise of a trumpet; a loud and somewhat harsh noise, like the blast of a trumpet; a roar or bellowing.

An association of men belonging to the same class, or engaged in kindred pursuits, formed for mutual aid and protection; a business fraternity or corporation; as, the Stationers' Guild; the Ironmongers' Guild. They were originally licensed by the government, and endowed with special privileges and authority.
A river of Hades whose waters when drunk caused forgetfulness of the past.

Any one of a large group of bright-colored clamatorial birds belonging to Pitta, and allied genera of the family Pittid<ae/. Most of the species are varied with three or more colors, such as blue, green, crimson, yellow, purple, and black. They are called also ground thrushes, and Old World ant thrushes; but they are not related to the true thrushes.
One of the divisions of a cleft hoof, as in the ox; also, the whole hoof.
A genus of shrubs (Sambucus) having broad umbels of white flowers, and small black or red berries.
A kind of dog. See Collie.
To run with a winding course; to double; to crook; to wind and turn.
A corner, bend, or angle; a hollow; as, the bight of a horse's knee; the bight of an elbow.
One who dotes; a man whose understanding is enfeebled by age; a dotard.
A class of claret wines, including several varieties, from the district of M<eacute/doc in the department of Gironde.

One of the forms which a verb takes by inflection or by adding auxiliary words, so as to indicate the time of the action or event signified; the modification which verbs undergo for the indication of time.
A small arboreal tropical American insectivorous lizard (Anolis carolinensis) with the ability to change skin color.

An inflammatory affection of the larynx or trachea, accompanied by a hoarse, ringing cough and stridulous, difficult breathing; esp., such an affection when associated with the development of a false membrane in the air passages (also called membranous croup). See False croup, under False, and Diphtheria.
pl. of Penny. See Penny.
A sudden causeless change or turn of the mind; a whim of fancy; a capricious prank; a vagary or caprice.
A South American striped frog (Pseudis paradoxa), remarkable for having a tadpole larger than the adult, and hence called also paradoxical frog.
An ouch; a jewel.

A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola).  The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides.  The horns are black, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp.  Called also rheeboc, rhebuck, rhebok, and rehboc.
Rounded stones containing tin ore, lying at the surface of the ground, and indicating a vein.

the American Standard Code for Information Interchange, a code consisting of a set of 128 7-bit combinations used in digital computers internally, for display purposes, and for exchanging data between computers.  It is very widely used, but because of the limited number of characters encoded must be supplemented or replaced by other codes for encoding special symbols or words in languages other than English.  Also used attributively; -- as, an ASCII file.
A live coal. See Gleed.
A public storehouse.
A leaf bud, as distinguished from a flower bud.
A certain quantity; a portion; a part; a division; as, a small share of prudence.
A tincture, rarely employed, which is considered as an orange color or bright brown. It is represented by diagonal lines from sinister to dexter, crossed by vertical lines.
Alloy.
To mark with, or as with, botches.
Leprosy.
A long, loose garment reaching to the feet.
The act of trying or testing in any manner.

A genus of American liliaceous, sometimes arborescent, plants having long, pointed, and often rigid, leaves at the top of a more or less woody stem, and bearing a large panicle of showy white blossoms.
A high, steep bank, as by a river or the sea, or beside a ravine or plain; a cliff with a broad face.
Fuel.
The under surface of the foot.
A tremulous agitation; a quick vibratory movement; a shudder; a quivering.
A station, as for collection of customs, for palanquin bearers, police, etc.
One who works with a file.
A pulling; a disturbance.

A contrivance employed by the ancient Peruvians, Mexicans, etc., as a substitute for writing and figures, consisting of a main cord, from which hung at certain distances smaller cords of various colors, each having a special meaning, as silver, gold, corn, soldiers. etc. Single, double, and triple knots were tied in the smaller cords, representing definite numbers. It was chiefly used for arithmetical purposes, and to register important facts and events.
The coast or land adjacent to a large body of water, as an ocean, lake, or large river.
A word of doubtful meaning, occuring frequently in the Psalms; by some, supposed to signify silence or a pause in the musical performance of the song.
Same as Sacs.
See Loach.
See 5th Scald.
A salutation or compliment of ceremony in the east by word or act; an obeisance, performed by bowing very low and placing the right palm on the forehead.
The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip of dogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps. See Illust. of Bloodhound.
A Roman measure of land, measuring 28,800 square feet, or 240 feet in length by 120 in breadth.
Headstrong; obstinate.
That which holds anything tightly or supports it firmly; a bandage or a prop.
The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinese tea.
An umbelliferous plant (Pimpinella anisum) growing naturally in Egypt, and cultivated in Spain, Malta, etc., for its carminative and aromatic seeds.
A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around a vertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railway track.
See Piece.
A small whale.
A game at cards; whist.
A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork; sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble in alcohol.
A shout of huzza; a cheer; a hurrah.
The armpit; also, the arm.

A very large and powerful carnivore (Felis tigris) native of Southern Asia and the East Indies. Its back and sides are tawny or rufous yellow, transversely striped with black, the tail is ringed with black, the throat and belly are nearly white. When full grown, it equals or exceeds the lion in size and strength. Called also royal tiger, and Bengal tiger.
Defensive armor for the thighs.
An effervescent liquor like kumiss, made from fermented milk, used as a food and as a medicine in the northern Caucasus.

An electronic device that converts electronic signals into sound waves, and sound waves into electronic signals, used to transmit information between computers by the use of ordinary telephone lines; also called modulator-demodulator; as, the latest modems can transmit data at 56,000 baud over a clear telephone line.  The speed of transmission of information by a modem is usually measured in units of baud, equivalent to bits per second.
Wheat, or bread made from wheat.
The bracteal covering of the flowers or seeds of grain and grasses; esp., an outer husk or bract of a spikelet.
A sterile transformed stamen.
Skin of bacon.
A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, in fascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle).
An instrument that converts sound into signals that can be transmitted over distances and then converts received signals back into sounds; a telephone; as, I talked to him on the phone.
A tropical tree of Central America and the West Indies and Puerto Rico (Inga laurina) having spikes of white flowers; it is used as shade for coffee plantations.
A West Indian name for two large timber trees (Podocarpus coriaceus, and Podocarpus Purdicanus) of the Yew family. The wood, which is much used, is pale brownish with darker streaks.
An African genet (Genetta pardina). See Genet.
A sudden or irregular incursion in border warfare; hence, any irregular incursion for war or spoils; a raid.
A fishing line, often extending a mile or more, having many short lines bearing hooks attached to it. It is used for catching cod, halibut, etc.; a boulter.
A knot in wood. See Gnarl.
The track or tread a horseman makes upon the ground he goes over.
Raspings of ivory, hartshorn, metals, or other hard substance.
See Almonry.
an interest followed with exaggerated zeal; a fad.
One who tunes; especially, one whose occupation is to tune musical instruments.
A small shaft sunk from one level to another, as for the purpose of ventilation.
A statement; also, a document containing a statement.
Drink; also, pottage.
To put in order; to reduce to a methodical arrangement; to arrange in a series, or with reference to an end. Hence, to regulate; to dispose; to direct; to rule.
A brant. See Brant.
A name given to several malvaceous trees (species of Hibiscus, Ochroma, etc.), and to their strong fibrous inner bark, which is used for strings and cordage.
A machine formerly employed for reducing dislocations of the humerus.
A contrivance, often consisting of a noose of cord, or the like, by which a bird or other animal may be entangled and caught; a trap; a gin.

A species of pepper (Piper betle), the leaves of which are chewed, with the areca or betel nut and a little shell lime, by the inhabitants of the East Indies. It is a woody climber with ovate many-nerved leaves.
The eye of a bean or other seed; the mark or scar at the point of attachment of an ovule or seed to its base or support; -- called also hile.
The carved work under the quarter piece at the aft part of the quarter gallery.
A single seat with three or four legs and without a back, made in various forms for various uses.
A kind of toy or rude musical instrument, as a tube inside of which is a stretched string or membrane made to vibrate by singing or humming into the tube.

A milky or colored juice in certain plants in cavities (called latex cells or latex tubes). It contains the peculiar principles of the plants, whether aromatic, bitter, or acid, and in many instances yields caoutchouc upon coagulation.  The lattex of the India rubber plant produces the rubber of commerce on coagulation.
An expression of mirth peculiar to the human species; the sound heard in laughing; laughter. See Laugh, v. i.
The gavial.

The unit of monetary value in Russia. <-- and, 1917-1992, in the Soviet Union --> It is divided into 100 copecks, and in the gold coin of the realm (as in the five and ten ruble pieces) is worth about 77 cents. The silver ruble is a coin worth about 60 cents.
Same as Alewife.
An eager desire or longing; greediness; as, a greed of gain.
Preface; introduction; preliminary observations; prelude.
A marsupial of Australia (Dasyurus macrurus), about the size of a cat.
See Rhyme.
The garfish.
See Gulf.
The beating or throbbing of the heart or blood vessels, especially of the arteries.

A unit of work which is equal to 107 ergs (the unit of work in the C. G. S. system of units), and is equivalent to one watt-second, the energy expended in one second by an electric current of one ampere in a resistance of one ohm; also called the absolute joule.  It is abbreviated J or j.  The international joule is slightly larger, being 1.000167 times the absolute joule.  The absolute joule is approximately equal to 0.737562 foot pounds, 0.239006 gram-calories (small calories),  and 3.72506 x 10-7 horsepower-hours, and 0.000948451 B.t.u.
A braid, knot, or curl, of hair; a ringlet.
A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U. S. standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons.
Same as Whall.
Same as Crape.
Any similar wind, as the chinook, in other parts of the world.
To set fire to; to cause to burn; to set burning; to ignite; to kindle; as, to light a candle or lamp; to light the gas; -- sometimes with up.

A species of hickory (Carya oliv<ae/formis), growing in North America, chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas, where it is one of the largest of forest trees; also, its fruit, a smooth, oblong nut, an inch or an inch and a half long, with a thin shell and well-flavored meat.

The act of stretching or extending; extension; power of reaching or touching with the person, or a limb, or something held or thrown; as, the fruit is beyond my reach; to be within reach of cannon shot.
An opening made by fracture or disruption.
A vat or tub in which the mash is made; a mash tub.
The joint or bend of the arm; the outer curve in the middle of the arm when bent.
See Gypsy.
A narrow passage between precipitous rocks or banks, which looks as if it might be crossed at a stride.
Rubbish or refuse consisting of broken rock containing little or no ore.
a type of folk song that originated among Black Americans at the beginning of the 20th century; has a melancholoy sound from repeated used of blue notes.
A transparent mucous discharge from the membrane of the urethra, commonly an effect of gonorrhea.
The cavity in such a nodule.
In Spanish America, a wood; forest; timber land; esp., in parts of South America, a comparatively wooden region.
Water retained by an embankment; a pool of water.
Scattered or ejected spittle.
See Zantewood.
A long seat, differing from a stool in its greater length.
A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate their aproach to a place.
An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerly common in Europe.
A believer in ovism.  Same as Ovulist.
Putage.
A shekel.
A continuous noise or murmur.
The strong point; that in which one excels.

A metallic pin with a head, used for uniting two plates or pieces of material together, by passing it through them and then beating or pressing down the point so that it shall spread out and form a second head; a pin or bolt headed or clinched at both ends.
A snipe.
A piece of cane or reed with a knot at each end, or a hollow cylinder of wood with a ridge at each end, used to wind thread or yarn upon.
A catkin or ament. See Ament.

A sauce used in Italian cuisine, typically made by blending olive oil, basil, garlic, pine nuts, and grated parmesan cheese; it is served hot or cold over pasta, meat, or fish.  Where pine nuts are expensive, sunflower seeds are sometimes substituted.
See Gonys.
A rapid in some rivers; as, the Sault Ste. Marie.
A small, oval, transparent jellyfish, belonging to the Ctenophora.
Belief; the assent of the mind to the truth of what is declared by another, resting solely and implicitly on his authority and veracity; reliance on testimony.
Same as Drilling.
The head.
A young fellow; formerly, a low thief.
Any eared seal.
The olecranon, or the elbow.
A bending without angles; that which is bent; a flexure; as, a curve in a railway or canal.
Like a miss, or girl.
See pansy.
A farewell; commendation to the care of God at parting.
Full extent; distance between extreme limits; especially; the distance between the nearest surfaces of two bodies, or the space between walls; as, a room ten feet square in the clear.
An imaginary evil being among Eastern nations, which was supposed to feed upon human bodies.
A South American armadillo (Dasypus sexcinctus). Called also sixbanded armadillo.
A gunlock.
The part of a plow which projects downward beneath the beam, for holding the share and other working parts; -- also called standard, or post.
A kind of cap worn in the 16th century, and copied in modern fashions; -- called also toquet.
Aliment; food.
A shot in which the ball struck with the cue comes in contact with two or more balls on the table; a hitting of two or more balls with the player's ball. In England it is called cannon.
A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point or process, terminating a larger part or organ.
One who fits shoes to the feet; one who furnishes or puts on shoes; as, a shoer of horses.
A salt glaze on pottery, made by adding common salt to an earthenware glaze.
The fleshy pome or fruit of a rosaceous tree (Pyrus malus) cultivated in numberless varieties in the temperate zones.
A kind of wild goose, by a flock of which a virtuoso was fabled to be carried to the lunar world.
The edge of a cask, etc; a chine. See Chine, n., 3.
Same as Thuja.
Sadness; dismalness.
A species of large South African antelope (Oreas canna). It is valued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing in the settled districts; -- called also Cape elk.
Any substance supposed to be capable of absorbing, retaining, and transporting contagious or infectious germs; as, woolen clothes are said to be active fomites.
That part of a garment which is turned back; specifically, the lap, or fold, of the front of a coat in continuation of collar.
The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman.
A wooden or metal pin, set in the gunwale of a boat, to serve as a fulcrum for the oar in rowing.
Sharp passion; vexation.
A conic section.

A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp, without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarp is succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry and subcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.
A large-maned wild dog of South America (Canis jubatus) -- named from its cry.

Any animal of the genus Hyrax, of which about four species are known.  They constitute the order Hyracoidea.  The best known species are the daman (Hyrax Syriacus) of Palestine, and the klipdas (Hyrax capensis) of South Africa.  Other species are Hyrax arboreus and Hyrax Sylvestris, the former from Southern, and the latter from Western, Africa. See Daman.
The ahu, or jairou.
The part of anything that hangs loose, having no strain upon it; as, the slack of a rope or of a sail.
The quality or being true; as: -- (a) Conformity to fact or reality; exact accordance with that which is, or has been; or shall be.
A white crystalline resinous substance extracted from gutta-percha by the action of alcohol or ether.

a game commonly used for low-stakes gambling, in which numbered balls or slips are drawn at random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards, called Bingo cards, which have square arrangement of such numbers.  Each card has a different arrangement of the numbers, and the first player to cover all numbers in one row (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal) is the winner, usually announcing that fact by a cry of <ldquo/Bingo!<rdquo/
A vital part; one of the vitals.
Small particles of ore.

A liliaceous plant of the genus Allium (Allium cepa), having a strong-flavored bulb and long hollow leaves; also, its bulbous root, much used as an article of food.  The name is often extended to other species of the genus.
See Verst.
A cottage or small house; a hut.

A trailing grass (Cynodon dactylon) native to Europe, now cosmopolitan in warm regions; used for lawns and pastures especially in the Southern U. S. and India.  Called also Bahama grass and Bermuda grass.
A small tropical American tree (Chrysobalanus icaco) bearing edible plumlike fruit.
A candlestick with many branches, each of which bears the name of some one of the descendants of Jesse; -- called also  tree of Jesse.
A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhood occupied by anchorites who were under the same superior.
Same as heroin; -- a slang term.
Crude tartar; an acidulous salt from which cream of tartar is prepared. It exists in the juice of grapes, and is deposited from wines on the sides of the casks.
To burn with a flame or blaze; to burn as gas emitted from bodies in combustion; to blaze.
A sharp tool or weapon.
Happy; fortunate; blessed.
See Fidget.
A rent, service, tribute, custom, tax, impost, or duty; an excise.
A simpleton.
See Rota.
See Waft, n., 4.
A room or rooms behind that part of the exterior; all the rooms immediately below the roof.
The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain (Plantago Lanceolata).
Fretful excitement. [Obs.] See Feaze.
See Meros.
A binary compound of oxygen with an atom or radical, or a compound which is regarded as binary; as, iron oxide, ethyl oxide, nitrogen oxide, etc.
A coarse or stupid fellow.
Olefiant gas or ethylene; -- so called by Berzelius from its forming an oil combining with chlorine. [Written also elayle.] See Ethylene.
A small collection of sheaves set up in the field; a shock; in England, twelve sheaves.
The eyelashes.
Same as Joust.

Any plant of the composite genus Tanacetum. The common tansy (Tanacetum vulgare) has finely divided leaves, a strong aromatic odor, and a very bitter taste. It is used for medicinal and culinary purposes.
Same as Taxer, n., 2.
A vexillum.
An earthwork; a mound; a raised work.
Pebbles, collectively; shingle.
A branch of the Mongolian race, now living in the northern parts of Norway, Sweden, and the adjacent parts of Russia.
A silk cloth, of a thick, close texture, and overshot woof, which has a glossy surface.
A sedgelike plant (Cyperus esculentus) producing edible tubers, native about the Mediterranean, now cultivated in many regions; the earth almond.
A hydro-a<eum/roplane.
The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustani language which is chiefly spoken by native Hindus. In employs the Devanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written.
See Sufi.
Same as Piraya.
a special loved one; a darling; -- used as a term of endearment.
Husband.

A small Asiatic mammal (Ailurus fulgens) having fine soft fur, which inhabits the mountains of Northern India.  It was once thought to be related to the bears, but is now believed to be more closely related to raccoons.  It has reddish-brown fur on the back and sides, and black fur on the legs and underside.  Called also the lesser panda.
The siskin.
One who exposes to the air.
The place where the meetings of the senate were held; the senate house.
The act of shooting; the discharge of a missile; a shot; as, the shoot of a shuttle.
A mark left by something that has passed along; as, the track, or wake, of a ship; the track of a meteor; the track of a sled or a wheel.
A judgment, sentence, or final decision. Specifically: The decision of arbitrators in a case submitted.
Goddess of the seasons, or of the hours of the day.
To injure, mar, spoil, or harm.
A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfing green.
The common mallow.
Talk to little purpose; trifling talk; unmeaning loquacity.
The sense or faculty by which certain qualities of bodies are perceived through the instrumentally of the olfactory nerves. See Sense.
A bank; a dike.
A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; -- usually in a bad sense.
A common American tyrant flycatcher (Sayornis ph<oe/be, or Sayornis fuscus).  Called also pewit, and ph<oe/be.

A form of dark matter in distant outer space unobservable except by its gravitational effect, and believed to be at least part of the <ldquo/missing matter<rdquo/ which is unobservable as ordinary stars, but helps keep galaxies from flying apart; MACHOS are massive but compact objects such as neutron stars or brown dwarfs, which can be detected (with difficulty) by their effect in bending light from distant light sources, such as other galaxies.  This can occur if by rare chance a MACHO passes in front of a more distant visible object, and the light from that object becomes temporarily amplified by the MACHO acting as a gravitational lens.  Some MACHOs have been discovered in the halo of dark matter that surrounds our milky way.  It is, however, questionable whether the amount of such matter is sufficient to explain the ability of galaxies to stay together in spite of rotation rates that would cause them to fly apart if the only matter present was that observable as visible stars.
Same as Ousel.

Any plant of the genus Carex, perennial, endogenous, innutritious herbs, often growing in dense tufts in marshy places. They have triangular jointless stems, a spiked inflorescence, and long grasslike leaves which are usually rough on the margins and midrib. There are several hundred species.
A Cretan
A panegyrical funeral oration.
An ethereal fluid that supplied the place of blood in the veins of the gods.
Lightning.
A train which receives and deposits passengers or freight along the line of the road; a train for the accommodation of a certain district.
The European pollack; -- called also laith, and leet.
The Barbary ape.

any of several types of protein particle lacking nucleic acid, believed to be the cause of certain slow-developing infectious diseases such as scapie in sheep, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and Kuru in humans.
A hermit.
A person of mixed blood.

A certain game at cards; -- so called because it requires silence and close attention. It is played by four persons (those who sit opposite each other being partners) with a complete pack of fifty-two cards. Each player has thirteen cards, and when these are played out, the hand is finished, and the cards are again shuffled and distributed.
The calcined ashes of any coarse seaweed used for the manufacture of soda and iodine; also, the seaweed itself; fucus; wrack.
A machine for fanning a room, usually a movable fanlike frame covered with canvas, and suspended from the ceiling. It is kept in motion by pulling a cord.
A mud volcano, the water of which is often impregnated with salts, whence the name.
A stringed musical instrument having a head and neck like the guitar, and a circular body like a tambourine.  It has five strings, and is played with the fingers and hands.
To have ideas or images in the mind while in the state of sleep; to experience sleeping visions; -- often with of; as, to dream of a battle, or of an absent friend.
A kind of minuet, in triple time, of French origin, popular in the reign of Queen Elizabeth and for some time after; -- called also passing measure, and passymeasure.
See Dermis.
One who makes jokes or jests.
A saint.
An implement for digging or cutting the ground, consisting usually of an oblong and nearly rectangular blade of iron, with a handle like that of a shovel.
Same as Silva.
The earth; earth.
To effect as an agent; to produce; to be the occasion of; to bring about; to bring into existence; to make; -- usually followed by an infinitive, sometimes by that with a finite verb.
A hautboy or oboe.

The fruit of the mango tree. It is rather larger than an apple, and of an ovoid shape. Some varieties are fleshy and luscious, and others tough and tasting of turpentine. The green fruit is pickled for market.

A cylinder, or a cylindrical perforation, having a continuous rib, called the thread, winding round it spirally at a constant inclination, so as to leave a continuous spiral groove between one turn and the next, -- used chiefly for producing, when revolved, motion or pressure in the direction of its axis, by the sliding of the threads of the cylinder in the grooves between the threads of the perforation adapted to it, the former being distinguished as the external, or male screw, or, more usually the screw; the latter as the internal, or female screw, or, more usually, the nut.
One of the hereditary classes into which the Hindu are divided according to the laws of Brahmanism.
A council; a convention; a tribunal; an assembly; esp., the grand council of state in Spain.
Judea; also, a district inhabited by Jews; a Jews' quarter.
See Argol.
A support or supporter; a stay; a prop.
Same as handkerchief.
A compressed mass of paper sheets, forming a matrix or mold for stereotype plates.
A pantry.
A rib of an animal or a human being.
Place, or spot, in general.
Neighborhood; vicinity; venue.  See Venue.
A cuirass or breastplate.
A mace bearer; an officer of a court.
A gun so placed as to rake an enemy's ship.
An old measure of length in France, containing six French feet, or about 6.3946 French feet.
To eject the contents of the stomach by the mouth; to puke; to spew.
A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for one second, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; -- proposed by J. D. Everett, an English physicist.
A West African gazelle (Gazella redunca).
A contraction for Violoncello.
A gift; endowment.
A mope; a drone.
One who rows with an oar.
The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the two bones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
In the Orkney and Shetland Islands, beef and mutton hung and dried, but not salted.
An organic radical, C3H5, existing especially in oils of garlic and mustard.
The dried meat of the cocoanut, from which cocoanut oil is expressed.
A large noxious fly of Abyssinia, which like the tsetse fly, is destructive to cattle.
A kind of tape or braid.
Slowness; tardiness.
A wonder; a marvel.

the candlewood of Mexico and couthwestern California (Idria columnaris or Fouquieria columnaris), having tall columnar stems and bearing honey-scented creamy yellow flowers; -- called also the boojum tree.

A great flow of water; a body of moving water; the flowing stream, as of a river; especially, a body of water, rising, swelling, and overflowing land not usually thus covered; a deluge; a freshet; an inundation.
See Bairn.
Something infixed.
A carucate.
A summary account.
A red color used by painters.
A soft crayon for use in stump drawing or in shading with the stump.
Series.
The small and nearly cubical stone building, toward which all Muslims must pray.
See Krang.
A sloth.
That portion of a fibrovascular bundle which has developed, or will develop, into wood cells; -- distinguished from phloem.
Lightning.
Any crude mixture of mineral or organic matters in the state of a thin paste.
Reconciliation; agreement after variance; harmony; concord.
See Peen.
A tool for shaping the rimes of a ladder.
A bard, or learned man, among the ancient Goths.
Hail or snow, mingled with rain, usually falling, or driven by the wind, in fine particles.
A glimpse, glance, or gleam.
See Graft.
The person creating a wakf.
See Calk.
A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part of spermaceti.
The covering of a flower. See Flower.

A small bag or pouch, the opening of which is made to draw together closely, used to carry money in; by extension, any receptacle for money carried on the person; a wallet; a pocketbook; a portemonnaie.
A gun, the inside of whose barrel is grooved with spiral channels, thus giving the ball a rotary motion and insuring greater accuracy of fire. As a military firearm it has superseded the musket.

Any one of several species of large wading birds of the family Ciconidae, having long legs and a long, pointed bill.  They are found both in the Old World and in America, and belong to Ciconia and several allied genera.  The European white stork (Ciconia alba) is the best known.  It commonly makes its nests on the top of a building, a chimney, a church spire, or a pillar.  The black stork (Ciconia nigra) is native of Asia, Africa, and Europe.
The act of hurrying in motion or business; pressure; urgency; bustle; confusion.
A Romansch dialect spoken in some parts of Switzerland and the Tyrol.
An old Italian silver coin, worth about ten cents.
A work having two parapets whose faces unite so as to form a salient angle toward the enemy.
See Troll.
The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or love deified.

A fabric made of fibrous material (or sometimes of wire, as in wire cloth); commonly, a woven fabric of cotton, woolen, or linen, adapted to be made into garments; specifically, woolen fabrics, as distinguished from all others.

A trench made in the earth by digging, particularly a trench for draining wet land, for guarding or fencing inclosures, or for preventing an approach to a town or fortress. In the latter sense, it is called also a moat or a fosse.
A variety of the common cabbage (Brassica oleracea major), having curled leaves, -- much cultivated for winter use.
A fat, oily substance; oinment.
A horse.

A plant of the genus Viola (Viola tricolor) and its blossom, originally purple and yellow.  Cultivated varieties have very large flowers of a great diversity of colors.  Called also heart's-ease, love-in-idleness, and many other quaint names.
One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serous membranes.
A disease of the scalp, produced by a vegetable parasite.
Same as Hilum, 2.
A canelike grass of southern Europe (Arundo Donax), used for fishing rods, etc.

The young or embryo of a vertebrate animal in the womb, or in the egg; often restricted to the later stages in the development of viviparous and oviparous animals. showing the main recognizable features of the mature animal, embryo being applied to the earlier stages.
A round or spherical body, solid or hollow; a body whose surface is in every part equidistant from the center; a ball; a sphere.
A man in private station, as distinguished from one holding a public office.
See Lamella.
meat from an adult domestic bovine.
A species of wild goose (Branta bernicla) -- called also brent and brand goose. The name is also applied to other related species.
A slip or piece.
The third letter (<GAMMA/, <gamma/ = Eng. G) of the Greek alphabet.

An intensely radioactive gaseous element produced by the radioactive decay of radium-226, which is the main isotope of radium found in pitchblende.  Chemically it is an inert noble gas.  Its atomic symbol is Rn. It has an atomic number of 86.  The radon isotope produced by decay of radium has an atomic weight of 222.017, and this isotope decays by alpha emission with a half-life of 3.82 days.  Numerous other isotopes have been observed, all radioactive and all having half-lives shorter than that of radon-222.  Radon was discovered by M. and Mme. Curie, of Paris, in their studies of the radioactive substances in pitchblende.  Radon was originally called  radium emanation or exradio.
Thrush.
A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat.
A red coloring matter. extracted from the Bignonia Chica, used by some tribes of South American Indians to stain the skin.
A hinge.
The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey through the wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food.
A piece or fragment of an earthen vessel, or a like brittle substance, as the shell of an egg or snail.

A vessel, boiler, or copper used in the distillation of liquids; specifically, one used for the distillation of alcoholic liquors; a retort. The name is sometimes applied to the whole apparatus used in in vaporization and condensation.
To swallow; especially, to swallow with greediness, or in large mouthfuls or quantities.

Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to the genus Mus and various related genera of the family Muridae.  The common house mouse (Mus musculus) is found in nearly all countries.  The American white-footed mouse, or deer mouse (Peromyscus leucopus, formerly Hesperomys leucopus) sometimes lives in houses.  See Dormouse, Meadow mouse, under Meadow, and Harvest mouse, under Harvest.
See Manteau.
Proof.
To pelt, beat, or kill with stones.
The twilight; gloaming.

A yellow carangoid fish of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts (Caranx chrysos), most abundant southward, where it is valued as a food fish; -- called also hardtail, horse crevall<eacute/, jack, buffalo jack, skipjack, yellow mackerel, and sometimes, improperly, horse mackerel. Other species of Caranx (as Caranx fallax) are also sometimes called jurel.
A human being.
A wearisome journey.
A plain sprinkled with trees or underbrush; a glade.
The rejected or waste parts of any process, especially the inedible parts of a butchered animal, such as the viscera.
The act of smiling; a peculiar change or brightening of the face, which expresses pleasure, moderate joy, mirth, approbation, or kindness; -- opposed to frown.
The country of Arabia.
A gambling game with dice.  It is one of the more popular games in casinos.
Tonicity, or tone; as, muscular tonus.
One who teases or plagues.
The ace of clubs in quadrille and omber.
One who hopes.
A small South American opossum (Didelphys quica), native of Guiana and Brazil. It feeds upon insects, small birds, and fruit.
A choice taw or marble.
Manliness; dignity; comeliness; civility.
See Catechu.
See 1st Pink.
A scurf or scabby disease, especially of the scalp.
The fireplace at the side of an annealing oven.
A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of low palms, but with exogenous wood.  See Coontie, and Illust. of Strobile.
The act of blowing; a roaring wind; a blast.
A fragrant kind of green tea.

Any of a variety of small magnifying glasses, having a magnifying power from 2X to 20X, commonly of 10X, which may be held in the hand, or in some cases held within the eyesocket without the use of a hand.  It is commonly used by jewelers and watchmakers.
Something thin, lean, or rough; a bony piece; especially, a bony neckpiece of meat; hence, humorously or in contempt, the neck.
A boomerang.

A genus of mosquitoes of the family Culicidae, to which most of the North American species belong.  Some members of this genus are exceedingly annoying, as Culex sollicitans, which breeds in enormous numbers in the salt marshes of the Atlantic coast, and Culex pipiens, the common house mosquito, breeding very widely in the fresh waters of North America. (For characters distinguishing these from the malaria mosquitoes, see Anopheles, above).  The yellow-fever mosquito is now placed in another genus, Stegomyia.
The name of several evergreen trees.  The wood is remarkable for its durability and fragrant odor.
An old English silver coin, equal to four pence.
A barbarous word used by the old chemists to designate various medical remedies.
A right; law in its aspect of the foundation of rights; also, in old law, the writ of right.
Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food; delicacies; dainties.
The first letter in the Greek alphabet, answering to A, and hence used to denote the beginning.
A tract of land, over which boats or goods are carried between two bodies of navigable water; a carrying place; a portage.
A sunken channel or groove, usually vertical. See Triglyph.
A plain.  See pampas.
A liquid measure in various countries of Europe. The Dutch anker, formerly also used in England, contained about 10 of the old wine gallons, or 8<frac12/ imperial gallons.
See Jigger.
The palm (or great black) cockatoo, of Australia (Microglossus aterrimus).
To regard or treat with honor, esteem, or respect; to revere; to treat with deference and submission; when used of the Supreme Being, to reverence; to adore; to worship.
A jest.
A decade.
One who hates.

A frame of wood, bent into the shape of the letter U, and embracing an ox's neck as a kind of collar, the upper ends passing through the bar of the yoke; also, anything so shaped, as a bend in a river.
See Shearn.
Tapestry; formerly, the cover of a council table.
Unreasonableness; absurdity.
A funeral feast.
See Whort.
See Capel.
Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy; as, he ate it with gusto.

Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors of electricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether, alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin (see Rosin).
A wind instrument of music, formerly in use, supposed to have resembled either the clarinet or the hautboy in form.
The act of moving round; routine; repetition.
Contagious or poisonous matter, as of specific ulcers, the bite of snakes, etc.; -- applied to organic poisons.
