A genus of venomous ticks which attack men and animals.  The famous Persian Argas, also called Miana bug, is Argas Persicus; that of Central America, called talaje by the natives, is Argas Talaje.
A sharp, abrupt noise, or succession of noises, made by striking an object.
An expression of disapprobation fir something deemed to be wrong; imputation of fault; censure.

A demise or letting of lands, tenements, or hereditaments to another for life, for a term of years, or at will, or for any less interest than that which the lessor has in the property, usually for a specified rent or compensation.
An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and Old Prussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.
A palace; a seraglio; also, in the East, a place for the accommodation of travelers; a caravansary, or rest house.
A shaft or gallery to drain a mine.
The act of twirling; a rapid circular motion; a whirl or whirling; quick rotation.
The heat, or utmost violence, of an onset; the strength or greatest fury of any contention; as, the brunt of a battle.
That which is seized by violence or obtained by robbery, especially collective spoil taken in war; plunder; pillage.
A line above or below a hanging net, to which the net is attached in order to strengthen it.
A boat; a small vessel.
A number of foxes together.
An ant.
Leaf of lard.
A decree of the Sultan.
A woman supposed to be endowed with a spirit of prophecy.
To take out or up with, a scoop; to lade out.
A plain face or plinth at the lower part of a wall.
a Philippine dish of marinated vegetables and meat or fish; served with rice.
In churches, a kind of closet, niche, cupboard, or locker for utensils, vestments, etc.
A loud burst of voice or voices; a vehement and sudden outcry, especially of a multitudes expressing joy, triumph, exultation, or animated courage.
An inclosed place; especially, a small field or piece of land surrounded by a wall, hedge, or fence of any kind; -- specifically, the precinct of a cathedral or abbey.
The blindworm.
One who places things in a pile.
A sound of quick movement, as of something whirled through the air.
An apartment for the reception of company; hence, in the plural, fashionable parties; circles of fashionable society.
Fright; esp., sudden fright produced by a trifling cause, or originating in mistake.
Indian millet and its varieties. See Sorghum.
A wading bird of the genus Grus, and allied genera, of various species, having a long, straight bill, and long legs and neck.
a single computer instruction which symbolizes, and is converted at the time of program execution or by a compiler into, a series of instructions in the same computer language.
A deputy or viceroy in India; a governor of a province of the ancient Mogul empire.
The lower and loose part of a coat, dress, or other like garment; the part below the waist; as, the skirt of a coat, a dress, or a mantle.
The offspring of animals, either a single animal or offspring collectively.
A clinkerbuit, narrow boat for sculling.
A female foal or colt; a young mare.  Cf. Colt, Foal.
See Umber.
That which is most bad or evil; the most severe, pernicious, calamitous, or wicked state or degree.

A colorless liquid, C4H8O2, obtained by condensation of two molecules of acetaldehyde: CH3CHO + CH3CHO = H3CH(OH)CH2CO; also, any of various derivatives of this. The same reaction has been applied, under the name of aldol condensation, to the production of many compounds.
A boy; especially, a boy servant.

A method of notation for all spoken sounds, proposed by Mr. Sweet; -- so called because it is based on the common Roman-letter alphabet. It is like the palaeotype of Mr. Ellis in the general plan, but simpler.
A tern.
A thin board; a billet of wood; a splinter.
An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiary ridge between two mountain gorges.
The European polecat; also, its fur.
a person's power or discretionary action; as, my fate is in your hands.

a unit of frequency equal to one cycle per second; it is abbreviated Hz.  It is commonly used to specify the frequency of radio waves, and also the clock frequencies in digital computers.  For these applications, kilohertz and megahertz are the most commonly used units, derived from hertz.
A colloquial abbreviation of midshipman.
See Paage.
a prior conviction; -- said of an accused criminal.
One of the large feathers of a bird's wing, or one of the rectrices of the tail; also, the stock of such a feather.
A premium given for a loan, or for a charter or other privilege granted to a company; as the bank paid a bonus for its charter.
Ebony.
The dziggetai.
Like pulp; consisting of pulp; soft; fleshy; succulent; as, the pulpy covering of a nut; the pulpy substance of a peach or a cherry.
Home-made wines, cordials, metheglin, etc.
Account; reckoning; computation.
A battle; an engagement; a contest in arms; a combat; a violent conflict or struggle for victory, between individuals or between armies, ships, or navies, etc.
A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the face of a woman and the body of a vulture, with long claws, and the face pale with hunger.  Some writers mention two, others three.
A yellow pigment of various degrees of intensity, approaching also to red.
See Xebec.
A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.
A kind of brittle limestone.
A hypothetical radical of glycerin.
The bindings of a hedge.
The sign <flat/; the same as B flat.
The act of one who climbs; ascent by climbing.
The two anterior of the four lobes on the dorsal side of the midbrain of most mammals; the anterior optic lobes.

Anything composed of parts fitted and united together; a fabric; a structure; esp., the constructional system, whether of timber or metal, that gives to a building, vessel, etc., its model and strength; the skeleton of a structure.

One of the sonant mutes <beta/, <delta/, <gamma/ (b, d, g), in Greek, or of their equivalents in other languages, so named as intermediate between the tenues, <pi/, <tau/, <kappa/ (p, t, k), and the aspiratae  (aspirates) <phi/, <theta/, <chi/ (ph or f, th, ch). Also called middle mute, or medial, and sometimes soft mute.
A Ceylonese boat. See Doni.

A shelly concretion, usually rounded, and having a brilliant luster, with varying tints, found in the mantle, or between the mantle and shell, of certain bivalve mollusks, especially in the pearl oysters and river mussels, and sometimes in certain univalves.  It is usually due to a secretion of shelly substance around some irritating foreign particle.  Its substance is the same as nacre, or mother-of-pearl.
See Prian.
The same prepared with a vehicle, as oil, water with gum, or the like, for application to a surface.
A punting pole with a broad flange near the end to prevent it from sinking into the mud; a setting pole.

A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in a state of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme by the action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals, and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.
Thread or cloth made of flax or (rarely) of hemp; -- used in a general sense to include cambric, shirting, sheeting, towels, tablecloths, etc.; as, bed linens
A stream of gas or vapor emitting light and heat in the process of combustion; a bright flame.
A tuft, or other excrescence or natural ornament, growing on an animal's head; the comb of a cock; the swelling on the head of a serpent; the lengthened feathers of the crown or nape of bird, etc.
Something in addition to what is due, expected, or customary; esp., an added charge or fee, or something for which an additional charge is made; as, at some hotels air conditioning is an extra.
a total failure in a recitation.
A native prince or king; also, a landholder or person of importance in the agricultural districts.
any chemical compound containing the azido group -N3, such as sodium azide (ionic and inorganic) or ethyl azide (organic and nonionic).
That which is affixed; an appendage; esp. one or more letters or syllables added at the end of a word; a suffix; a postfix.
Doctor of Philosophy, a British doctorate.
The California poison oak (Rhus diversiloba).  See under Poison, a.
See Cultch.
A fief. See Fief.
A fish allied to the turbot (Rhombus levis), much esteemed in England for food; -- called also bret, pearl, prill. See Bret.
See Corf.

Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging to Anthus and allied genera, of the family Motacillid<ae/. They strongly resemble the true larks in habits, colors, and the great length of the hind claw. They are, therefore, often called titlarks, and pipit larks.
The bulau.
An enemy of the gods, esp. one of a race of demons and giants.
A flat tablet or ledge of any material set horizontally at a distance from the floor, to hold objects of use or ornament.
A kind of black tea.
A fragment or part of anything separated from the whole, in any manner, as by cutting, splitting, breaking, or tearing; a part; a portion; as, a piece of sugar; to break in pieces.
Scantness; scarcity.
A dry measure of four bushels, or half a quarter.
Treacherous; betraying.
A small anchor used whenever a large one can be dispensed with. See Kedge, v. t., and Anchor, n.
A watered, clouded, or frosted appearance on textile fabrics or metallic surfaces.
See Steen.
A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor of spirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium.
Defect; want; lack; default.
A gliding, slipping, or gradual falling; an unobserved or imperceptible progress or passing away,; -- restricted usually to immaterial things, or to figurative uses.

A black man; especially, one of a race of black or very dark persons who inhabit the greater part of tropical Africa, and are distinguished by crisped or curly hair, flat noses, and thick protruding lips; also, any black person of unmixed African blood, wherever found.
The grit worn away from grindstones in grinding cutlery wet.
The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet of paper; -- opposed to recto.
To place or dispose in order, as troops for battle; to marshal.
the genus comprising the most common varieties of shad.  It replaces the older term Clupea.  See also shad.
performance of moral or religious acts; salvation is not by deeds, but by faith; to do good deeds.
One who, or that which, mows; a mowing machine; as, a lawn mower.
A round hill or point of land; hence, Morro castle, a castle on a hill.
The agency for another who acts through the agent; authority to act for another, esp. to vote in a legislative or corporate capacity.
A reprimand; a rebuke.
Same as Bolty.
A petty money of accounts of Persia; 100 dinars consituted a rial.

The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and so named by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata, which are called in German the Bunter sandstein, Muschelkalk, and Keuper.
Scent or savor of meat or food, cooked or cooking.
A round-up. See Round-up.
The prow or fore part of a ship.
A rich goblet, esp. one used on state occasions.

A drama, either tragic or comic, of which music forms an essential part; a drama wholly or mostly sung, consisting of recitative, arias, choruses, duets, trios, etc., with orchestral accompaniment, preludes, and interludes, together with appropriate costumes, scenery, and action; a lyric drama.
To search for; to examine.
Milk sickness.

The plea or mode of defense under which a person on trial for a crime proves or attempts to prove that he was in another place when the alleged act was committed; as, to set up an alibi; to prove an alibi.
Same as Doorga.
See Spinny.
A house or shed built of boards, boughs, or other slight materials, for temporary occupation.
a small South American spiny tree (Erythrina crista-galli) with dark crimson and scarlet flowers solitary or clustered.
A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsome lady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.
An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make tea canisters.
The lead glaze used for pottery.

A system of electronic navigation in which a vessel or aircraft determines its latitude and longitude by measuring the time differences between low frequency radio transmissions from two stationary transmitters (slaves) and a stationary master transmitter.  Contrary to the name, Loran is a medium range system, usually effective for no more than a few hundred miles from shore.  The first commercial system was called Loran A; the latest (and final) development is Loran C.
A small, light boat.
A kind of triangular spade.
An addition to, or a paraphrase of, some part of the Latin service in the vernacular; -- common in English before the Reformation.
Any plant of the natural order Cycadace<ae/, as the sago palm, etc.
See Comb.
A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
A bearing of a rhomboidal figure; -- named from its shape, which resembles that of a spindle.
A sweet viscid fluid, esp. that collected by bees from flowers of plants, and deposited in the cells of the honeycomb.
School.
One of the Aztec race or people.
A goblin; a specter; a frightful phantom; a bogy; a bugbear.
Act of gulching or gulping.

A form of croquet modified for greater accuracy of play. The court has a wood border often faced with rubber, used as a cushion in bank shots. The balls are 3<frac14/ in. in diameter, the cage (center arches or wickets) 3<frac38/ in. wide, the other arches 3<frac12/ in. wide.
An electro-negative atom or group of atoms, or the element which, in electro-chemical decompositions, is evolved at the anode; -- opposed to cation.
Rising.
A store, stock, or quantity of anything accumulated or laid up; a hidden supply; a treasure; as, a hoard of provisions; a hoard of money.
Same as Delftware.
To utter or make a low, dull, monotonous, humming or murmuring sound.
A person infected with a filthy or pestilential disease; a leper.
One who, or that which, mixes.
A pearly substance which lines the interior of many shells, and is most perfect in the mother-of-pearl.
Half-roasted ore.
An untimely birth.
Scotland; esp. the Highlands of Scotland.
A share; a part or portion; -- obsolete, except in the colloquial phrase, to go snacks, i. e., to share.
A genus of grasses, including the common oat (Avena sativa); the oat grasses.
A thrust.
A dwelling house, generally with land attached.
An abalone.
An image.
The tolling of a bell; a knell.
The language spoken in the Isle of Man. See Manx.
Same as papaya, senses 1 and 2.
A number of men who relieve others in carrying on some work.
A feat hard to perform; an act which is striking for the skill, strength, or the like, required to do it; a feat.
The track or trail of any wild animal; as, the spoor of an elephant; -- used originally by travelers in South Africa.
A gold coin of Rome, worth 64 shillings 11 pence sterling, or about $ 15.70.
A variant of Height.
The external occipital protuberance of the skull.
See Spunk.
A surcingle, or strap of leather, used for binding a load upon the back of a beast; also, a leather tie; a short wagon rope.
The first part; the earliest stage; the beginning or opening, as of the day, the year, etc.; hence, the dawn; the spring.
The commonalty of ancient Rome who were citizens without the usual political rights; the plebeians; -- distinguished from the patricians.

The C.G.S. unit of density of magnetic field, equal to a field of one line of force per square centimeter, being thus adopted as an international unit at Paris in 1900; sometimes used as a unit of intensity of magnetic field. It was previously suggested as a unit of magnetomotive force.
The tincture red, indicated in seals and engraved figures of escutcheons by parallel vertical lines. Hence, used poetically for a red color or that which is red.

The inner bark of plants, lying next to the wood. It usually contains a large proportion of woody, fibrous cells, and is, therefore, the part from which the fiber of the plant is obtained, as that of hemp, etc.
A genus of composite plants, of which one species (Madia sativa) is cultivated for the oil yielded from its seeds by pressure.  This oil is sometimes used instead of olive oil for the table.
A bracelet.
Report; rumor; fame.
A spirit, or immaterial being, holding a middle place between men and deities in pagan mythology.
An organic body or cell having locomotion, as a spermatic cell or spermatozooid.
A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin, with long barbs which are engrailed on the inner edge.
See Bromine.

A long-nosed monkey (Nasalis larvatus, formerly Semnopithecus nasalis), native of Borneo. The general color of the body is bright chestnut, with the under parts, shoulders, and sides of the head, golden yellow, and the top of the head and upper part of the back brown. Called also proboscis monkey.  It is now an endangered species.
See Cymry.
Forbearance to inflict harm under circumstances of provocation, when one has the power to inflict it; compassionate treatment of an offender or adversary; clemency.
A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise, as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc.
A spiral; a curl; a whorl; a twist.
A person who is tough{7}; a ruffian; a thug; as, a cluster of neighborhood toughs hanging out on the corner.
A gust of wind and rain.
See Favus, n., 2.
Upbraiding language; bitter or sarcastic reproach; insulting invective.
A character or point [,] marking the smallest divisions of a sentence, written or printed.
A retinue or company of attendants, as of a distinguished personage; as, the suite of an ambassador. See Suit, n., 5.
A lawyer.
The act of offering, bringing forward, proposing, or bidding; a proffer; a first advance.
See Wends.

A dwarf umbelliferous plant, somewhat resembling fennel (Cuminum Cyminum), cultivated for its seeds, which have a bitterish, warm taste, with an aromatic flavor, and are used like those of anise and caraway.
The sum of four tens; forty units or objects.
See Eyelet.
See Throse.
The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob.
Not firmly woven; that ravels.
The carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.
A borough or incorporated town, especially, one in Scotland. See Borough.

A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The species found in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of Northern Africa is Hyrax Brucei; -- called also ashkoko, dassy, and rock rabbit. See Cony, and Hyrax.
Coma with complete insensibility; deep lethargy.
An ultimate atom, or simple, unextended point; something ultimate and indivisible.
A drinking vessel. See Quaich.
A kind of military cap or headdress.
A raised structure (as a square or oblong erection of stone or wood) on which sacrifices are offered or incense burned to a deity.
One who adheres to or believes the doctrines of Arius.
the Rock of Gibraltar, a limestone promontory at the southern tip of Spain; associated with Britain.
See Litchi.
A proportional part or share; the share or proportion assigned to each in a division.
A savory meat jelly containing portions of fowl, game, fish, hard boiled eggs, etc.
Any modified leaf, or scale, on a flower stalk or at the base of a flower.
The great artery which carries the blood from the heart to all parts of the body except the lungs; the main trunk of the arterial system.
A little mass or weight of lead, or the like, attached to a line, and used by builders, etc., to indicate a vertical direction; a plummet; a plumb bob. See Plumb line, below.
One who fires or sets fire to anything; an incendiary.
The magpie.
See Pekoe.
A precipitous bank or rock; a scar.
A view; especially, a view through or between intervening objects, as trees; a view or prospect through an avenue, or the like; hence, the trees or other objects that form the avenue.

A native of the Caribbee islands or the coasts of the Caribbean sea; esp., one of a tribe of Indians inhabiting a region of South America, north of the Amazon, and formerly most of the West India islands.
(Irish) one of a group of sea demons sometimes associated with the hostile power of nature.
An explosive consisting of ammonium nitrate, a derivative of nitrobenzene, chlorated napthalene, and wood meal.
The young of a canine animal, esp. of the common dog; a whelp.
A stupid person.
Improper treatment or use; application to a wrong or bad purpose; misuse; as, an abuse of our natural powers; an abuse of civil rights, or of privileges or advantages; an abuse of language.
To go; to fare.
A vibrant or whirring noise such as that made by some insects, as the cockchafer, or by some birds, as the nightjar, the partridge, etc.
See 4th Ware.
Departure; exodus; esp., the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.
A woman who practices unlawful sexual commerce with men, especially one who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.
A kind of woolen stuff.
See Stirk.
Soft mud.
A bigamist.
A water course.

A bitter, brownish yellow, amorphous substance, extracted from vegetable mold, and also produced by the action of acids on certain sugars and carbohydrates; -- called also humic acid, ulmin, gein, ulmic or geic acid, etc.
The peculiar dress worn by pilgrims to Mecca.
Meat, especially beef, that has been cut in strips and dried; meat that has been jerked; see first jerk, v.; as, beef jerky
One of the long, pliable twigs of this plant, or of other similar plants.
One who practices robbery on the seas; a pirate.
A bit of wood split off; a splinter.
See Crewel.
A sauce made of small fish. It was prized by the ancients.
Same as Kaffir.
Force or power of any kind, whether of body or mind; energy or intensity of purpose, feeling, or action; means or resources to effect an object; strength; force; power; ability; capacity.
Nitroglycerin.

The relation which one quantity or magnitude has to another of the same kind. It is expressed by the quotient of the division of the first by the second; thus, the ratio of 3 to 6 is expressed by <frac36/ or <frac12/; of a to b by a/b; or (less commonly) the second term is made the dividend; as, a:b = b/a.
A mean, sneaking fellow.
Something given or admitted; a fact or principle granted; that upon which an inference or an argument is based; -- used chiefly in the plural.
A genus of small beetles, of which one species (the grapevine Fidia, F. longipes) is very injurious to vines in America.
Var. of Soldier.
A corruption of the word faith.
To resolve into its elements, as a sentence, pointing out the several parts of speech, and their relation to each other by government or agreement; to analyze and describe grammatically.

The standard unit of electrical capacity; the capacity of a condenser whose charge, having an electro-motive force of one volt, is equal to the amount of electricity which, with the same electromotive force, passes through one ohm in one second; the capacity, which, charged with one coulomb, gives an electro-motive force of one volt.

A tropical tree, or its fruit, of the genus Psidium.  Two varieties are well known, the P. pyriferum, or white guava, and P. pomiferum, or red guava.  The fruit or berry is shaped like a pomegranate, but is much smaller. It is somewhat astringent, but makes a delicious jelly.
A sheeling.
A European fresh-water fish (Tinca tinca, or Tinca vulgaris) allied to the carp. It is noted for its tenacity of life.
A drab; a strumpet; a harlot; a trollop.
The act of upsetting, or the state of being upset; an overturn; as, the wagon had an upset.
The siamang; -- called also ungka ape.
Devexity.
Flexible wood worked into the top of hedge stakes, to bind them together.

The act of visiting, or going to see a person or thing; a brief stay of business, friendship, ceremony, curiosity, or the like, usually longer than a call; as, a visit of civility or respect; a visit to Saratoga; the visit of a physician.
an illicitly distilled (and usually inferior) alcoholic liquor.
A lake steamer or canal boat.
Wood that readily takes fire; touchwood; also, a kind of tinder made from a species of fungus; punk; amadou.
To draw or keep near; to approach.
A sudden flowing; a rush which fills or overflows, as of water for cleansing purposes.
A rush.
A falcon (Falco sacer) native of Southern Europe and Asia, closely resembling the lanner.
A strap of leather; especially, one used for fastening anything.
aggravation or aggression.

A mode of expressing words and phrases by pictures of objects whose names resemble those words, or the syllables of which they are composed; enigmatical representation of words by figures; hence, a peculiar form of riddle made up of such representations.
Smooth and bright or translucent; -- used almost exclusively of ice; as, skating on glare ice.
A large stream of water flowing in a bed or channel and emptying into the ocean, a sea, a lake, or another stream; a stream larger than a rivulet or brook.
A shelf on which articles may be laid; also, that which resembles such a shelf in form or use, as a projecting ridge or part, or a molding or edge in joinery.
Prey.
Same as Spade, 2.
A waxy substance containing fatty acids, soaps, and resinous material which, combined with cellulose, forms a substance nearly impervious to water and constituting the cuticle in plants.
A white (caucasian) person; -- a term used by some African-Americans, intended to be disparaging and often taken as offensive.
The act of stamping, as with the foot.
A genus of marine univalve shells; the harp shells; -- so called from the form of the shells, and their ornamental ribs.
See Caliph.
An order or subclass of cryptogamous plants; the mosses. See Moss, and Cryptogamia.
A girdle.
A grove.
A native or inhabitant of Latium; a Roman.

A weapon of war, consisting of a long shaft or handle and a steel blade or head; a spear carried by horsemen, and often decorated with a small flag; also, a spear or harpoon used by whalers and fishermen.
Rock.
An aboriginal war club.
An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine, or to impart nourishment.
A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.
A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said to devour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; a witch.

A line or surface to which, at every point, a vertical or plumb line is perpendicular; a line or surface which is everywhere parallel to the surface of still water; -- this is the true level, and is a curve or surface in which all points are equally distant from the center of the earth, or rather would be so if the earth were an exact sphere.
See Sirocco.
A single oar used at the stern in propelling a boat.
A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems and whorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
Anything intended to lead into a snare; a lure that deceives and misleads into danger, or into the power of an enemy; a bait.
A strong, offensive smell; stench; fetidness.
One that fumes.
An adz; a hoe.
A young buck in the third year. See the Note under Buck.
Poke (Phytolacca decandra).
The earthy or mineral particles of combustible substances remaining after combustion, as of wood or coal.
The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.
Of a dull yellowish brown color, like things tanned, or persons who are sunburnt; as, tawny Moor or Spaniard; the tawny lion.
A census; -- also, a public rate or tax.
The rump of beef; esp., the lower and back part of the rump.
A small drain.
A set or sequence of five, as in piquet.
Trowsers; especially, those of the Scotch Highlanders.
A woody plant of less size than a tree, and usually with several stems from the same root.
A kind of sirup made by the Indians of Arizona from the fruit of some cactaceous plant (probably the Cereus giganteus).
The source of electrical power in a building; the wiring system of a building.
A person of rank above a commoner; a nobleman; a peer.
To form into ringlets; to curl; to crimp; to friz; as, to crape the hair; to crape silk.
See <ae/dile.
An island. See Eyot.
A step (in a flight of stairs); a degree.
A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomach by gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany; bloating.
A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly if associated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bones of the nose.
a genus of elk or moose.
Same as Brier.
See Waggel.
A species of Magnolia (Magnolia conspicua) with large white blossoms that open before the leaves.  See the Note under Magnolia.
The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.
A tall drinking cup.
The face; the countenance or its expression.
The pungent grayish green flower bud of the European and Oriental caper (Capparis spinosa), much used for pickles.
The fossil resin of the kauri tree of New Zealand.
The small, troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus and lower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids. See Hemorrhoids. [The singular pile is sometimes used.]
A small European river fish (Leuciscus alburnus), of the family Cyprinid<ae/; the blay.
A perennial alliaceous plant (Allium fistulosum), sometimes called Welsh onion. Its fistular leaves areused in cookery.
A tall, coarse grass (Imperata arundinacea) of the Philippine Islands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
A confused heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as of sounds.

A material of short fiber and inferior quality obtained by deviling woolen rags or the remnants of woolen goods, specif. those of felted, milled, or hard-spun woolen cloth, as distinguished from shoddy, or the deviled product of loose-textured woolen goods or worsted, -- a distinction often disregarded.
The grain left after harvest or gleaning; also, nuts which have fallen to the ground.
A neighborhood or near place; the place or county in which anything is alleged to have happened; also, the place where an action is laid.

One of a primitive people supposed to have lived in prehistoric times, in Central Asia, east of the Caspian Sea, and north of the Hindu Kush and Paropamisan Mountains, and to have been the stock from which sprang the Hindu, Persian, Greek, Latin, Celtic, Teutonic, Slavonic, and other races; one of that ethnological division of mankind called also Indo-European or Indo-Germanic.
A short concise writing or letter; a statement in few words.
One of the two prominences at the posterior extremity of the frog of the horse's foot.
A substance that is held in a fixed form by cohesion among its particles; a substance not fluid.
a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
A whirlpool.
To express gratitude to (anyone) for a favor; to make acknowledgments to (anyone) for kindness bestowed; -- used also ironically for blame.
A collection of twelve objects; a tale or set of twelve; with or without of before the substantive which follows.
See Gumbo.
A deputy ruler or viceroy in India; also, a title given by courtesy to other persons of high rank in the East.
A structure appended to a larger edifice for a special purpose, as for a belfry, and then usually high in proportion to its width and to the height of the rest of the edifice; as, a church tower.
One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the cranes, and were destroyed.
Something scraped off; hence, a small piece; a bit; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.
A measure of land in India, varying from a third of an acre to an acre.
A kind of ornamental firework.
The cheetah.
A tract of soft wet land, commonly covered partially or wholly with water; a fen; a swamp; a morass.
Nothing.
a type of rye bread, made using molasses or brown sugar.
See Attar.
A cup or dish.
Moisture, especially, the moisture or fluid of animal bodies, as the chyle, lymph, etc.; as, the humors of the eye, etc.
A winning of all the tricks at the game of piquet. It counts for forty points.
The arch over the dam of a blast furnace; the tymp arch.
Border; margin; edge; verge.
The local environment; as, he hasn't been seen around these parts in years.
A two-footed animal, as man.
a petty officer on a merchant ship who controls the work of other seamen; a contraction of boatswain.
The principal rafters of a roof, especially a pair of rafters taken together.
The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
The divine energy, personified as the wife of a deity (Brahma, Vishnu, Siva, etc.); the female principle.
Any plant of the labiate genus Thymus. The garden thyme (Thymus vulgaris) is a warm, pungent aromatic, much used to give a relish to seasoning and soups.
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
Diminutive of Dad.
Cleaning; afterbirth.
A quaternary deposit, usually consisting of a fine yellowish earth, on the banks of the Rhine and other large rivers.
The electric catfish.
The Baltic or variable cod (Gadus callarias), by some believed to be the young of the common codfish.
A lock of wool or hair.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.

A glucoside resembling, but distinct from, quercitrin.  Rutin is found in the leaves of the rue (Ruta graveolens) and other plants, and obtained as a bitter yellow crystalline substance which yields quercitin on decomposition.
A swamp.

Lit., skilled mechanical work, such as that required in wood carving; trade work; hence, a system (usually called the sloyd system) of manual training in the practical use of the tools and materials used in the trades, and of instruction in the making and use of the plans and specifications connected with trade work. The  sloyd system derives its name from the fact that it was adopted or largely developed from a similar Swedish system, in which wood carving was a chief feature. Its purpose is not only to afford practical skill in some trade, but also to develop the pupils mentally and physically.
See Souse.
The fruit of the oak, being an oval nut growing in a woody cup or cupule.
A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothing ceilings, etc.

A colorless gaseous substance (O3) obtained (as by the silent discharge of electricity in oxygen) as an allotropic form of oxygen, containing three atoms in the molecule.  It is a strong oxidizer, and probably exists in the air, though by the ordinary tests it is liable to be confused with certain other substances, as hydrogen dioxide, or certain oxides of nitrogen.  It derives its name from its peculiar odor, which resembles that of weak chlorine.
A sandpiper (Terekia cinerea) of the Old World, breeding in the far north of eastern Europe and Asia and migrating to South Africa and Australia. It frequents rivers.
One of a race of filthy brutes resembling men but subject to the Houyhnhnms in Swift's <ldquo/Gulliver's Travels.<rdquo/  See in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction.
Same as Britzska.
A pen or inclosure of stakes and hurdles on the seacoast, for holding fish.
A mill for grinding grain, the upper stone of which was turned by hand; -- used before the invention of windmills and watermills.
A plant (Salvia sclarea) of the Sage family, used in flavoring soups.
A Russian peasant (especially prior to 1917).
A female servant charged with the care of a young child.
See Kaiser.
A mother.
See Sneck.
The thickest part, or the time when anything is thickest.
Wine, -- chiefly used in Pharmacy in the name of solutions of some medicinal substance in wine; as: vina medicata, medicated wines; vinum opii, wine of opium.
The malicious burning of a dwelling house or outhouse of another man, which by the common law is felony; the malicious and voluntary firing of a building or ship.
A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.
Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa.  Many varieties are cultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers.
The way or fashion of people at any particular time; temporary mode, custom, or practice; popular reception for the time; -- used now generally in the phrase in vogue.

A self-evident and necessary truth, or a proposition whose truth is so evident as first sight that no reasoning or demonstration can make it plainer; a proposition which it is necessary to take for granted; as, <ldquo/The whole is greater than a part;<rdquo/  <ldquo/A thing can not, at the same time, be and not be.<rdquo/
Ten millions; as, a crore of rupees (which is nearly $5,000,000).

A silver coin of France, and since 1795 the unit of the French monetary system. It has been adopted by Belgium and Swizerland. In 1913 it was equivalent to about nineteen cents American, or ten pence British, and is divided into 100 centimes.
Same as Mazer.

The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief administrative officer of a municipal corporation.  In some American cities there is a city court of which the major is chief judge.  The post is usually elective, its holder chosen by the electorate of the entire city.

The blind mole rat (Spalax typhlus), native of Eastern Europe and Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft and brownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensive burrows.
A coral island or islands, consisting of a belt of coral reef, partly submerged, surrounding a central lagoon or depression; a lagoon island.
A paint; a dye; also, false show.
An escape.
One who loses; as, the loser pays for a round of beer.

A fat, liquid at ordinary temperatures, but solidifying at temperatures below 0<deg/ C., found abundantly in both the animal and vegetable kingdoms (see Palmitin).  It dissolves solid fats, especially at 30-40<deg/ C.  Chemically, olein is a glyceride of oleic acid; and, as three molecules of the acid are united to one molecule of glycerol to form the fat, it is technically known as triolein.  It is also called elain.
A corruption of Annotto.
Character or construction of a thing as determining its external appearance; outward aspect; make; figure; form; guise; as, the shape of a tree; the shape of the head; an elegant shape.
A shrew.
One who guards, protects, watches over, or has the care of, some person or thing.
One who gazes.

The opening through which an animal receives food; the aperture between the jaws or between the lips; also, the cavity, containing the tongue and teeth, between the lips and the pharynx; the buccal cavity.
One who dozes or drowses.
A heart.
One of a series of series of complex nitrogenous substances, represented by methyl ketol and related to indol.
A pagoda.
The orange-colored pulp covering the seeds of the tropical plant Bixa Orellana, from which annotto is prepared. See Annoto.
Any carnivore of the genus Mellivora, allied to the weasels and the skunks; -- called also honey badger.
See 4th Crowd.
That which is held as an opinion; a tenet; a doctrine.
A waif; a castaway.
Same as Achene.

One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra.
Amall shrubby African tree (Brachystegia speciformis) having compound leaves and racemes of small fragrant green flowers.
A native of Sind, India, esp. one of the native Hindoo stock.
a gloomy mental state; same as 2nd dump{1}; -- used mostly in the phrase <ldquo/in the dumps<rdquo/.
A little moon or satellite.
A spot or stain; also, a trick.
The entire thing; the entire assemblage of parts; totality; all of a thing, without defect or exception; a thing complete in itself.
A genus of ruminants, including the common goat.
A Chaldean astronomical period or cycle, the length of which has been variously estimated from 3,600 years to 3,600 days, or a little short of 10 years.
The aboriginal and most numerous inhabitants of Borneo. They are partially civilized, but retain many barbarous practices.
A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
Used in English only in the expression en creux. Thus, engraving en creux is engraving in intaglio, or by sinking or hollowing out the design.

One of several species of large, crested ground pigeons of the genus Goura, inhabiting New Guinea and adjacent islands. The Queen Victoria pigeon (Goura Victoria) and the crowned pigeon (G. coronata) are among the best known species.
One who pries; one who inquires narrowly and searches, or is inquisitive.
Prey; plunder; booty.
A bumper in honor of a toast or health.
Want of tone; weakness of the system, or of any organ, especially of such as are contractile.

One of a class of basic substances derived from ammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by an alkyl or aryl group.  Compare amide, in which an acyl group is attached to the nitrogen.  Hydroxylamine and hydrazine, which are not an organic compounds, are also basic and may also be considered amines.
See Skean.
a narrow waterway leading into a harbor.
A fat herring with undeveloped roe.
One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by the action of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
To penetrate with a pointed instrument; to pierce; to stab; hence, to kill by piercing; as, to stick a beast.
A place in a pagan temple in which the images of the deities were inclosed.
pl. of Wife.
A frame (commonly) of wood serving to hold a canvas upright, or nearly upright, for the painter's convenience or for exhibition.
The coarse part of flax or hemp; hards.
Act of thinking; a thought.
A secluded, private, or obscure way; a path or road aside from the main one.
The proximal segment of the hind limb containing the thigh bone; the thigh. See Coxa.
Same as Moodir.
A knot; a cluster; a group; a crowd; a flock; as, a plump of trees, fowls, or spears.
The helm or tiller of a vessel or boat; also, the rudder.
A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indian zinziberaceous plant (Curcuma angustifolia); also, the plant itself.

The fronds of certain marine alg<ae/ used as food, and for making a sauce called laver sauce.  Green laver is the Ulva latissima; purple laver, Porphyra laciniata and Porphyra vulgaris. It is prepared by stewing, either alone or with other vegetables, and with various condiments; -- called also sloke, or sloakan.
Five hundred; as, a mease of herrings.
Mania; insanity.
A boatman; an oarsman.
A bundle of sticks, twigs, or small branches of trees, used for fuel, for raising batteries, filling ditches, or other purposes in fortification; a fascine.
A spirit; a ghost; an apparition; a hobgoblin.
A tern; the sea swallow.
A kind of woolen, or woolen and cotton, cloth, often highly glazed, -- used for curtains, sieves, strainers, etc.
An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue.
A rounded or conical heap of stones erected by early inhabitants of the British Isles, apparently as a sepulchral monument.
A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament.  Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
To make a short stop; to cease for a time; to intermit speaking or acting; to stop; to wait; to rest.
An arch, or ceiling, of boards, placed over the men's heads in a mine.
A nobleman on the continent of Europe, equal in rank to an English earl.
See Dun crow, under Dun, a.
Labor; toilsome effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural in form, but used with a singular or plural verb, commonly the former.
Chaparajos.
One who, or that which, bites; that which bites often, or is inclined to bite, as a dog or fish.
An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angels and saints as the servants of God.

A thong of leather, or a long cord, by which a person may hold or restrain an animal, such as a falconer holding his hawk, or a courser his dog.  For dogs and cats, the leash is commonly attached to a collar around the neck of the animal.
The Muslim tribes of the southern Philippine Islands, said to have formerly migrated from Borneo.  Some of them are warlike and addicted to piracy.
A genus of endogenous herbs with grassy leaves and small yellow flowers in short, scaly-bracted spikes; yellow-eyed grass. There are about seventeen species in the Atlantic United States.
Same as Bourr<eacute/e.
A Cuban timber tree (Malpighia obovata) with hard wood very resistant to moisture.
That point of the heavens, or lower hemisphere, directly opposite the zenith; the inferior pole of the horizon; the point of the celestial sphere directly under the place where we stand.
A sign. See Al segno, and Dal segno.
See Teyne.
Animal fat; lard.
a country on the island of Hispaniola.
One who gives; a donor; a bestower; a grantor; one who imparts or distributes.
Paralysis, complete or partial. See Paralysis.
A hard, heavy, and durable wood, which admits of a fine polish or gloss. The usual color is black, but it also occurs red or green.
A tilting match; a mock combat on horseback between two knights in the lists or inclosed field.
A narrow piece, or one comparatively long; as, a strip of cloth; a strip of land.
The suslik.
Property; -- often used by Chaucer in contrast with rent, or income.
Something or someone that is phony.
The apartments or portion of the house allotted to females in Muslim families.
A gem of an azure color.
See Mulley.
Prussian leather.
a trade name for simvastatin.
A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to the cranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breasted trumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
To drive, as cattle or sheep, esp. on long journeys; to follow the occupation of a drover.
One who is dumb.

A shrub of the genus Syringa. There are six species, natives of Europe and Asia.  Syringa vulgaris, the common lilac, and Syringa Persica, the Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance and beauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British colonies various other shrubs have this name.
See 1st Fere.
A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; hence, a lady's flat workbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba.
The front compartment of a French diligence; also, the front compartment (usually for three persons) of a car or carriage on British railways.

A comprehensive name for all of the pretended arts which claim to produce effects by the assistance of supernatural beings, or departed spirits, or by a mastery of secret forces in nature attained by a study of occult science, including enchantment, conjuration, witchcraft, sorcery, necromancy, incantation, etc.
One who, or that which, puzzles; a difficult or inexplicable question or fact.
The white indris of Madagascar. It is regarded by the natives as sacred.
See Sola.
A race or variety of men or other animals (or of plants), perpetuating its special or distinctive characteristics by inheritance.
See Copse.
One who, or that which, imparts motion; a source of mechanical power.
A simpleton; a fool.

A kind of larva, or nurse, which is prroduced within the sporocyst of certain trematodes by asexual generation. It in turn produces, in the same way, either another generation of rediae, or else cercariae within its own body. Called also proscolex, and nurse. See Illustration in Appendix.
A nappy cloth.
Nonsecretion or defective secretion of urine; ischury.
A privy.
A vulture; the griffin.
A thick, viscid fluid; a clot, as of blood.
A white or buff-colored granular powder, C6H9N11, obtained by heating ammonium sulphocyanate.
Danger; risk; hazard; jeopardy; exposure of person or property to injury, loss, or destruction.
A kind of gaiter of waterproof cloth wrapped around the leg, used by soldiers, etc.
A gay or sportive action; a ludicrous, merry, or mischievous trick; a caper; a frolic.
Cerium oxide, CeO2, a white infusible substance constituting about one per cent of the material of the common incandescent mantle.
A neglected and untrained city boy; a young street Arab.
That which makes smooth; varnish.
See Gobbet.
A little island.
An arm of the sea; a frith.
Among Muslims, a warrior champion or veteran, esp. in the destruction of infidels.
A spy; a scout.
The waste piece of metal cast in this hole; hence, dross.
A native or inhabitant of Scio.
A mantelpiece.
An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures (usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
Same as Ampulla, 2.
A coin of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of the value of about twenty-eight cents (in 1913). See Crown, n., 9.
same as aoudad.
A genus of herbs with compound white or bluish flowers; starwort; Michaelmas daisy.
A copying machine which copies graphic matter by the action of light on an electrically charged photoconductive insulating surface in which the latent image is developed with a resinous powder.
A police station.
To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison.
A cry in war as the signal for indiscriminate slaughter.
Pulverized sugar candy.
trousers made of corduroy cloth; corduroys.
One that uses wings.
The brains.
A sudden and capricious inclination of the mind.
A vial.
Same as Eagre.
A husband; a master of a family.
A very thin, slight, transparent stuff, generally of silk; also, any fabric resembling silk gauze; as, wire gauze; cotton gauze.
See Croaker, n., 2. (a).
The process of soaking through anything.
a dividend, especially one paid by a cooperative society.

Plaster of Paris, or gypsum, esp. as prepared for use in painting, or in making bas-reliefs and the like; by extension, a plasterlike or pasty material spread upon a surface to fit it for painting or gilding, or a surface so prepared.
A collection of people; a company; a number; a multitude.
A student of the first year.
Fine clay or ocher made up into balls, used for marking sheep.
See Ph<oe/be.
A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered at one end.
One who gapes.
A pet or colloquial name for Mary.
An old term for a river boat.
An icicle.
The act of plucking; a pull; a twitch.
All; -- a direction for all the singers or players to perform together.
Same as Withe, n., 4.
A light one horse two-wheeled vehicle.
Manipulation applied to a hernial tumor, or to an intestinal obstruction, for the purpose of reducing it.
An armed ship having her upper deck cut away, and thus reduced to the next inferior rate, as a seventy-four cut down to a frigate.
One who taws; a dresser of white leather.
The act of evading by some skillful movement; a sudden starting aside; hence, an artful device to evade, deceive, or cheat; a cunning trick; an artifice.
Same as Jereed.
The syntactical or structural form peculiar to any language; the genius or cast of a language.
The elastic, aeriform fluid into which water is converted when heated to the boiling point; water in the state of vapor; gaseous water.
A collection of visible vapor, or watery particles, suspended in the upper atmosphere.
A lighted coal, smoldering amid ashes; -- used chiefly in the plural, to signify mingled coals and ashes; the smoldering remains of a fire.
The act of fainting, or the state of one who has fainted; a swoon. [R.] See Fainting, n.
A small yellow singing bird, with an ash-colored head; the European siskin. Called also tarin.
a European shad, (Alosa alosa).
A fruit tree (Durio zibethinus, the only species known) of the Indian Archipelago.  It bears the durian.
Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. See Vair.
a member of the people inhabiting the Aleutian Islands.  Same as Aleutian, n.
